HEADLINE: PRODUCTIVITY;
Cyberagencies Match Families With Modern Mary Poppinses

BYLINE: By BONNIE ROTHMAN MORRIS 

 BODY:
TERESA JOHNSON never wanted to be a nanny. After graduating from Oral Roberts University, she spent four years teaching band at a Christian school in Madison, Wis. When she wanted a new teaching job, possibly one that would take her overseas, she began her job hunt on the Internet.
"Somehow through my searching, nannies just came up," said Ms. Johnson, 30. The site she discovered, I Love My Nanny, advertised nanny jobs in Europe (www.ilovemynanny. com). Ms. Johnson began to rechart her future and eventually applied for work through another agency on line, Apple Pie, U.S.A (www.nanny.com). 
 There are other nanny-related sites, like www.nannynetwork.com, which bills itself as a listing of every agency nationwide and lets families and nannies find phone numbers, addresses and, where available, Web sites for agencies in their area. To help families with tax and payroll work, there is www.nannytaxes.com.
Today Ms. Johnson works as a nanny in East Hills, N.Y., on the North Shore of Long Island, caring for two school-age children. She has her own room, her own phone line and her own computer. Her French horn, which she has played for 18 years, is tucked away for now. She is a new breed of live-in nanny, the kind coveted by many families and, because of the Internet, increasingly available: college educated, at least 25 years old and accustomed to being away from home. She was lured to the profession by the prospect of a job in a glamorous location.
"It turned out that the overseas positions were filled already, but I thought even if I didn't go overseas, maybe I could be on the East Coast," said Ms. Johnson, who is thrilled to be in affluent East Hills, a place almost as foreign to her as Europe would be.
In the olden days of the nanny business -- that's about two years ago -- nanny employment agencies placed classified advertisements in local and college newspapers in the Midwest, trolling for prospective workers. That needle-in-a-haystack approach was expensive and inefficient. Many applicants were too young or too inexperienced or had sketchy, uncheckable backgrounds. But the Web is effecting some fundamental changes in nannydom.
About 5 percent of all preschool-age children are cared for by live-in nannies, governesses and au pairs. That's about one million child-care workers, 125,000 of whom are placed by approximately 500 nanny employment agencies, said Mary O'Connor, president of the International Nanny Association (www.nanny.org). Though that represents a slim slice of the child-care pie, there are still fewer qualified candidates than jobs. For would-be nannies and the families who hire them, the Web may help put more employable candidates into the mix.
Mary Clurman, who runs Apple Pie, U.S.A., a 14-year-old agency, put her business completely on the Web two years ago. Ms. Clurman, who places nannies directly with families and recruits them for other agencies, said she had more qualified nannies today than she could place. Leigh Billingsley, a mother of two in Tustin, Calif., who just hired her second nanny from the Net (her first returned home), said: "I've had so much luck with Internet nannies. There's an abundance of young women who are highly qualified and highly educated."
Web-based agencies are increasingly functioning as clearinghouses for many of the smaller nanny employment agencies nationwide who rely on them for candidates. These smaller agencies may have E-mail or simple billboard-type Web sites but many can't receive applications from candidates and families on line.
The Web-based agencies say they are standardizing the industry by codifying job descriptions and raising salaries, which average $350 a week nationwide, according to a survey of 300 readers in Nanny News, published by Apple Pie for nannies and their employers. Salaries in the New York metropolitan area and in other major cities can reach $800 to $1,000 weekly.
Salaries and job standards are well advertised on the more sophisticated sites, which attract college graduates who, like Ms. Johnson, may never have considered the career before. Many candidates view a nanny position as a stop on the way to "real life," allowing them to pay off student loans and figure out what's next.
Recruiting on line does have a downside: it's a little too easy. "Right around college graduation, we get tons of applications from women who don't have jobs yet, and after hours of going through the process with us, decide they don't want to be a nanny after all," said Jackie Williams, owner of I Love My Nanny. Once her agency decides that a candidate is serious, the matching process begins. The nannies, and the families seeking them, are screened.
The Web makes it easier for agencies to do background checks, too. Digging deeply -- tracing a phone number or address of a reference or verifying a college degree or the length of previous employment -- is simplified. The International Nanny Association warns, however, that background checks of criminal records are limited by state and Federal laws and may not show the whole picture.
"Finding nannies on the Internet is the very beginning," said Carol Solomon, owner of the New York Nanny Center (www.nynanny.com). Rigorous screening still involves person-to-person contact, Ms. Solomon said.
For qualified candidates, the process doesn't take long. Jennifer Staszewski, a 25-year-old graduate of the University of Wisconsin at Lacrosse, applied with Midwest Nannies (www.mwnanny.com). Her job search lasted one month. Now she works for a family in Short Hills, N.J.; she plans to be with them for a year, then go to graduate school.
While many agency owners say most of their clients learn of them by word of mouth, families in need of nannies are also using the Web. Some families are from remote areas where nannies and nanny agencies are nonexistent.
Ed Stansfield, the manager of the Merrill Lynch office in Hanover, N.H., and his wife, Amy, administrative director of Dartmouth's Hitchcock Medical Center, started searching for a nanny to care for their 6-year-old son through I Love My Nanny. Mr. Stansfield likes to use the Internet, so using it to find a nanny was natural for him. He was directed to the site by his sister-in-law, Ms. Billingsley in California. The Stansfields live on a mountaintop on 60 acres; their driveway is a mile long. They wanted their nanny to be athletic and not afraid of isolation.
"I give a lot of credit to the technology edge for making the quicker match," said Mr. Stansfield, whose college-educated nanny, Tara Olcott, applied through the Internet. She grew up in Vermont, where her nearest neighbor lived a half-mile away. Isolation isn't a problem.
"The Web is attracting people who are better able to communicate with their employers, and families are looking for people who are more economically and educationally like themselves," said Kathleen Webb of Home/Work Solutions in Sterling, Va. Home/Work Solutions runs three Web nanny sites; one site carries classified listings for families and nannies who want to avoid agency fees, which range from $800 to $3,000 per placement (www.4nannies.com).
But the heads of Web-based agencies concede that their focus on the Internet might make them miss out on some qualified candidates.
"You can be an outstanding caregiver and not have any of the attributes needed to get on the Internet," Ms. Webb said. "Think of 'The Brady Bunch.' Do you think Alice was on the Net?"
And Ms. Williams said, "You don't need a Ph.D. to give a hug."

HEADLINE: For Whom the Sell Tolls? It Tolls For Thee

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
PAPA'S got a brand new bag.
On Oct. 15, Ernest Hemingway will become a home furnishings brand. The Ernest Hemingway Collection -- 96 pieces of living, dining and bedroom furniture and accessories -- will be introduced at the International Home Furnishings Market in High Point, N.C., the wholesale furniture exposition. 
 Matthew J. Bruccoli, a Hemingway scholar, isn't surprised. "Hemingway was the most astute self-publicist that America has ever known," he said. "His brand name has outlived him by 37 years. People who have never read a book recognize him. "
"Branding" -- attaching a name or trademark to a product to give it an aura of value and a sales hook -- is a familiar strategy in fashion, luxury goods and entertainment. But it is about to hit consumers where they sit. And the pitch has an odd new roll call, with famous names from the four corners of the pop cultural map, Coca-Cola to Greta Garbo.
Bob Mackie, the Hollywood costume designer, will be at High Point, too, with his own spin, as will the Central Park Conservancy and the Professional Golfers' Association. Mr. Mackie will bring to seating the glamour he brought to Barbie. Central Park hopes to hit pay dirt, initially with rugs from a "casual age of innocence." For the PGA Tour, "styling which we hope will be popular with 26.5 million golfers" could be straight fairway or pure sand pit.
The Cole Porter Memories collection -- including $1,900 copies of zebra-cloth chairs from Porter's Paris apartment and a $142,000 replica of the Steinway piano he played at the Waldorf-Astoria -- is being introduced today by the J. Peterman Company at the opening of its Grand Central Terminal store.
Source Perrier furnishings arrived at Pierre Deux stores in August. The company has restocked twice.
With a strong economy producing a record $59 billion in sales in the year ended in July for the furniture industry, a gold rush of unlikely licensing agreements is now under way. Ralph Lauren, the Moses of cross-merchandising, was just the beginning. He moved into furnishings 15 years ago. Retail sales are now $700 million annually. Next year could be the year when the way furniture is marketed changes forever.
For spring, expect the Faith Popcorn Cocooning collection. Ms. Popcorn, the trend forecaster, is negotiating with Barcalounger on the initial product: a recliner for women that will include features for nursing mothers and aromatherapy.
For fall 1999, meet the Beatles. The Yellow Submarine, a franchise being launched next year by the three surviving band members, will include inflatable children's furniture. ("We all live . . . ") "The Beatles said fine," said Del Furano, the president of Sony Signature, the Beatles' merchandising representative. "I wouldn't rule out lamps and sofas. We encouraged them in home furnishings -- it's an exploding category. Everyone's nesting, and they want images from their past."
Home furnishings, humble stay-at-homes, are one of the last, wide frontiers for the hard celebrity sell.
"It's a big, uncharted territory for branding," said Juliet Schor, a Harvard economist and the author of "The Overspent American: Upscaling, Downshifting and the New Consumer" (Basic Books, 1998). "Home furnishings don't yet have the level of brand identification that so many industries do, like cars and soft drinks."
Licensed branded products, including apparel, cosmetics and toys account for $80 billion annually in retail sales in the United States, according to the Licensing Industry Manufacturers Association. Home furnishings now represent $1 billion of that. "It's one of the hottest segments of licensing," said Charles Riotto, the executive director.
Working with living celebrities, the estates of deceased celebrities (or "living legends," as licensing agents prefer to call them) and big trademarks like Coca-Cola, which introduced its bedding at a trade show this month, the furnishings industry is banking on the hope that branding will help sales to its core customers. Baby boomers, notorious for refusing to grow old, will be encouraged to buy middle-aged merchandise like furniture by identifying it with the eternal youth of popular culture.
"We don't have many heroes today, as the millennium approaches," said Marla A. Metzner, president of Fashion Licensing of America. She created the Ernest Hemingway brand with Hemingway's three sons, Jack, Gregory and Patrick. "We're going back to the great icons of the century, as heroic brands." Ms. Metzner also represents F. Scott Fitzgerald's grandchildren, who have asked for a Fitzgerald brand.
"I see a line that would be a mix -- from Art Deco to Ivy League," she said. " 'The Great Gatsby' is America's favorite novel -- and there's going to be a made-for-television movie next year."
Marilyn Monroe, Amelia Earhart and Greta Garbo -- an early cocooner -- are under serious review, too. "Symbols like brands have become a part of reality, a halo," said Dr. Richard Shweder, a cultural anthropologist at the University of Chicago. "In India, where I work, people believe water from the Ganges has a potent positive power."
Does star power really give furniture sales a boost? The Arnold Palmer furniture collection, introduced in 1996, is doing well. So is Eddie Bauer's. Alexander Julian, the fashion designer, is a hit, with $70 million to $90 million in wholesale business.
But Bill Blass's stripped-down interpretations of his own antiques have been labeled lemons by the industry. And Norman Rockwell painted himself out of the picture with licensed designs that didn't sell.
"The failure rate's pretty high," said Warren Shoulberg, editor of Home Textiles Today, an industry publication. "For every successful Ralph Lauren program, there are two or three who fall flat on their faces." The losers' circle is more crowded than the winners' circle.
Cher, the actress and singer, lost her tattooed skin four years ago with "Sanctuary," a direct-mail catalogue that included Gothic-style home furnishings.
"I was ahead of my time," she said of the self-financed effort, which was brought down, she said, by mismanagement and order-fulfillment problems. The collection will be reintroduced on the Internet in November at www.cher.com. But Cher has no illusions about the allure of a name in the furniture business. "I don't think that has much to do with furniture,"' she said. "People look at something that's going to come into their home and it either touches them or it doesn't."
Her friend and colleague Bob Mackie agreed. "I'm not going to pretend I'm this closet furniture designer," he said. Sketches of the Louis XV-style furniture for his collection were presented by the manufacturer, American Drew, a division of the Ladd Furniture Company. A five-piece bedroom suite will sell for a suggested $5,000 to $6,000 when it arrives in stores next spring.
"I hope people will be buying the collection for the furniture," Mr. Mackie said. "Buying it because somebody's name is attached -- that's a bad idea."
With the success of "life style" home furnishing retailers like Pottery Barn and Crate and Barrel, celebrity life-style retailing may not be an awkward reach; it is familiar ground to an adult population used to cultural souvenirs like T-shirts and baseball caps. Maureen Horn, director of home furnishings for Walt Disney Consumer Products, will be at High Point this month, shopping for licensees for a Disney home collection. "Guests staying at the theme hotels want to be able to buy the sofas and tables, so they can couple their memories with the furniture around them at home," she said.
How dear are your memories? And at what price fame, for furnishings manufacturers?
The typical royalty rate is 1 to 5 percent, depending on the power of your pull. "Living legends" like Marilyn Monroe can go as high as 15 percent.
Does the consumer get something original? More or less. Most celebrity collections are much like the rest of the companies' furniture, often at the higher end. The actual cost of developing a medium-size celebrity collection like Mr. Mackie's is largely the same as it would be for a group of unbranded furniture, which is generally $200,000 to $400,000. The "brand name" -- living, dead or incorporated -- has a veto on designs presented by the company, and a voice to suggest or change. It is rarely exercised.
"PGA Tour had a consultant who looked at our ideas," said Shelby Pulino-Pigot, the vice president of merchandising at Vanguard Furniture and a designer of the PGA Tour collection. "They never changed a thing."
What is one getting, then, at the end of the day, as one settles into one's identity?
"Confidence and passion, and a romance mixed with life and death," Ms. Metzner, the licensing agent for Hemingway Ltd., said of the new brand that will have its premiere at High Point. Thomasville Furniture Industries, the manufacturer, is introducing four theme collections: Kenya, Key West, Ketchum and Havana. There is no farewell to armoires: two are being offered. Sturdy but not unstable.
Thomasville conducted a focus group to gauge the market for the brand.
"Negativity came up from about 5 percent," said James Adams, senior vice president for sales and marketing. "He married four times -- this is Hemingway. He was a handsome guy. But there's an edge to this that kind of blows the bad stuff away.
"No one ever asked about what the furniture looked like. That's a great collection."
Brian Carroll, an editor at Furniture Today, said: "The industry has been chastened. No matter whose name you have, you're going to have to pay careful attention to the product. If the product's not exquisite, it's going to fail."
In other words, the sun also sets.

HEADLINE: Pace of U.S. Consumer Borrowing Slows

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a slower pace in August, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Consumer borrowing rose $4.6 billion for the month, to $1.27 trillion, after rising a revised $5.5 billion in July. Previously, the Fed said July borrowing increased $5.3 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $4.7 billion. 
 Economists watch the Fed's consumer credit statistics because it helps them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity. Consumer credit growth has been more subdued than just a few years ago, reflecting an abundance of jobs, low interest rates and low inflation.
In July, consumer credit increased a revised $5.5 billion, previously reported as an increase of $5.3 billion, according to the Federal Reserve's statistics.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $2.2 billion in August, erasing a July decline of the same amount. Auto loans rose $3.9 billion after increasing $2.2 billion in July. Other types of installment loans decreased $1.4 billion after rising $6.5 billion.
The pace of consumer credit was rising at a 4.4 percent annual rate in August. That was down from the pace of borrowing of 5.2 percent in July.

HEADLINE: College Tuition Rises 4%, Outpacing Inflation

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
The cost of a college education rose by about 4 percent this year, two and a half times the current rate of inflation, 1.6 percent, maintaining a pattern of the last few years.
"The cost of attending college presents a steadily rising challenge to many Americans, particularly the most financially disadvantaged," said Donald M. Stewart, president of the College Board, a national nonprofit association, which released its annual survey of college fees. 
 But Mr. Stewart said disproportionate attention to the small number of elite colleges in the $30,000-a-year range obscured the fact that most students at four-year colleges and universities paid less than $4,000 a year for tuition and fees.
The new data show that this year at four-year private institutions students are paying an average of $14,508, up 5 percent, while those at four-year public institutions are paying an average of $3,243, a 4 percent increase. At two-year private institutions, prices rose 4 percent, to $7,333 and 4 percent at two-year public institutions, to $1,633 on average.
College administrators made much of the fact that after double-digit increases for tuition in the 1980's and early 1990's, this was the fourth year in a row with an increase of 4 percent to 5 percent.
But Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, said he was amazed that the price of college continued to outstrip inflation.
"I'm surprised by this, especially among the more modest institutions, given the evidence that people in their 20's find it so much easier to find jobs," Mr. Burtless said. "You'd have thought that with some people deciding not to go to college that would increase pressure on colleges to reduce costs."
Lawrence Gladieux, executive director for policy analysis at the College Board, said he was "pretty sure a couple years ago that consumer pressure would pull the cost of private colleges down."
"But it hasn't," Mr. Gladieux said. "The market for higher education is so robust. People know that the best life chances and jobs come through college education."
He and others pointed out that children of the baby boom generation were coming of college age and that college applications were up.
George Rupp, president of Columbia University, said one of the biggest costs for him and other administrators was updating dormitories and dining halls to keep up with the demands of students and their parents for standards that increasingly seek to match those of hotels and restaurants.
The College Board data show costs for room and board to have increased 3 percent to 5 percent this year. Slightly more than one-quarter of full-time four-year undergraduate students live on campus.
"It was nice to go for 100 years at a stretch without having to change the infrastructure," L. Jay Oliva, president of New York University, said of the conditions offered for generations by many universities.
David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, said colleges and universities were looking at ways to reduce fees further but were worried about affecting quality by increasing student-faculty ratios and reducing laboratory use.
Among the steps these institutions are using or considering, Mr. Warren said, is hiring contractors for dining services, grounds maintenance and bookstores. While this approach can be cost-effective, the resulting job loss disrupts the sense of community that many colleges consider vital.
Peter McPherson, president of Michigan State University in East Lansing, said fees there were up 2.3 percent, the fifth year that his institution has kept its increases at or near the rate of inflation.
This achievement has been possible partly through state aid that has surpassed the inflation rate but also, Mr. McPherson said, because of changes like selling the bookstore to an outside company -- the store used to lose $500,000 a year but now earns that amount -- and improving its campus hotel and convention center to attract more business.
The College Board survey shows significant regional differences in private college costs, with the highest average, $19,211, in New England and the lowest, at $10,701, in the Southwest. These differences were largely matters of the cost of heating and the age of the institutions.
Financial aid to students is now at a record $60 billion, a 6 percent increase over the previous year after adjusting for inflation, but most of the increase is in the form of loans rather than grants and most of the increased borrowing is unsubsidized. Loans now represent 60 percent of aid, compared with just over 40 percent in 1980-81.
President Clinton yesterday signed into law a rate cut for student loans, bringing it to 7.46 percent, down from more than 8 percent last year and its lowest level in 17 years. Under the new law, a typical student borrower at a four-year college, graduating with $13,000 in debt, would save about $700 over a 10-year repayment period.

HEADLINE: Wrangling Over I.M.F. Bill at Fever Pitch

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Alarmed that their foot-dragging could drive international financial markets into still deeper turmoil, the Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans said they were working frantically today to agree on legislation to provide $18 billion in new funding to the International Monetary Fund.
While both sides insisted that a deal was still not a sure thing, White House officials and Congressional leaders agreed on the urgency of additional funds for the I.M.F. as it attempts to avert a global financial meltdown. 
 The most important remaining question, they said, is what sort of restrictions -- if any -- should be put on future lending by the fund, which has been harshly criticized by both Republicans and Democrats for mismanaging the global economic crisis.
The issue of I.M.F. funds is central to negotiations intended to avert a shutdown of the Federal Government this weekend, when funding for most of the Government is scheduled to run out.
"We still have some distance to go but I think we're making some progress," said Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, when asked about the negotiations over the I.M.F. funds. "I think there remain some stumbling blocks."
After meeting today with White House budget officials, Representative Bob Livingston, the Louisiana Republican who is the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said that "the tough drafting is over" on compromise legislation to provide the additional money to the I.M.F.
But the top Congressional Democrat in the negotiations, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, warned that the negotiations with the White House could still break down and that "we're a long way from signing anything."
Earlier this week, President Clinton criticized Congress for delaying approval of the new funds to the I.M.F., saying that failure to provide the money was like "refusing to supply the fire department with water while the fire is burning," given the precarious state of the world economy.
The Senate has already approved the full $18 billion line of credit for the I.M.F. that was requested by the Clinton Administration to replenish reserve accounts that were emptied as the Fund attempted to bail out the economies of Russia and Southeast Asia.
The House, though, has approved only $3.4 billion of the requested funding. House Republican leaders, facing pressure from conservative members of their party who wonder whether the international economic crisis is proof that the Fund does more harm than good, say they will approve the rest of the money only if strict new conditions are imposed on future loans by the I.M.F.
The Republicans have demanded less secrecy in I.M.F.lending decisions, an end to below-market loans to foreign governments and shorter-repayment terms, with perhaps a one-year maximum.
"The I.M.F. has the Midas touch in reverse -- virtually every country it tried to help has become worse off from the experience," said Representative Richard Armey of Texas, the House Majority Leader, who led efforts earlier this year to block the full $18 billion in funding. "Full funding of an unreformed I.M.F. would be recklessly irresponsible."
The White House has resisted the so-called reform measures, saying it is improper for the United States to attempt to dictate policy to a multinational agency like the I.M.F.
White House and Congressional officials said that under a likely compromise, the I.M.F. would face some restrictions on its lending, with the Treasury Department required to certify progress by the fund in implementing a variety of loan reforms. But they said the conditions would not be nearly as onerous as those initially demanded by House Republicans.
Congressional officials say the House leadership has shown a new willingness to resolve the I.M.F issue -- and to end a variety of other funding disputes with the White House -- in hopes of preventing a Government shutdown this weekend that might distract from the impeachment investigation of President Clinton.
Other nations that lend money to the I.M.F. have warned that if the United States failed to provide the full $18 billion, they might well reduce their own contributions, which could leave the fund short of the $90 billion that it says it needs to deal with economic crises sweeping across the developing world.

HEADLINE: Global Computer Chip Sales Rose 1.5% in August

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Global sales of computer chips rose 1.5 percent in August in the first month-to-month increase this year, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.
The rise in global sales came despite a slump in Japan, where single-month revenues were 30 percent below August 1997 levels, according to the trade group's global sales report. 
 Total sales rose $147 million, to $9.81 billion, from $9.66 billion in July. The rise was the first month-to-month gain since November, a spokesman for the trade group said.
"Given all of the volatility in the global markets, these numbers are a positive sign for the semiconductor industry," said George Scalise, the semiconductor association president. "We are cautiously optimistic about the industry's prospects for additional gains in the fourth quarter, because it's traditionally the most active chip quarter of the year."
The report showed modest month-to-month gains of 3.4 percent in the Americas, seventh-tenths of 1 percent in Europe and 3.1 percent in Asia-Pacific markets.
On a year-to-year comparison, global sales for August were 15.7 percent lower than the $11.63 billion recorded in August 1997. Sales in Asia-Pacific, which were severely hurt by the region's economic crises, showed a 12.6 percent decline from a year earlier, while sales in the Americas fell 14.3 percent.
Sales in Europe, which have exhibited strength throughout 1998, were only 2 percent below August 1997 sales.

HEADLINE: Mortgages Are Much in Demand

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Applications for United States mortgages jumped last week to an all-time high, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today. Applications to refinance mortgages also surged to a record, as mortgage rates continued to decline.
The association's mortgage applications index increased 15.9 percent, to 736.6, in the week that ended last Friday, from 635.5 the previous week. The group's refinancing index surged 21.3 percent last week, to 3,253.1, from 2,682.7 the previous week. Those are the highest levels for both the overall and refinancing indexes since the association began its survey Jan. 5, 1990. 
 The purchase index, which gauges demand for new houses, increased 7.2 percent, to 304.0 -- just below the all-time high set in late January.
The association's report showed the average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage with a 20 percent down payment dropped 15 basis points, to 6.36 percent.

HEADLINE: Raytheon Widens Layoffs; Lower EarningsForeseen

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Continuing to struggle in its construction operation and in its attempts to build a lean, integrated military electronics business, the Raytheon Company said yesterday that it would expand layoffs and would not meet Wall Street's expectations for third-quarter earnings.
The company said earlier this year that it would shed about 8,700 jobs by the end of 1999. Yesterday, the company raised that figure to about 14,000 jobs, or roughly 16 percent of its work force. 
 Raytheon spent almost $13 billion last year to acquire the military units of Hughes Electronics and Texas Instruments, and the company has been trying to squeeze costs from the combined operation ever since.
As the jobs disappear, Raytheon, the No. 3 military contractor, intends to close operations in Texas, Washington, South Carolina, Massachusetts and California.
Raytheon also said that its beleaguered engineering and construction business, which some analysts have urged the company to sell, had dragged down earnings for the third quarter. Analysts had predicted that the company would earn 90 cents a share, but in a statement Raytheon said its earnings would be "slightly below" that figure.
In the statement, the company also said the weakness in the construction operation would lead it to take an after-tax charge of $284 million, or 83 cents a share.
"The good news is they are facing the problems square on and they are going to get rid of them," said Howard A. Rubel, who follows Raytheon for Goldman, Sachs.
Referring to scheduled meetings today between analysts and Raytheon's top management, he added, "The bad news is the earnings are a little bit light and the valuation is probably based on earnings, so the run-up in the shares on expectations of some very good strategic direction tomorrow will probably be over for a short while."
Yesterday's announcement was a coming out of sorts for Daniel P. Burnham, Raytheon's president and chief operating officer. Mr. Burnham joined the company 100 days ago after serving as vice chairman of Allied Signal Inc. His conference call yesterday with reporters was his first since joining Raytheon. He is to take over as chief executive in December from Dennis J. Picard.

HEADLINE: Meeting of World Finance Leaders Ends, With No Grand Strategy but Many Ideas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The world's finance ministers and central bankers ended five days of debate today with nothing approaching a strategy to lift the global markets out of their downward spiral, but a with a plethora of new ideas that some officials insisted would ultimately bear fruit.
All week the mood was so pessimistic that one European finance minister left Washington insisting, "I've had more fun at funerals." 
 At times the officials politely sparred with President Clinton and Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. They argued over which European countries should cut interest rates and how much, and whether too much austerity imposed by the West would lead to the breakup of Russia or more bloodshed in Indonesia.
But they agreed repeatedly and publicly that the chief villain in this drama is Japan, with a supporting cast of avaricious hedge fund managers and currency speculators.
Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda, the Thai Finance Minister, said "not much" had been accomplished. He was treated as something of a cult hero because his country's economy has hit bottom and now seems to be crawling back. "I'm afraid the markets will be disappointed," he said
Finance Minister Yannos Papantoniou of Greece agreed with the sentiment, bemoaning "the lack of clear political will to move in any direction."
Those who did not expect much progress nonetheless said they saw glimmers of hope. Weary from days of meetings and nights of glittering receptions that seemed oddly out of sync with the mood of gloom, they talked about Britain's proposal to establish what would amount to a Ministry of the Global Economy -- a standing committee on global financial regulation that would try to get the International Monetary Fund, financial regulators and private industry marching in a single direction.
Many said the world now understood the dangers of financial secrecy, though they were bickering about just what kind of closely held data countries and financial institutions should publish.
A few said President Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, in confidential asides, had given assurances that they would pull $18 billion for the I.M.F. out of Congress, an amount they have requested.
What was missing was a parting message: that in tough times a strategy was emerging. "What this whole thing is about is finding a catalyst that will restore confidence," said John R. H. Bond, the group chairman of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., whose Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank has done business in Asia for a century. "But in this crisis there are so many players, so many different agendas, that turning it around will be very, very difficult."
In an interview today, Mr. Rubin suggested that anyone who thought a meeting of 182 countries would come to hard and fast conclusions did not have realistic expectations. "It was never going to come out with some highly momentous individual proposal," he insisted. "The question was, would it energize international action and a coalescence of views. And I think it unquestionably did."
"There are no magic wands," he added. "These problems developed over many years, and it will take time to work them through."
Mr. Rubin also made the case that there was now a consensus that there needed to be "some private sector involvement" in packages to aid affected countries -- financial code words meaning that big banks, investment houses and hedge funds that help drive countries to the brink ought to pay to clean up the mess.
One of the biggest accomplishments, he said, was that "everyone came out of the G-7 meeting with a shared sense of concern." He was referring to the huge gap between European and American views of the severity of the global downturn.
Some members of the Group of Seven leading industrial countries, France and Germany in particular, argued until last week that Mr. Clinton's repeated references to the "greatest financial challenges in a half-century" were overdramatizing the problem.
A senior European diplomat agreed with Mr. Rubin today, saying his delegation of officials and bankers had "left a lot more depressed than they arrived."
Finance ministers spent part of the week trying to assess President Clinton's political difficulties. Over breakfasts and lunches, ministers would ask reporters to put away their notebooks and then pepper them with questions about whether Mr. Clinton would survive the impeachment inquiry that was gathering steam two miles away.
France proposed giving developing countries and the European Union more authority over the monetary fund, a plan that seemed to be aimed at diminishing America's near domination of the institution.
Mr. Rubin politely dismissed the French plan with the suggestion that it should be studied at length -- the longer the better, he seemed to be saying -- but on Tuesday Mr. Camdessus endorsed it, saying he offered his "full support of the French suggestion."
President Clinton's suggestion on Friday that the I.M.F. change its strategy and develop a way to inoculate fundamentally healthy countries from economic contagion with pre-emptive aid packages led to public and private suggestions that it was time for Washington to come up with more cash before offering ideas on how to spend it. It seemed likely that Mr. Clinton's idea would eventually be accepted, but a top official of the monetary fund, Jack Boorman, said figuring out how it would work would take several months.
Most of the other talk about creating a "new international financial architecture" involved plans that most of those attending said would require years to be enacted.
The first may be new rules on what the financial community calls "transparency" -- requirements that countries divulge far more information about their finances to investors, making it harder to hide evidence of imminent economic disaster. Still, that is no guarantee. Investors ignored a good deal of data about impending trouble in Thailand and South Korea.
The other key suggestions to emerge from these meetings will take even longer. Establishing rules for common financial accounting rules and for renegotiating bad debts when countries and their banks cannot pay may make sense, but they impinge on the sovereignty of individual nations.
Giving broader powers to the I.M.F. to cajole, and sometimes order, countries to lower their budget deficits or raise their taxes also would impinge on their sovereignty.
"This is the basic dilemma of globalization," Mr. Papantoniou said. "Where do you draw the line between intervention and non-intervention?"

HEADLINE: Communists and Workers March to Denounce Yeltsin

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Red banners flapping in the breeze, Communists and trade unionists led a nationwide strike today to protest President Boris N. Yeltsin's rule.
In Moscow, thousands of protesters marched toward the Kremlin during a brilliantly sunny day to demand that Mr. Yeltsin resign. In Vladivostok, the improverished port city on Russia's Pacific Coast, strikers briefly blocked a road. 
 But the marches drew only a small fraction of the ten million demonstrators the Communists had expected. And while thousands of factories and companies conducted short, symbolic work stoppages, life basically went on as usual.
The Moscow subway operated normally and stores were open for business. Traffic was light, as many Moscovites took advantage of the demonstrations to turn the day of national protest into a holiday.
Today's tepid protests were in stark contrast to the anxiety early this week. Overheated rhetoric by Communist Party leaders about "civil war," and the economic shocks of past weeks prompted fears that this could be difficult, even dangerous, week for the Kremlin.
Braced for trouble, Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov promised earlier in the week to pay back wages. Moscow schools were closed today as a security precaution. The American Chamber of Commerce went so far as to warn foreigners to avoid the city center and to disguise their nationality.
The Kremlin also arranged for the marches to take place far from the White House, the spot where tanks loyal to President Yeltsin fired on the rebellious Parliament in 1993, and an emotionally charged symbol for the left.
In fact, today's protest march seemed like more like a casual city stroll than a parade of revolutionaries. The crowd, which tended to be elderly, was made up of trade unionsist, workers and pensioners.
The protesters gathered across the river from the Kremlin and trudged peacefully toward St. Basil's Cathedral, while a loudspeaker played revolutionary songs from the Russian Civil War, like the ballad of Commander Shchors, a legendary Red Army Commander.
Holding a banner that read, "No to Private Property," the vanguard marched by the billboards for Nescafe coffee, Renault cars, Casio watches and Samsung televisions.
At a rally near St. Basil's, there were fiery calls for Mr. Yeltsin to quit, but no real expectation that he would actually do so.
Some of the labor officials tried to turn the protest into a campaign for Moscow's mayor, Yuri Luzhkov, who has sought to postion himself as the leader of a new center-left coalition in the next Presidential election.
But they drew catcalls and boos from the hard-core Communists. And after an hour or so of speech-making, most of the crowd drifted away.
Mr. Yeltsin, for his part, came to the Kremlin early today and monitored the situation, telephoning security officials and militia across the country. Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman said that the President had received "absolutely complete information, both pleasant and unpleasant."
Today's strikes, in fact, were as much a referendum on the Communists' ability to tap the vein of national discontent, as a test of Mr. Yeltsin's dwindling popularity.
The Communists had planned to mobilize some 200,000 demonstrators in Moscow, but the Kremlin insisted that no more than 50,000 turned out. The actual number seemed to be closer to the lower end of the spectrum.
Relatively low turnouts were also reported in other parts of the nation. Police estimated that 70,000 had protested in the Vladivostok region, not the 300,000 the Communists claimed.
Still, the Kremlin insisted that no more than 1 million participated in the marches or strikes, one-tenth the number projected by the Communists. In the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, Aleksandr Lebed, the governor and Presidential hopeful, egged on the protesters, telling them that Mr. Yeltsin was alone and isolated.
There are several reasons why today's protests were only a pale reflection of what had been advertised. Mr. Primakov was able to partially defuse the protest by promising to pay back wages and by naming Communists to top positions in his Cabinet.
Many Russians have also become deeply cynical about politics and no longer have any expectation that the Government will help them.
When Russians were asked in a recent poll who they relied on in a crisis, only 12 per cent said they counted on the state. In contrast, 61 per cent said they rely "only on myself," according to the survey, conducted by the Center for International Sociological Studies.
Further, many Russians who are unhappy with Russia's version of capitalism do not think that the Communist Party, which is led by the uncharismatic Gennady Zuganov, is capable of leading the nation out of its economic crisis.
The national mood seemed to be captured during the recent mayoral election in Vladivostok where a majority voted against all the candidates.
"It's absurd to demonstrate now," said Vladimir Speransky, a sociologist who said he came to watch the demonstration. "It's not clear whom to protest against."
Some of the fringe groups had even less successful than the mainstream Communists in mobilizing their supporters. Viktor Anpilov, the vituperative leader of the far-left faction Working Russia, had expected to mobilize thousands of his supporters. But no more than 300 showed up.
The event also attracted the usual complement of Cossacks, Monarchists and fascist extremists, who, by and large, mingled peacefully with the crowd.
Still, dedicated Communists insisted the demonstrations were an important way for Russians to show that they want Mr. Yeltsin to resign and make way for a new president.
Vasily L. Shishkaryov, a 48-year-old worker at the Zil truck factory, said he joined the Moscow protest but many of his coworkers stayed away. He said he only received 2,500 rubles a month, about $156. Because prices have soared and imports have dried up with the fall of the rouble, he spends almost all of it on food.
Most of his fellow workers, he said, gathered potatoes and vegetables in the countryside to scrape by. Some have virtually given up eating meat since the factory's subsidized sausage store shut down.
Most of his fellow workers were more resigned than angry, and that they would not be ready to take to the streets until things got much worse.
"We got paid in August," he said. "I don't think people will take any real action until they have gone eight months without wages."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Russian Communists and labor unionists lined up during a demonstration near Red Square in Moscow yesterday to protest Boris N. Yeltsin's rule. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Korean Leader, Visiting Japan, Urges Healing of Old Wounds

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 7

 BODY:
President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea arrived in Japan today for a long-awaited state visit and immediately called for a closer partnership and an end to the longstanding tensions between the neighbors.
At a state dinner tonight, Mr. Kim stood up to toast Emperor Akihito, whose father, Hirohito, presided over Japan for much of its brutal occupation of the Korean peninsula until the end of World War II. Avoiding the comments that past South Korean leaders always made on such occasions about the "unfortunate past," Mr. Kim urged a "forward-looking partnership." 
 "The situation surrounding the two countries demands a closer partnership," Mr. Kim said. He later added, "The Korean people and my administration are willing, open-minded and fully prepared to exchange and cooperate with our neighbor."
President Kim has called for reconciliation of every kind since he took office in February, and he has urged for lifting the ban in Korea on Japanese music, comics, movies and television programs. That ban is a measure of the deep hostility to all things Japanese that remains widespread among Koreans, although the black market in Seoul for Japanese tapes suggests a bittersweet fascination with Japanese culture.
Japanese officials, apparently seeing a rare opportunity to heal ties with their neighbor, seem ready to reciprocate by making an unusually humble apology for the colonial past.
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi is expected to offer the most contrite formulation yet for a Japanese apology to Korea. The wording has been under negotiation between the sides for weeks, which means that it comes as much from committees as from the heart, but the result apparently will be a more direct official apology than Japan was ever prepared to make in the past.
Japan and Korea have a long and intertwined history, but Koreans are still haunted by the Japanese annexation and occupation of the Korean Peninsula from 1910 to 1945. Japan built roads, schools and factories, but Koreans were harshly governed and forced to take Japanese names.
Mr. Kim can speak fluent Japanese, but like most Koreans he is reluctant to use it because of the bitter memories that it evokes. Although in the United States in June Mr. Kim addressed Congress in English, which he does not speak as well as Japanese, Mr. Kim is using Korean for all his addresses throughout his Japan trip.
Still, in any language, a president could scarcely have been more gracious than Mr. Kim was in his toast to Emperor Akihito. Mr. Kim warmly thanked Japan for helping during South Korea's economic crisis over the last year, and his only suggestions that Japan face its past were veiled in several layers of silk.
"If our two nations are to succeed in cooperative efforts, we must first respect each other and open our hearts," Mr. Kim urged.
Delicately reminding his hosts that many Koreans believe that Japanese society has not yet acknowledged the truth about its past, Mr. Kim added, "Let us forge a neighborly relationship based on truthfulness and a cooperative spirit."
Emperor Akihito responded with his own expression of regret about the occupation -- a reference carefully crafted by Japanese officials.
"The history of close exchange had a reverse side at one period when Japan brought great suffering on the people of the Korean Peninsula," Emperor Akihito said. "The deep sorrow that I feel over this never leaves my memory."

HEADLINE: A Quick Turnaround;
In Only 4 Months, Greenspan Changes Economic Tune

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Testifying before Congress in June, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called the American economy the best he had ever seen. Less than four months later he is trying to avert a slowdown that some economists now fear could easily turn into a recession.
Speaking before a group of economists here, Mr. Greenspan said today that the outlook for the United States had "weakened measurably" and hinted that the Fed was ready to reduce interest rates further if the financial turmoil that began last year in Asia continued to spread. 
 Mr. Greenspan still marveled at the continuing combination of low inflation, low unemployment and steady American growth, which have sustained what is about to become the nation's longest peacetime expansion. But he fretted about the "somewhat scary psychology" afflicting financial markets and focused on the expectation that consumers would sharply cut back their spending because of the steep drop in stock prices.
And on a day when one of the nation's largest banks forecast that the United States will slip into recession next year, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the confusing and countervailing forces buffeting the economy had left policy makers without a clear idea of how serious a slowdown might be in the offing.
"The economy has remained in reasonable shape, with good growth and low, if not declining, inflation," Mr. Greenspan said in remarks here to the National Association for Business Economics.
"But we are clearly facing a set of forces that should be dampening demand going forward to an unknown extent. We do not know how far it will go or how much it will affect consumer and business spending here at home."
Mr. Greenspan went on to say that this is "a time for monetary policy to be especially alert." Investors took that phrase to mean the Federal Reserve is prepared to follow up its quarter-point cut in the Federal funds target rate last week, to 5.25 percent, with further reductions in coming months.
A few hours after Mr. Greenspan spoke, economists at J. P. Morgan in New York became the first from a major institution to forecast a recession next year.
Morgan said it expects no growth in the first quarter of 1999, a decline in economic output of 2 percent in the second quarter and 1 percent in the third quarter, followed by a return to growth of 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter. Morgan had previously projected growth of about 1 percent over the next year.
"The extra weakness has been triggered by the further deterioration in domestic financial markets in recent weeks," said a report from James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at Morgan. "Although a downturn could still be avoided, it would likely take a prompt reversal of recent financial market deterioration, or particularly quick and aggressive support from policy easing. Neither are anticipated."
While not ready yet to predict an end to the current expansion, which began in March 1991, other economists said they increasingly saw the economy as fragile and vulnerable to further shocks.
"My sense is that recession risks have risen dramatically, that recession is just as likely as a normal slowdown now," said James Glassman, an economist at Chase Securities in New York. "It wouldn't make sense for a Fed chairman to make that case, but if you read between the lines of his speech you can see a heightened concern about developments in the financial markets and tightening credit conditions."
In his remarks today, delivered from notes rather than from his usual rigorously prepared text, Mr. Greenspan often seemed to be pondering how the United States had suddenly been put at risk by the forces that have sent Asia into a deep recession and spread through Russia into much of the rest of the world.
"I've never seen anything like this," Mr. Greenspan said at one point, referring to the flight of investors out of any instrument perceived to have some risk and into the haven of Treasury bonds, which are guaranteed by the United States Government and are always easy to buy and sell.
As usual, Mr. Greenspan presented both the positive and negative elements of the outlook, but analysts said his emphasis was on the risks to the economy, which he has laid out in increasingly explicit terms lately.
Mr. Greenspan said the economy still had "a fairly significant continued momentum." Its performance, he said, is "really still quite an impressive sight," with job growth remaining healthy and inflation pressures muted.
While he acknowledged that it was becoming more difficult and expensive for businesses to borrow money in the debt markets and from banks, Mr. Greenspan said that "we are far short of anything that could resemble a credit crunch in the United States."
So far, Mr. Greenspan said, there is not much evidence of a slowdown in capital investment by business or on spending by consumers.
"In fact, if you look at the physical aspects of the economy as a whole, it is very difficult to find any real variable impact as yet," he said. While job growth slowed last month, unemployment claims remain low, "and anecdotal evidence still indicates that we are confronted with fairly tight labor markets and labor markets which are still putting some pressure, if perhaps not accelerating, on the overall wage structure," he said.
But Mr. Greenspan dwelled at length on the risks to the economy from the latest round of turmoil in the global markets, set off in August when Russia effectively defaulted on its debt, sending investors fleeing not just from other emerging markets, but also from high-yield junk bonds and other investments that suddenly seemed risky.
Mr. Greenspan, who saw one of the underlying causes of the 1990-91 recession as a credit crunch stemming from problems in the banking business, said the problems facing the economy now would be exacerbated if lenders and investors continued to pull back.
"What is occurring is a broad area of uncertainty or fear," he said. "And when human beings are confronted with uncertainty, meaning they do not understand the rules of the terms of particular types of engagement they're having in the real world, they disengage."
The Fed chairman noted that exports were declining, hurting manufacturers and farmers. But he soon returned to the potential psychological shocks from the global turmoil, especially the effects on consumers of the stock market's downturn.
He estimated that $1.5 trillion in wealth had been wiped out since the stock market's peak in July.
"It's got to show up somewhere," Mr. Greenspan said, adding that "we're bound to see the major impact in personal consumption expenditures and housing," two sectors that have driven the economy for the past several years.
William Dudley, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, said Mr. Greenspan's comments were "very much slanted towards the risks to the economy" and that his characterization of the economy as weakening measurably was "a fairly strong statement from a Fed chairman known for being opaque."
That Mr. Greenspan is acutely aware of how quickly the economy can slide into recession is understandable in light of his experience with the 1990-91 recession, when he, like most economists, failed to see at first that the economy had tipped from sluggish growth into economic contraction.
"We have not tilted down," Mr. Greenspan said in September 1990 -- two months after the recession later was shown to have started.
 
Chart: "A Rosy Economy:"
 
To Be . . .
Despite turmoil abroad, shakiness in the stock market, and fears of a credit crunch, many economic indicators remain remarkably positive. With inflation extremely low, real wages are rising at a healthy clip, the job market is strong, and banks are continuing to lend plenty of money to business.

. . . Or Not To Be?
Even though the current economy generally looks good, conditions are starting to deteriorate on a number of fronts. Fear of risk-taking has suddenly made it a lot more expensive for many companies to borrow from the credit market. Export markets for American goods are drying up and managers in other business sectors are becoming increasingly pessimistic.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Price Plunge On Nasdaq Hits 15-Month Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Prices on the Nasdaq stock market declined to their lowest level in 15 months yesterday and have fallen 17.25 percent in just the last eight days of trading. Other market gauges also continued to slump.
Analysts continued to cite nervousness over financial and economic turmoil in many parts of the world and unmistakable evidence that the United States economy is being affected. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified yesterday that he was trying to avert a slowdown that many economists now fear could easily turn into a recession. 
Nasdaq stocks fell 3.2 percent, or 48.28 points, yesterday to 1,462.61, a level not seen since July of last year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 1.41 percent, or 13.91 points, to 970.68, and avoided a new low with a modest late-session rebound. The Dow Jones industrial average moved up in the morning but then faded to close with a loss of 1.29 points at 7,741.69.
European markets were also mostly lower. Stocks fell 2.90 percent on the main German index, 1.24 percent in France and 52/100 of 1 percent in Britain. Brazil's market closed 2.84 percent lower and the Nikkei index of 225 issues jumped 6.17 percent, the biggest gain of the year, while the Hong Kong market rose 2.38 percent.
Amid the general drubbing, however, analysts found some grounds for encouragement. One was that the march to lower interest rates, normally the stock investor's friend, stopped.
"This was one of the few days when stocks went down and the bond market didn't go up," said Christine A. Callies, chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Possibly the capital flight into the U.S. dollar may be winding down."
Investors around the world have been piling into Treasury securities as a haven so yesterday's contrary action may suggest diminished worry about what has been described as the worst financial crisis since World War II.
Analysts also pointed to some further signs that corporate profits in the third quarter may be a bit better than the market has been led to expect. Some multinational companies with sizable overseas earnings posted hefty market gains yesterday, benefiting from the decline in the dollar on currency markets -- 2.3 percent on a trade-weighted basis. McDonald's, for example, rose 2 13/16 , to 61 1/16 , while Procter & Gamble rose 3 1/8, to 77 3/8.
Banks and brokers, on the other hand, were pummeled again. Citicorp dropped 5 3/16 , to 79 13/16 , more than $100 a share less than the peak of $182 set April 6. Merrill Lynch fell 4 3/16 , to 37 3/4, barely one-third the stock's value of 109 1/8 set four days before the Dow hit its record high of 9,337.97 on July 17.
Bankers Trust, which traded as high as 136 7/16 in April, lost another 4 1/8 yesterday to close at 49 3/16 .
The financial sector is exposed to meltdowns overseas and to hedge fund and other borrowers here whose ability to repay is in doubt.
"We have a tug of war going on between those who think international efforts to stem the financial crisis are working and those who think they're not doing enough," said Andy Brooks, head of stock trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. He said it seemed of late that "all the forces at work in the market seem to be causing investors be scared about staying in."
Daniel Knight, portfolio manager at Columbine Asset Management in Colorado Springs, expressed frustration that several of the factors that have traditionally proved good predictors of stock valuations are no longer working.
For example, he said stocks with high price-earnings ratios have "dramatically" outperformed stocks with low p-e's in recent months, reflecting investors' focus on big-name companies with growth stories at the expense of lesser companies with greater intrinsic value.
He said this "overreaction" reflected shaken confidence on the part of investors, who in addition to favoring "feel good" stocks are also paying more attention than in the past to companies with solid dividends.
The Nasdaq's drop was marked by sizable losses in technology, its dominant category. Dell Computer fell 4 3/4, to 50 9/16 ; Microsoft was down 3 1/2, to 94 1/8; Yahoo plunged 10 7/16 , to 114 3/8, and eBay fell 5 5/8, to 30 7/8, after trading as high as 54 1/4 when it first reached the market two weeks ago.
On the New York Stock Exchange, new lows swamped new highs by 535 to 66 while declines outpaced advances by 2,136 to 1,012. Volume was heavy at 977.1 million shares.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Issues Post Loss
 (By Bloomberg News) -- The price of Treasury bonds posted the biggest loss in more than a year as expectations that Japan will bolster its ailing economy sent the dollar tumbling, lessening the appeal of Treasuries as a refuge.
"We might be beginning to see some of the flight to quality money being unwound" as the dollar falls amid signs of progress toward reform in Japan, said Ken Anderson, who helps manage $14.5 billion at Evergreen Asset Management in Purchase, N.Y. "We could be facing a major turn in the market."
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 2 3/32 , to 110 3/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.86 percent, from 4.73 percent on Tuesday.
Investors flocked to Treasury securities in recent months as a haven from turmoil in overseas markets and amid speculation the recession in many Asian economies may spread to the United States.
Yesterday, though, the dollar tumbled by the largest amount in 25 years on expectations Japan's bank rescue plan will become law and the Government will introduce a spending package to bolster the economy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Dollar Drops 8% in Day Against Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar plunged 8.1 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday, its biggest one-day decline in 25 years.
But this spectacular drop in the foreign-exchange market was not touched off by a new belief among investors that Japan was on the verge of turning its troubled economy around, traders and analysts said. If that were the case, the fall of the dollar could be seen as positive, as the end of the recession in Japan would help lead the rest of Asia out of its slump. 
 Instead, the traders and analysts said, the selloff seemed to be set off by a new rush of hedge funds and other investors to get out of bets against the Japanese currency that had been very profitable until two months ago. Much of this selling reflects an unwillingness among hedge funds and other investors to take much risk -- or stick with relatively small losses for long -- in the current global financial crisis, even if they think the dollar will rebound from this plunge.
"In this risk-averse environment, people are just getting out," said Avinash Persaud, the global head of currency research at J. P. Morgan Securities in London. "All the people selling today believe the dollar should go up against the yen but they can't tolerate the loss."
Most of the selloff happened during the trading day in Europe, rather than in Tokyo, where the yen got no boost even though the Government neared approval of a plan to rescue the country's banking system and the stock market rallied. Traders and analysts said much of the selling was reinforced by talk of major selling by two hedge funds -- Long-Term Capital Management L.P., which had to be rescued last month with an infusion of $3.6 billion, and Tiger Management L.L.C., which is run by Julian Robertson, a noted hedge-fund manager.
A spokesman for Long-Term Capital denied that it was selling dollars for yen. A spokesman for Tiger Management would not comment. But it is generally known that Mr. Robertson has made major bets that the yen would continue to weaken and that Japanese bank stocks would fall. And traders said they did see Tiger selling yesterday, as Japanese bank stocks rebounded and the yen rallied.
Traders also said there was a lot of selling after the dollar fell below 130 yen, 128 yen and 127 yen, levels where many derivatives based on a dollar-yen trade forced selling. The recent cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve and the prospect of more are also weighing on the dollar.
In late trading in New York, the dollar cost 120.25 yen, down from 130.85 yen Tuesday, its steepest one-day fall since 1973, according to Bloomberg News. The dollar also fell against other currencies but not nearly as much. Against the German mark, the dollar was down 1 percent, to 1.6138 marks, from 1.63 marks Tuesday.
While the dollar is off 18.3 percent against the yen since Aug. 11 and 11.7 percent against the mark since July 9, it had held up well against other currencies, including the Mexican peso and the Canadian dollar, the currencies of two of America's largest trading partners. But the trade-weighted dollar, which reflects the dollar's value adjusted for the amount of trade with each country, dropped 2.3 percent yesterday, according to the index kept by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, and is down 5.4 percent since Aug. 28.
Analysts said that the aversion to taking even minimal risk in the current financial climate -- in which investors are bringing their money home and banks are less willing to make loans -- could be the catalyst that slows the world economy even more and pushes the American economy into a recession. Even though Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that there was not a credit crunch, analysts and economists are talking about it more every day.
"There is no good reason to change our mind that the risks for the global economy remain on the downside," John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said.
In less turbulent circumstances, the fall of the dollar could be positive for the American economy and countries abroad. A weaker dollar would make American exports cheaper, helping reverse the sharp slide in this sector since the demand from Asia dried up with the economic crisis that erupted 15 months ago.
In addition, a weaker dollar could help make commodities more attractive by lowering their price to consumers in the rest of the world. Because most commodities are priced in dollars, a weaker dollar makes them less expensive in other currencies. Stronger commodity prices could help many of the world's troubled economies, like Russia, that are major exporters of commodities.
But analysts are worried that the current slide of the dollar will have little benefit if the American economy is slowing sharply and, in turn, makes things more difficult for countries abroad. In this circumstance, demand both for American exports and commodities would be likely to fall in a worldwide slowdown, even if a weaker dollar makes the prices cheaper.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The StrongPound Weakens Britain's Export Economy

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, England, Oct. 7

 BODY:
When the Bank of England's secretive Monetary Policy Committee decides on Thursday whether to lower interest rates, its members may not be thinking too much about Hugh Morgan Williams. But he will most certainly be thinking about them.
"If rates don't move down at all, then my view of the Monetary Policy Committee is unprintable, absolutely unprintable," said Mr. Morgan Williams, whose company, Canford Audio P.L.C., makes products ranging from the devices used by the police to record witnesses' testimony to radio station control consoles. 
 In the last year, he said, export earnings by his modest company in this blustery factory park in northeastern England have fallen because the strong British pound makes his products more expensive for foreign buyers. For every German pfennig added to the price of sterling, he said, his earnings in Germany shrink by $100,000 a year.
Such tribulations have created a clamor from British business for lower rates and a weaker pound. Indeed, after Spain cut its benchmark rates half a point, to 3.75 percent, on Tuesday, there was a crescendo of demands for a cut in Britain's 7.5 percent benchmark.
Even the Government -- which last year handed over responsibility for setting rates to the Bank of England -- has acknowledged that the outlook has changed from the heady days earlier this year when Britain seemed to be emulating the United States' coupling of low unemployment and surging growth.
Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington on Tuesday, "Slower world growth makes it inevitable that growth in Britain next year will be more moderate."
Across the land, signs of a slowdown are apparent. The Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary last month put the 4,400 workers in its Dagenham plant on a four-day week. This month, Rover Group, owned by BMW A.G., said it would temporarily halt production of its 200 and 400 models in December, after announcing 1,500 layoffs in July.
The signs are all too familiar here, in a region where bust has followed boom with metronomic predictability -- from the gradual demise of coal mining and shipbuilding, beginning in the 1970's, to the Thatcherite 1980's, which marked Britain's decline as a manufacturing nation.
The pound's rise during the last three years -- caused partly by investors' search for a hedge against the Euro, the single European currency set to be introduced next January -- has compounded other woes in a region that once looked to foreign investment as a panacea. The collapse of the global semiconductor industry contributed directly to the closing in August and September of two big plants by Siemens A.G. and Fujitsu, at a cost of 1,700 jobs.
Almost every week, in a region stretching to Scotland, foreign companies have slashed work forces. National Semiconductor said just this week that it would shed 600 jobs at Greenock in western Scotland.
The job losses have left few options for policy makers, who have relied on foreign investment to create 75,000 jobs since 1986. "Can anyone seriously suggest," said Sir George Russell, chairman of the Northern Development Company, a Government agency, "that this approach should be abandoned and something else put in its place?"
The fruits of those investments are clear. But with 9.1 percent unemployment -- almost twice the figure in the southeast -- and an economy that draws 44 percent of its output from exports, those chill winds are blowing again.
"We are much more vulnerable than most other regions," said Mr. Morgan Williams, who is also regional chairman of the Confederation of British Industries, the main employers' association. And though the pound has fallen 11 percent against the German mark in six months, any sustained fall, he said, "would take 18 to 24 months to have an impact on manufacturing."
In this region alone in recent months, 4,500 manufacturing jobs have been lost -- but 6,000 have been created in businesses like telephone call-centers, which provide fewer full-time jobs and contribute less to local suppliers.
Those companies that survive do so on leaner profits. While Siemens and Fujitsu are departing, the giant Nissan Motor auto factory near here has pledged not only to stay but also to expand. But profits will be down, reflecting the shock of the strong pound on a plant that produces 60 percent of the Nissans marketed in continental Europe.
Mr. Morgan Williams's factory is much smaller, but the pressures are similar. This year, his company expects profits to be up, meaning that his 179 employees have not been threatened with layoffs.
But expectations are lower. "We managed to increase market share in Europe," he said, "by accepting that we are not going to make a lot of money doing it."

HEADLINE: Aid to Russia for Space Station Is Defended

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Members of Congress expressed doubts today about Russia's continued role in the international space station as NASA officials defended plans to help Russia finish important components of the program and reduce future dependence on the cash-strapped nation in completing the orbiting outpost.
Daniel S. Goldin, Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said that plans to pay Russia $660 million over four years for equipment and services connected with the space station were necessary to save the multinational project and that more money would be needed to pay other added costs, most of them caused by Russia's financial problems. 
 Mr. Goldin told the House Science Committee hearing that Russia was a valuable partner in the space station program, but that the agency shared the concerns of many members of Congress that the collapse of the economy in Russia threatened its major contributions to the project.
"Our reliance on Russian capabilities has to be reduced, not by eliminating their involvement but by adding layers of protection," he said.
The bailout money, $60 million of which is needed immediately, is necessary to insure that the Russian-built service module, the crucial third component of the modular space station, is completed and ready for launching in July 1999, three months after an April 1999 date set earlier this year.
Mr. Goldin said the $60 million was not a gift to Russia and would buy the United States added storage space and research time on Russian components of the station.
Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the Wisconsin Republican who heads the Science Committee, criticized NASA for making Russia a partner in the project and letting the troubled nation have such a crucial role. Mr. Sensenbrenner said NASA had assured Congress for years that it was taking steps to insure that Russia would not be in such a critical position in the station project that its problems would endanger completion of the station.
"The White House does not want to admit that its management of our relationship with Russia is fundamentally flawed," Mr. Sensenbrenner said, "The President promised me in writing in 1994 that we would not be dependent on the Russians to build the international space station. And now the Administration wants to stick the American taxpayer with the costs of its mistakes, just to hide the fact that it made them."
Representative Tim Roemer, an Indiana Democrat and a longtime critic of the space station, repeated his call to cancel it. Mr. Roemer noted that a recent NASA audit estimated that each month's delay in the project cost United States taxpayers at least $130 million, and predicted more delays because of Russia's money problems.
Judyth Twigg, an expert in Russian affairs at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond told the hearing that Russia's problems ran deeper than just a lack of money. Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, Russia has not been conducting meaningful research and development in space and its industrial capacity has declined.
Neal F. Lane, the White House science adviser, said after the hearing that Russia was experiencing more financial problems than anyone had anticipated.
"We want to work with them on the problems," Mr. Lane said, adding that the administration was examining requests from NASA for more money in future budgets to cover increased project costs.
Mr. Goldin said partners in the $40 billion space station project, including the European Space Agency, Japan and Canada, agreed last week to stay on schedule for launching the first two parts of the station. Critics have questioned the wisdom of putting the first two elements of the project into orbit this year and then having to wait months for the much-delayed Russian service module.
Russian Space Agency officials announced today that they had started launching preparations for the first element, an unmanned maneuver and storage unit named Zarya. The module, built in Russia but paid for by the United States, is to be launched on Nov. 20 aboard a Russian rocket. It is to be followed on Dec. 3 by the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour carrying the first United States element, a connecting module called Unity.
James Oberg of Houston, an expert on the Russian space program, told the hearing that it would be a mistake to begin launching parts of the space laboratory before reevaluating options for the program, including one that excludes Russia.
