HEADLINE: For a Judge, Yankee Call Just Another In a Blizzard

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
The Mayor was deriding him as a Democratic Party hack. His admirers were praising his judicial acumen and savoring the familiar populist tone in his latest decision.
For Justice Douglas E. McKeon of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, who ruled against the Mayor yesterday and said a referendum should be held in November on the fate of Yankee Stadium, it was another day at the center of a whirlwind, his telephone alive with calls from reporters, judges and other public officials. 
 For the last eight years, Justice McKeon has heard nearly every high-profile civil case in the borough, including most recently the lawsuits over the death of Anthony Baez during a struggle with a police officer, Francis X. Livoti, in 1994.
But the judge, who came up in the Bronx Democratic organization during the reign of Stanley Friedman, is likely to find himself in the spotlight far less often from now on. He has been transferred to a less-prestigious assignment hearing routine civil trials in the wake of a state judicial panel's decision last month to censure him for misconduct.
The panel, the Commission on Judicial Conduct, rebuked Justice McKeon for discussing a pending case with a reporter for The New York Times, appearing on television to comment on the civil case against O.J. Simpson and asking the city's Law Department to speed its hiring of a woman who once worked for him. The panel said Justice McKeon also lobbied on behalf of the woman, with whom he had a personal relationship, when the Law Department sought to dismiss her several months later.
The rebuke, and the reassignment by Chief Administrative Judge Jonathan Lippman, swiftly put an end to widespread speculation that Justice McKeon, 50, would succeed Burton B. Roberts, 76, the longtime Administrative Judge in the Bronx, who is to retire in December.
Now, after years in which he managed the largest caseload of any jurist in the state, at times juggling pretrial motions and trial work in up to 8,000 lawsuits at once, Justice McKeon will hear only trials, one at a time. "From 8,000 cases down to one," he said ruefully, during an interview in his chambers yesterday.
Moments later, Justice McKeon was informed that Mayor Giuliani had denounced his decision in the Yankee Stadium case, calling it the work of "a judge who is the product of the Democratic machine" and saying its legal merit was nonexistent.
The judge pointedly declined to defend or discuss his reasoning in the case. He said only that he had indeed been a Democratic regular -- "I'm proud of it," he added -- but that he was elected to his first judgeship after a hard-fought primary, not anointed by the party's leadership.
Justice McKeon devoted a page and a half in his ruling to an essay on Yankee Stadium's place in the hearts of New Yorkers. "The decision to abandon an athletic stadium involves emotional and economic factors," he wrote. "Ebbets Field, the Polo Grounds -- shouldn't the public have the right to say whether Yankee Stadium meets that same fate?"
It was not the first time Justice McKeon sounded like a populist in a black robe. In 1996, when city and state officials sought his help in keeping a Farberware plant on Bruckner Boulevard from shutting down, Justice McKeon, who was born in Woodlawn and lives near Pelham Parkway, made his sympathies clear, saying his priority was to preserve 700 jobs. "There are families with real problems and real concerns who are impacted by this," he said. "I am most interested in trying to restore hope to these people."
Since his censure, however, Justice McKeon's high profile has subjected him to more scrutiny. Hours after Justice McKeon released his decision, the gist of which was reported in The Daily News yesterday, he was called by an official in the Office of Court Administration, inquiring about how the newspaper had learned of his ruling in advance.
Justice McKeon said he had filed the document with the clerk Tuesday afternoon. If someone had leaked it to the newspaper, he said, he was unaware of it. "I didn't," he said, after hanging up the phone.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Iraq Talks Fail to End Stalemate on Arms

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 7

 BODY:
After 10 days of talks, Iraq and the United Nations said today that they had failed to break a two-month impasse that prevented spot searches for weapons of mass destruction.
But both sides said they intended to pursue a search for a peaceful way out that might allow Iraq to have some idea when economic sanctions might be eased and satisfy the Security Council that Baghdad has disbanded its nuclear, biological and chemical weapons systems as well as missiles to deliver them. 
 Senior diplomats here emphasized that Iraq and the United States, as well as other key members of the Security Council, were eager to avoid another confrontation like the one that nearly led the United States to bomb Iraq in February.
"Nobody wants a fight," said a senior Arab diplomat.
"The Iraqis want a way to climb down from their ban on inspections in return for a little gain, as they have done in every confrontation over the past few months," the diplomat said. "And the Americans are in no position to wage an attack on Iraq right now, given the domestic situation in this country."
Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq said, "We are going to weigh the situation in its entirety in Baghdad." He led an unusually large delegation to New York that included the Foreign Minister, several senior diplomats and top scientists in the attempt to lobby for a new approach to the weapons inspection system and ease economic sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990.
A statement issued by Secretary General Kofi Annan's office simply said "both sides agreed that the process of dialogue would continue."
Both sides now seem to put their hopes on a so-called "comprehensive review," a compromise proposed by Mr. Annan. It would examine Iraq's compliance so far with all aspects of the elimination of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons of mass destruction and propose a timetable for easing the sanctions.
A senior United Nations official who insisted on anonymity said the "beauty of a 'comprehensive review' is that everybody can put everything they want in it. It's workable."
A benefit of the review, from Iraq's standpoint, is that if it can prove that it has complied sufficiently, it can expect a schedule for lifting some of the economic sanctions. Those sanctions are crippling the country's economy and impoverishing its 20 million people.
In return, the Security Council would obtain the immediate return of the United Nations Special Commission inspectors banned by Iraq from spot checks since Aug. 5.
In his talk with reporters today after meeting Mr. Annan, Mr. Aziz denied a report in The New York Times today that French tests appear to have found traces of chemicals linked to the nerve gas VX on Iraqi warheads, but are refraining from making the announcement.
Mr. Aziz said the report was politically motivated and "timed to sow confusion and suspicion" as Iraq pursued its quest to lift sanctions.

HEADLINE: Pataki's Economic Adviser Is Subpoenaed in Contract Inquiry

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed Gov. George E. Pataki's senior economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, in their inquiry into the awarding of a $97 million state contract to a Long Island company owned by a major Republican political contributor, officials said yesterday.
The prosecutors are investigating whether the contracting process was influenced by a total of $100,000 that donors linked to the company, Silverite Construction, had given to the New York Republican State Committee in the days just before and after the company received the contract to repair the Queens Midtown Tunnel in May 1997. 
 Mr. Gargano's office declined to comment, but other Pataki aides said that in the past week Mr. Gargano had received the subpoena to testify before a grand jury.
The United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn has declined to discuss the inquiry.
Mr. Gargano was the chief fund-raiser for the Pataki campaign in 1994, after which Mr. Pataki appointed him to oversee the state's economic development agencies.
Since then, Mr. Gargano has said he no longer raises money for the Pataki campaign.
Silverite's owner, Angelo J. Silveri, said in an interview in March that he was a friend of Mr. Gargano and talked to him often. Mr. Silveri said he might have spoken about the tunnel project with Mr. Gargano.
Aides to Mr. Gargano have said there could have been such a discussion, but they said Mr. Gargano had no role in the project, which is supervised by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The authority had originally determined that Silverite and its partner in the venture lacked the experience for the four-year project, one of the largest state contracts in recent years. But Silverite then altered its application and got the contract.
The authority and Mr. Silveri have both said that the donations had nothing to do with the contract. But after The New York Times disclosed the timing of the donations in March, Federal prosecutors began their investigation and the authority undertook an internal investigation.
The prosecutors have already issued subpoenas to officials at the transportation authority, Mr. Silveri and executives of the companies that lost the bidding and contended that the process was biased toward Silverite.
Mr. Silveri has been one of the biggest financial backers of the Pataki campaign and the Republican State Committee. He and donors connected to him have given roughly $335,000 to the Republican State Committee and the Pataki campaign since October 1994, according to campaign finance records.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nikkei Soars After Japan Edges Closer to a Bank Bailout

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The governing party edged closer today to injecting massive amounts of money into the Japanese banking system, and that prospect sent investors rushing into markets with greater hopes of an economic recovery.
The Liberal Democratic Party introduced legislation to enhance the capital base of banks that are sound, but weakly capitalized. The legislation, which would add to bank-organization bills agreed to last week, provides 10 trillion yen, or nearly $80 billion, in taxpayers' money to recapitalize the Japanese banks, with an option to provide more. 
 "We realized we should hurry, though it doesn't mean that we can pass any bill no matter what its content," said Chikara Sakaguchi, deputy head of the New Peace Party, a newly pivotal player in the opposition group. That party and another small one now seem close to pooling their votes with those of the Liberal Democrats to support the measure, insuring passage.
Encouraged by the prospects of the Liberal Democrats' greater influence, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues soared 803.97 points today, or 6.2 percent, to 13,825.61, with the index logging its second-largest single-day gain of the year in a rally that helped push markets higher throughout Asia. At the midday break Thursday, the Nikkei was down 3.32 percent, to 13,366.74.
Just last week, the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly 13 years. Over the weekend, Japan's financial leaders painted a picture of gloom for American and foreign officials in Washington. In one of his most outspoken remarks, Masaru Hayami, the governor of the Bank of Japan, told the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, that Japan's top banks are short of capital and that taxpayers' money would be necessary to strengthen them.
Mr. Hayami was criticized by Japanese bankers, including Satoru Kiishi, head of the nation's banking association, who said that he was "deeply worried" that the remarks could "further erode confidence" in Japan's banking system. But many analysts say that increasing the capital of the banking system is crucial to financial stability and, ultimately, economic recovery.
"First and foremost, the policy priority is to recapitalize the banking system," James P. Fiorillo, an analyst at ING Barings in Tokyo, said. "They can worry about the pure market principle later."
Many analysts, politicians and bankers say that Mr. Hayami's remarks, along with those by the Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, appear to have been cleverly staged to inspire worry among the opposition parties and force them to buckle to the demands of the Liberal Democratic Party.
Analysts also say that even if the remarks by Mr. Hayami were scripted, they may reflect a new sense of urgency among Government and central bank officials. Though the Government has warned about the severity of Japan's recession -- it now forecasts the economy will shrink by 1.8 percent in the fiscal year ending in March -- politicians bickered for months over what to do about it.
But last week, when the Nikkei average plunged below 13,000, banking officials appear to have gotten nervous because of the impact that lower stock prices have on the capital bases of Japanese banks. As of the end of March, the most recent statistics offered by the Bank of Japan, all Japanese banks technically met the capital adequacy requirements set forth by the Bank for International Settlements.
Under Bank for International Settlements guidelines, the falling stock prices did not have an impact on the Japanese banks, which are still suitably capitalized. But that is reassuring only for those who focus on accounting rules that permit the banks to value stock portfolios at cost, and in reality the declining stock market clearly meant that banks had less padding. That seems to be the concern that Mr. Hayami tried to raise in Washington, and it is also of concern to investors.
"The markets were worried about bank failures, about a massive banking crisis that would envelop all the banks and sink the market," said Craig O. Chudler, a strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo.

Greenspan's New Worry
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the outlook for the United States had "weakened measurably" and hinted that the Fed was ready to reduce interest rates further if the financial turmoil that began last year in Asia continued to spread. Mr. Greenspan still marveled at the continuing combination of low inflation, low unemployment and steady American growth, but he fretted about the "somewhat scary psychology" afflicting financial markets and he focused on the expectation that consumers would sharply cut back their spending because of the steep drop in stock prices. A few hours after Mr. Greenspan spoke, economists at J. P. Morgan became the first from a major institution to forecast a recession next year. C1

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Hong Kong's Chief Offers No Economic Initiatives

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Hong Kong's chief executive, in his second annual policy address, offered little to immediately lift the beleaguered domestic economy. The executive, Tung Chee-hwa, covered familiar ground in his address, reiterating that the government remained committed to free-market principles and to maintaining the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the United States currency. 
 Mr. Tung said that the economy, hit by regional financial turmoil and in its first recession in 13 years, will be in a hard situation "well into 1999." The government will thus run a budget deficit significantly higher than the shortfall of 21 billion Hong Kong dollars that was forecast in June, Mr. Tung said.

HEADLINE: Economic Turmoil's Latest Turns Raise the Level of Anxiety in U.S.

 BODY:
The world economic crisis spread a nervousness in America yesterday that played out in odd ways.
The mood was decidedly downbeat in the United States. The International Monetary Fund's annual meeting ended in Washington without agreement from the ministers in attendance on a plan to resolve the crisis. Page A6. And Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's once upbeat chairman, said the likelihood of continued good times in America had "weakened measurably." Page C1. 
 His blunt statement was taken as a hint that the Fed would again lower interest rates, and the Dow Jones industrial average, perhaps in response, recovered from a 100-point fall to finish almost unchanged. But Nasdaq tumbled to 15-month low.
In the spirit of the day, the powerful dollar fell suddenly in value against the yen. That should be good news in America. A cheaper dollar makes American exports less expensive. And selling more goods abroad is a national goal. But many experts, persistent in their pessimism, offered a negative reason for the dollar's fall: they blamed panicky American investors who picked yesterday to sell off millions of dollars invested in hedge funds, worried that another fund might fail, and then convert their redeemed dollars into yen to repay Japanese banks that had loaned them the money.
Japan was strangely optimistic. Its economy is in disastrous, recessionary shape, but Americans awoke yesterday morning to learn that Japanese stock prices had gone straight up -- one of the best days in weeks. Grasping at straws, perhaps, investors in Japan had focused on good news -- the possibility of a big infusion of government money into the nation's cash-short banks. Page C4.
The banks would have money to lend again, which they have not been doing lately, at least not inside Japan. More lending at home should, in theory, revive economic activity. Encouraged by this prospect, people rushed out and bought stocks -- a striking reversal from last week.

HEADLINE: Republicans Agree to New Limits On Consumer Bankruptcy Filings

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
House and Senate Republicans agreed today on a vast overhaul of the bankruptcy system, making it more difficult for consumers to walk away from their debts and handing the banking and credit-card industries a major victory.
The agreement was reached without the consent of Congressional Democrats or the White House, and Administration officials said they would recommend that President Clinton veto the bill because of its treatment of low-income consumers. 
 Under the Republican agreement, only consumers with relatively low incomes could declare bankruptcy under the rules that wipe out many debts. But the agreement would give bankruptcy judges some discretion in determining whether debtors could file under Chapter 7, which wipes out many debts, or under Chapter 13, which requires the repayment of most debts.
Debtors who earn more than the median income -- $17,900 for single people and $51,000 for a family of four -- would be moved into Chapter 13. Also sent into Chapter 13 would be debtors who could repay 25 percent of their unsecured debts, like credit cards, or $5,000 over five years.
The negotiated bill weakens a requirement approved by the Senate that credit card companies disclose on each monthly bill how much consumers will owe and for how long if they make only the minimum payment.
It also drops a Senate provision that sets a $100,000 limit on the value of homes that could be kept by those declaring bankruptcy. This means that people could still move to certain states, like Florida and Texas, buy expensive homes, declare bankruptcy and keep the entire worth of their homes. But the compromise bill requires these people to live in the adopted state for at least two years before they can claim the homestead exemption.
With the perception that low-income Americans -- primarily women and minorities, who are among Mr. Clinton's most reliable political allies -- would be hurt most by the bill, Hillary Rodham Clinton has argued against the House version, toward which the compromise tilts.
Mrs. Clinton's concern is that credit-card companies will have a stronger claim than women and children on debtors -- usually ex-husbands -- who file for bankruptcy but who owe child support and alimony.
Republicans say alimony and child support will be the priorities in any bankruptcy liquidation under this agreement, but Democrats say the language is far from that clear.
The industry supported the bill passed by the House, which was guided by a concern that filing for bankruptcy had become too easy and that thousands of Americans were abusing the system. The Senate bill started from the premise that easily available credit was also responsible for the increase in bankruptcies and that the credit-card industry needed to be held accountable along with consumers.
The House and Senate approved vastly different bills, and negotiators have been scrambling to iron out the differences before Congress recesses this weekend. The Republican agreement was sent to the House for a vote, which could come as early as Thursday.
Republicans said today that they were happy with the compromise and that it was fair, but Democrats were furious, none more so than Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois.
Mr. Durbin had joined Republicans in seeking an overhaul of the bankruptcy system, and his name gave the process bipartisan credibility. But he said he was shut out of the final negotiations.
The Senate bill, which had passed 97 to 1, "has been devastated in a closed-door Republican conference," Mr. Durbin said.
"Republican conferees stripped out every significant consumer protection in the Senate bill," he said. "The President will not sign this bill in its present form."
Today's agreement represents a huge success for banks, credit-card companies and retailers. The lending industry spent more than $40 million to lobby for the changes, which could help it recoup an estimated $4 billion a year.
Bankruptcy filings reached a record 1.42 million over the 12 months ending on June 30, continuing a three-year trend that has persisted despite the robust economy. More than one million of these bankruptcies were filed under Chapter 7, which erases all debt except taxes, mortgages, student loans, child support, alimony and, in some cases, loans on a car needed to get to work.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who led the negotiations for the Senate, said the compromise protected honest consumers from those who abused the bankruptcy rules.
"Consumers across the country who work hard and pay their own way should not be forced to subsidize the abusive spending practices of those who exploit the Federal bankruptcy code for personal gain or convenience," Mr. Grassley said.
William P. Binzel, a lobbyist for MasterCard International, said complaints of a bill that let the industry off the hook were unfounded.
 "If a lender makes credit available to someone who can't afford to repay it, the lender loses the principal and interest," Mr. Binzel said. "The bill addresses the fundamental flaw in the law that allows a debtor who can repay a portion of his debts to use the system to walk away from those debts."

HEADLINE: Citizen Line Item Veto?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "More Military Waste" (letter, Oct. 4): Military spending is so far out of control that it harms the United States economy. Last year more than 40 percent of the Federal income taxes that New Yorkers paid went to the military, compared with 5.7 percent for social services, 2.5 percent for education, 2.9 percent for nutrition and 0.9 percent for the environment. 
 Total military spending removes tremendous monetary resources from local economies, increasing job downsizing and exacerbating poverty.
 
ROBERT B. LEPLEY
Garden City, N.Y., Oct. 4, 1998
 
The writer is executive director, Long Island Alliance for Peaceful Alternatives.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Needs Reform, Not Money;
The Poor Suffer

 BODY:

To the Editor:
An Oct. 5 editorial on the International Monetary Fund overlooked an important aspect of the institution: the poor people in developing countries shortchanged by its policies. Congress owes the world something more than the $18 million for the monetary fund: the demand that its policies do not result in countries' slashing their health and education budgets. 
 In addition to disrupting health and education programs, monetary fund policies have encouraged some countries to reduce or eliminate minimum-wage levels, and have also resulted in developing countries' shifting more of their agriculture to cash crops for export rather than food crops for domestic consumption.
The I.M.F. has plenty of resources to weather its crises. We have a rare opportunity to leverage meaningful reform that will help the poor. But that opportunity will be lost if we give the I.M.F. the money without demanding change.
 
STEPHEN VALK
Atlanta, Oct. 6, 1998

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Cityscape Chapter 11 Plan

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Cityscape Financial Corporation and its Cityscape Corporation unit filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.
Cityscape Financial, which is based in Elmsford, N.Y., in Westchester County, said it expected confirmation of its reorganization plan by United States Bankruptcy court, although the plan was rejected by holders of its Series B preferred shares. Other holders of shares and debt approved the reorganization, the company said. 
 Cityscape is a sub-prime mortgage lender, making mortgage loans to individuals with spotty credit histories, usually at high interest rates. The filing comes after the company sold its profitable British lending unit and a loan-servicing business in the United States.
The company has put itself up for sale but has yet to find a buyer.
Cityscape Financial and its unit will continue to operate. The company plans to ask the court to set a hearing for confirmation of the reorganization plan, expected to take place in one or two months.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: JON JERDE;
The Global Village Goes Pop Baroque

BYLINE: By FRANCES ANDERTON

 BODY:
"JON JERDE," Steve Wynn declared grandly, "is the Bernini of our time." He continued: "These are the cathedrals of our time. This is the future of architecture."
The "cathedrals" touted by Mr. Wynn -- a pontiff of the material world -- are Disneyland, the Mall of America and his own casino extravaganza, Bellagio, due to open next week in Las Vegas, Nev. All three are landmarks of the trend for fusing architecture, commerce and fantasy, of which Mr. Jerde is a pioneer. Mr. Jerde, a self-described "experiential architect" in Los Angeles, designed the Mall of America and (with Mr. Wynn's in-house team, Atlandia Design) Bellagio. 
 Bernini, the master of Roman Baroque, might enjoy Mr. Jerde's modern American variant, employing exaggerated color, spatial tricks and theatricality. Bellagio is one of the few casinos in Las Vegas that actually looks good in daylight. Solid, three-dimensional, dripping with landscaped patios and balustraded terraces, it is as charming and persuasive an Italian idyll as is possible in the shadow of a looming 36-story, 3,000-room hotel whose gargantuan presence no amount of scale-reducing applied moldings and friezes can diminish.
At Bellagio, Mr. Wynn wanted elegance and romance. Drawing on Lake Como in Italy and its shore-side town of Bellagio for inspiration, Mr. Jerde's firm, the Jerde Partnership International, planned and designed a painterly composition of Italianate buildings surrounding an artificial lake, so richly detailed they could actually pass for authentic. (Atlandia designed the interiors.)
With Bellagio, Mr. Wynn moves his casinos another notch toward the bourgeois respectability that began with family-friendly glitz at Treasure Island and the Mirage and that is now culminating in fine art and architecture at the polite, softly pretty, neon-free new hotel. Yet, Mr. Jerde is surprisingly low-key about the project, despite the fact that his firm spent four years on it.
At his home in Los Angeles, a rustic dwelling in the Santa Monica Mountains, he explained that Bellagio was "Steve's vision." It is small fry compared to his Big Idea: the remaking of cities with entertainment as the core.
Early on, Mr. Jerde, now 58, recognized that "the consumption addiction is what will bring people out and together," and he has made a career of feeding it with his controversial brand of pop public space.
People who love the messy urbanism of traditional cities may feel profound discomfort at this apparent repackaging of the urban realm.
"Architecture as packaging or playacting, as disengagement from reality, is a notion whose time, alas, seems to have come," Ada Louise Huxtable mourned in her 1997 book, "The Unreal America: Architecture and Illusion" (New Press).
In 1985, Mr. Jerde pushed his career forward with Horton Plaza in San Diego, which wed the conventional suburban mall -- department stores, shops and movie houses -- with the specialty shops, food courts and party ambiance of the quaint festival centers popularized by the Rouse marketplaces in the 1970's. This six-block profusion of cheap and cheerful buildings and public spaces helped turn around the fortunes of downtown San Diego. It also helped to spawn the now ubiquitous "urban entertainment center," promoted by many developers and city planners as the panacea for declining downtowns, from Times Square to Tokyo.
In 1993, Mr. Jerde (pronounced JER-dee) and a team of Los Angeles designers and architects created Citywalk, an upbeat distillation of Los Angeles's architectural and graphic landmarks into an artificial street at the Universal City studios and theme park. Herbert Muschamp, The New York Times's architecture critic, wrote at its opening soon after the Los Angeles riots that with its "zippy collage of signs and storefronts," Citywalk "is a shiny new wheel in the pop machine that boosts the city's rhythm." Its view "of harmonized diversity is a hokey Hollywood ending," he continued, adding, "Would a sad ending be better?"
Soon after, at the invitation of Mr. Wynn, the Jerde firm designed the "Fremont Street Experience," a transformation of Las Vegas's downtown main street into a covered "destination."
Two years ago, Mr. Jerde completed Canal City, a futuristic mall with hotels, shops and explosive fountains in a canyon of buildings snaking along a newly created canal in a disused industrial area in Fukuoka, Japan.
While conceptually ambitious, these projects are essentially privately owned pedestrian shopping malls. Next stop is real city-making: 24-hour, multi-block, private and public developments comprising shops, entertainment, houses, offices and, in some cases, traffic. The Jerde group has such projects under way in Japan, Taiwan and Warsaw as well as in Kansas City, Mo., and Salt Lake City. "We've got some lulus," Mr. Jerde said, with childlike excitement. "All of these middle American cities need it," he added, referring to his brand of urban renewal, "because they are the ones with the least to do."
MR. JERDE was sitting in the garden of his home, the Stone House, eagerly awaiting the return from school of his son, Oliver, the child of his fourth marriage. The house where he lives with his wife, Janice Ambry, a residential architect, is dark, eccentric, suffused with the odor of wood floors and paneling.
Built over two decades with raw stone quarried from the property, it is part Tyrolean hut, part cave, more somber than Mr. Jerde's trademark festive malls, and less high-tech -- materials are all natural, fireplaces are the only source of heat and there isn't a computer in sight. But in other ways, it reflects his work, with its textured surfaces, decorative furnishings and potpourri of objects -- Buddha's heads, a silk mandala, a Maori mask, intricate carved wood columns from Nepal, an Eames chair -- all cast in high relief by theatrical lighting.
In the garden, behind Mr. Jerde, was a stone fireplace he built -- the "spite wall" he cheerfully calls it -- to separate himself from his third wife, who, on leaving him, took up residence in a house they owned next door. Like the house, the fireplace appears to have emerged from the ground; together they embody Mr. Jerde's paradoxical architectural goal: to imbue commercial, modern environments with a sense of the organic, of having accreted over time.
Both gregarious and a loner, Mr. Jerde considers himself a creature of the globe: "I have never had any particular allegiance to any place, state, town or neighborhood," he said. He is the only child of peripatetic parents, his father a migrant oil-field worker. "Our family was called oil-field trash," he remembers. "We just blew into town and we blew out of town."
On moving to Southern California, he says, he found "a wonderful warmness and sense of belonging amongst anonymous folks" at the Long Beach Pike, an early theme park in Long Beach. He went on to train as an architect, winning a travel scholarship to Europe, where he discovered the Italian hill towns, "an architecture by nobody and everybody at the same time."
To simulate this architecture of anonymous communality, Mr. Jerde works "co-creatively" on projects with multi-disciplinary teams, layering on references to local and global, man-made and natural sources. His projects are not themed, he contends, but rather capture the "essence" of their environments.
Mr. Jerde is a trim man with a ruddy complexion, sandy hair and sharp eyes, who can be an extremely engaging advocate for his mission. But not everyone is sold.
Scott Cantrell, the architectural writer at The Kansas City Star, last year attacked Mr. Jerde's proposal for reinvigorating the Kansas City downtown with streetscapes made of existing facades and what he calls "synchronous" new buildings. "For all the lofty verbiage," Mr. Cantrell wrote, "Mr. Jerde is proposing not real architecture but a collage of facadectomies." He continued, "It's a synthetic jumble, heavy on circa-1900 nostalgia, with an overlay of shopping-mall glitz."
Where critics bemoan the commercialization and privatization of civic space that his work represents, Mr. Jerde argues that "the public sector stopped making public space a long time ago."
His admirers include the Los Angeles architect Craig Hodgetts. "Jon Jerde," Mr. Hodgetts writes in a forthcoming book, "is one of that breed of innovative architects whose contagious vision redefines an era." He adds, "His designs would, quite frankly, be unthinkable in a world without television, modems, global brands."
With movie houses anchoring retail developments, and tricks of movie-making informing his undeniably successful designs, Mr. Jerde has become impossible to ignore. The Pritzker Prize-winning architect Arata Isozaki has said that Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, and Jon Jerde's Canal City in Fukuoka, Mr. Isozaki's birthplace, are the two most important buildings created in the last two years.
Norman Klein, a cultural critic and professor at the California Institute of the Arts, believes that Mr. Jerde's work is significant because it represents "a transition from one notion of urban space to another" -- what he calls the "metropolitan suburb."
Given a disappearing tax base, these kinds of malls may be a necessity to city managers, Mr. Klein said, arguing that these cityscapes are reflections of a latter-day Baroque mercantile civilization, with corporations rather than popes and aristocrats for clients.
With his cinematic environments, Mr. Jerde's creations "provide a kind of camouflage under which large franchise companies can pretend to be local," Mr. Klein said.
So perhaps the Bernini comparison is apt, in another way. Mr. Jerde's work may just express the reality of the global economy, of a shrunken public sector, from which people may want to run. But they cannot hide.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
RAILING, LEWIS IRA

 BODY:
RAILING-Lewis Ira, age 76, of New York City, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, at Newport Hospital, Newport, RI, after a long illness. He was the husband of the late Trudy Kalbfleisch Railing of Wheeling, W.V. Born in Baltimore, on September 23, 1923, he was the son of the late Lewis Ira and Edna Creighton Railing. Mr. Railing lived and worked in NYC most of his career. He graduated in 1940, from Baltimore City College High School and did post-graduate work at Baltimore Polytechnic Institute. He attended the Colorado School of Mines in Golden, CO., until 1944, when he joined the U.S. Corps of Engineers, Third Army, under General George Patton. He was awarded a Battlefield Promotion and discharged with the rank of Major. He received his BS from Colorado School of Mines in Geological Mining Engineering in 1947. He subsequently attended Harvard Business School. He was associated with Ford, Bacon and Davis, Co., for 20 years, as an independent engineering consultant; he spent nine months in Bolivia as a consultant for construction and operation of underground installations. He also acted as a consultant to Guggenheim, Bros, Asbestos Corp, Ltd., South American Gold and Platinum Co. For the last ten years, he was Research Consultant for the investment firm of Ruane, Cunniff, the Sequoia Fund, in NYC. He received a MS degree in Transportation Management from State University of NY in 1965. He most recently was a Doctoral Candidate at Pace University, majoring in management, economics and finance. He leaves a sister, Dorrie R. Richardson, of Newport, RI, and Vero Beach, FL: three sons, Chip Railing and Bill Railing of Wheeling, WV; Andrew Railing of Charlottesville, VA, and eight grandchildren. Memorial Service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the Colorado School of Mines Alumna Association, 1600 Arapaho Street, Golden, CO. 80401.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bank of England Lowers Rate a Quarter-Point

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point today, reflecting concern about global financial turmoil and fears of recession among British exporters and manufacturers.
It was the bank's first such action since June 1996. The general response to the reduction, to 7.25 percent from 7.5 percent, however, was that it would make little immediate difference to Britain's economic slowdown. "What makes a difference is the signal that rates are coming down," said Holger Schmieding, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "It was important in that those expectations were not disappointed." 
 The reduction had little effect on currency trading and did nothing to halt the slide of British equity markets. London's Financial Times 100 index slumped 2.7 percent today, to 4,698.90 points.
The British rate cut matched a similar quarter-point reduction by the Federal Reserve in the United States last week and coincided with indications that interest rates internationally are falling. Japan, Canada and Spain have also cut rates; Portugal and Ireland are expected to drop their higher rates to the average among the nine other nations preparing to introduce the single European currency on Jan. 1.
The Bank of England's nine-member Monetary Policy Committee -- which is responsible for setting interest rates -- said it had taken the action because the worsening international climate had damaged business and consumer confidence.
The bank's guidelines are primarily to hold down inflation to a target of 2.5 percent. Despite indications this week that British paychecks are soaring, the bank said today that inflation might fall to less than 2.5 percent, making it "appropriate" to cut interest rates.
The modest reduction disappointed analysts who had hoped for a cut of half a percentage point.
"It's obviously a move in the right direction, and it's obviously part of what's necessary," said David Mackie, an economist at J. P. Morgan. "But the Bank of England has a lot more to do. The economy is going to be very weak next year, and they'll need to react to that by cutting rates aggressively."
Today's rate cut came after projections by Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, that growth would be far slower next year than the Government had first forecast -- possibly as low as 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Slight Drop Found in North America's Pollution

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
One of the first detailed studies of environmental pollution across North America shows a slight decrease in the amount of hazardous substances being released into the air, water and soil, but the improving record of American industry was largely offset by hefty increases in pollution by Canadian companies.
The report, released on Wednesday in Montreal, does not include conditions in Mexico because usable information still is not widely collected, nearly five years after implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement required such environmental monitoring. 
 The continental study was conducted by the Commission for Environmental Cooperation, which includes representatives from the United States, Canada and Mexico. It estimates that in 1995 about 20,000 manufacturing plants reported that they had produced more than 2.8 billion pounds of hazardous substances, including known carcinogens, that were released directly into the air or water, or were transferred to landfills.
That amount represents a decline of 1.5 percent across North America, and is considered an important step toward slowing the spread of dangerous substances across international boundaries.
But when broken down by country, the figures give a slightly different picture of North America. Pollution produced by industries in the United States declined 2.1 percent in 1995 from 1994, while in Canada the amount of pollution released or transferred increased 3.9 percent.
Methanol, ammonia, zinc, nitric acid and toluene made up almost half of the pollutants released in 1995.
The report also indicates that while the United States has far more industrial sites, Canadian plants, on average, emit almost twice as much pollution. Lisa Nichols, a program manager for technical cooperation at the environmental commission, said it was not clear why Canadian plants produced higher average pollution.
Although the report is not expected to cause much controversy in the United States, it is likely to raise environmental concerns in Canada about the weakness of the system of provincial environmental standards.
"Essentially there has been an assumption that the Canadian performance is as strong as the U.S., but part of what makes this report so significant is the extent to which it shatters that national myth," said David S. Winfield, research director at the Canadian Institute for Environmental Law and Policy, a nonprofit organization in Toronto.
When the commission released similar results in its first report last year, local governments and industries in Canada said it was unfair to compare general statistics on pollution among unrelated industries in different states or provinces.
This year's report is also expected to focus attention on the lack of progress Mexico has made toward meeting the requirements of the environmental side agreement that President Clinton tacked onto the Nafta legislation in 1993 to get it approved by Congress.
Mexican officials said they had started collecting information on industrial pollutants last year but still had a long way to go before they compiled a list comparable to those monitored in the other two countries.
Arturo Morales, an official with the National Institute of Technology in Mexico, said some Mexican industries had objected to the inclusion of certain hazardous substances on the list of about 200 pollutants that will be tracked. Since Nafta took effect in 1994, the Mexican Government has feared that environmental regulations could be used in a way that harms domestic industries.
Peter M. Emerson, senior economist for the Environmental Defense Fund, said he was disturbed by the lack of progress in Mexico.

HEADLINE: France Seeks Talks on Iraqi Chemical Tests

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 8

 BODY:
France asked today for a meeting of technical experts at the United Nations to "clarify" the results of tests its scientists carried out on Iraqi warheads. Earlier American tests had found traces of chemicals linked to VX, a deadly nerve gas .
Iraq denied that it put VX on warheads, and called for additional tests, which were conducted over the summer in France and Switzerland. Preliminary results from these tests did not find VX. 
 But several weapons experts said that final French tests apparently found traces of VX components. Some diplomats also charged that France had withheld these results because it did not want to embarrass Iraq while it lobbied this week at the United Nations to lift sanctions imposed after it invaded Kuwait in 1990.
Although French diplomats have denied withholding results, and said they expected that the final French tests would show no traces of VX, today's statement by the French Foreign Ministry neither confirmed nor denied the reports.
Instead, a French Foreign Ministry spokesman said that French experts would make a presentation at the meeting, now scheduled for Oct. 22 and 23, that "would allow an appreciation of the scientific methods used by the three laboratories" of the United States, France and Switzerland. That language suggested France's scientific findings as well as those of the Swiss may have differed in methodology from the American procedures.
Some diplomats here said, however, this may set the scene for an inconclusive result in which no one gets blamed.
Before sanctions are lifted, Iraq's weapons of mass destruction must be destroyed, and the United Nations Special Commission, charged with overseeing that process, must be confident that Iraq cannot rebuild them. Iraq has often accused the United States of making misleading charges aimed at delaying any lifting of the punishing economic sanctions. But if tests find traces of VX, Iraqi credibility would be further weakened.
Iraq officially suspended all inspections by the special commission on Aug. 5 and refused again on Wednesday to reopen the way for a resumption of these forays. The United Nations said it would not consider any action on lifting sanctions until the inspections resumed.
Ewen Buchanan, a spokesman for the special commission, said the group had planned to call for a new meeting of experts even before the French controversy arose. "There is the matter of sampling to discuss and then the whole issue of VX," and how much of it Iraq had produced.
Iraq and the United Nations have also clashed about one of the special commission's chief inspectors, Scott Ritter, who quit in protest recently, charging that the United Nations and the United States were easing up on inspections, seeking to avoid further confrontations with Iraq. Richard Butler, who heads the commission, accused Mr. Ritter of divulging secrets about the commission's work.
Today, in a letter released to the press, Mr. Ritter's lawyers asserted he has a constitutional right to speak his mind and will continue to do so despite a threat of prosecution. The lawyers asked Mr. Butler to "retract" a statement charging Mr. Ritter with breaking the law.

HEADLINE: Lyman Ford, 89, Who Headed A Precursor to the United Way

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Lyman S. Ford, who in the 1960's was president of what became United Way of America and who pushed the old Community Chests to become a financing channel for President Lyndon B. Johnson's war on poverty, died Monday of pneumonia at a hospice in Hillsborough, N.C., United Way of America said. He was 89.
When the war on poverty began in late 1964, its leader, Sargent Shriver, rushed to get Federal funds out to about 1,000 hastily created community action agencies. In many cities Mr. Ford pressed the local Community Chests to step forward and receive the funds, arguing that since they already had legal status as public charities and networks of social service agencies under their umbrella, they could best handle the money. 
 The tactic, which infuriated some advocates for the poor who wanted organizations outside the local power structures to control the funds, set the stage for the rapid growth of Government funds to social service charities. Today, nonprofit social service agencies rely on Government money for more than half of their revenue, said Lester M. Salamon, a Johns Hopkins University economist who studies nonprofit agencies.
During the decade that Mr. Ford headed what was then called United Community Funds and Councils of America, he dealt with the mergers in many cities of competing social service charity fund drives, an efficiency move urged by corporate leaders who wanted to simplify payroll giving into a single unified drive.
"In some communities it was a very positive merger and in others it was a shotgun wedding," recalled Dick Aft, a protege of Mr. Ford who is now president of the United Way and Community Chest of Greater Cincinnati. "But everywhere Lyman worked with tact and diplomacy to make it work."
Mr. Ford also resisted efforts to expand United Way into financing the arts and other fields, sticking close to the core interest in helping children, troubled people and the elderly.
Lyman Sedgwick Ford was born in Baldwinsville, N.Y., the son of a minister. He graduated from Denison University and earned a master's degree at Ohio State University, which also gave him an honorary doctorate.
In 1931, he started out as publicity director for the Community Chest in Columbus, Ohio. He later headed the Community Chests in Evanston, Ill., and Kansas City, Mo., and then joined the Community Chest national staff in 1942. He became associate executive director in 1950 and executive director in 1960, retiring in 1970.
Mr. Ford was a trustee of Denison and served on the boards of the National Charities Information Bureau, the National Council on Social Work Education and the National Conference of Lawyers and Social Workers.
He is survived by his wife, Mary Elizabeth Nist Ford; a daughter, Barbara Ford Thelen of Denver; a son, James Lyman Ford of Mequon, Wis.; seven grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: U.S. Said to Face Brunt of Economic Crisis

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank wound up their annual meetings today saying that the United States will bear most of the burden of helping Asia and the rest of the developing world get out of a recession.
America's relatively strong economy will draw in the exports of crisis-stricken countries at the same time that foreign demand for American goods is weakened. As a result, the United States balance of payments deficit will soar, with I.M.F. forecasts showing the American deficit rising sharply from $155 billion in 1997 to $236 billion this year and $290 billion in 1999. 
 One implication of that rising deficit is that a steady increase in competitively priced imports can, over time, lead to an erosion of American market share and jobs.
By contrast, the 15 member countries of the European Union and Japan will continue running substantial payment surpluses with exports far in excess of imports.
On Wednesday, Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, struck a note of quiet desperation when he described his country's failure to recover economically, saying at the annual meeting that, "despite steady implementation of the latest economic policy package, the largest ever, our economic situation is still extremely severe."
Japan seems set to remain in deep recession this year with only a minute recovery next year. Its already massive payments surplus of $94 billion last year is expected to reach $131 billion this year and $135 billion next.
In his final address and press conference today, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F., said the world was making progress toward resolving the crisis that has gripped much of the global economy since the collapse of some of Asia's leading economies last year.
"Nothing could have happened more than has happened," he said. "We are dealing with a monumental task."
The 182 countries represented at the meetings endorsed his proposals for tackling five "major shortcomings" in the international financial system, he said.
These included a lack of transparency about economic details throughout the world that impeded sound policy making; weak financial systems; unrestricted and volatile flows of capital around the globe; a reluctance to make private banks and other financial institutions pay part of the costs of the crisis; and better regulation of world financial markets.
He said he is now "confident" agreement will be reached between the Clinton Administration and Congress to give the I.M.F. about $18 billion in new funds as part of a $90 billion effort by several countries to recapitalize the fund.
The meeting also endorsed President Clinton's call for a new standby loan fund linked to the I.M.F. that would bolster the financial defenses of some countries before they came under attack from investors.
Agreement is also close, he said, on new steps to shore up Brazil's shaky economy that would include an announcement by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso later this month of new austerity measures in return for a new a package of loans from the fund and other donors. Finally, while the world economy was still sailing "stormy, uncharted waters," Mr. Camdessus said the recent cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, and Europe's low interest rates, showed that central bankers are striving to preserve economic growth. "Growth must be sustained. Inflation is not a danger," Mr. Camdessus said. Early today, the Bank of England cut a key interest rate by a quarter point.
Nevertheless, while this year's annual meeting undoubtedly produced a plethora of ideas on mending the world's damaged monetary system and a positive avalanche of pledges to do so, it has not yet resulted in any concrete action.
The leaders of both institutions put the best possible face on the outcome despite the lack of specific action and the vagueness of many of the pledges made by their governments.
"We have undoubtedly moved a long way forward in identifying the steps needed to establish a more durable global economic system and for addressing the crisis," Mr. Camdessus said.
With millions of people being pushed back into abject poverty throughout the developing world by the economic downturn, the World Bank President, James D. Wolfensohn, expressed satisfaction that governments now recognized that more must be done to protect people from the social costs of the crisis.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Clear Channel toBuy Jacor For $2.8 Billion in Stock

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
Clear Channel Communications agreed yesterday to pay $2.8 billion in stock for Jacor Communications, the broadcaster that brings Rush Limbaugh, Dr. Laura Schlessinger and other radio personalities to the nation.
The combined company would rank third in radio revenues, behind CBS and the Chancellor Broadcasting Company, and second in number of stations. 
 Jacor's chairman is Sam Zell, a personality in his own right whose Zell/Chilmark Fund holds 26 percent of the company's shares. Analysts and others on Wall Street said that he had chosen Clear Channel in part because its founder and chief executive, L. Lowry Mays, had agreed to keep Jacor management and because he had confidence in Clear Channel and its stock.
"When someone as savvy as Zell looks at someone as savvy as Lowry Mays, I think he takes a lot of comfort from that," said Thomas A. Vanderslice, a managing director in investment banking for the CIBC Oppenheimer Corporation.
Mr. Mays said in an interview that the deal, which also includes the assumption of $1.5 billion in Jacor's debt, would pay off through growth rather than cutbacks and economies. Having clusters of radio stations in many markets where he also has billboards, and programs to send everywhere, will help in attracting advertisers, he said.
Jacor has about 40 percent of its radio station revenues in cities where Clear Channel has forests of billboards. But the Clear Channel radio stations are mostly in different markets, Mr. Mays said, making it easy to win Government approval for the deal without having to sell many stations off.
The combined company would have 2 or more radio stations in 6 of the nation's 12 largest markets, but not New York City. There, Clear Channel, the nation's largest billboard company, has more than 1,000 billboards. In a rapidly consolidating business, analysts praised the Jacor acquisition as complementary and fairly priced. "It's a very good fit," said Jessica Reif Cohen, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, confirming the company's prediction that 1999's earnings per share would benefit.
Analysts also agreed, however, that Jacor would have fetched more before stock market reversals that have hit media companies especially hard. In another rough day for the markets, Clear Channel shares fell 37.5 cents, to $36.625, while Jacor rose 43.75 cents, to $40.5625. Standard & Poor's said it was considering downgrading Clear Chanel's debt and upgrading Jacor's.
Since Congress eased the limits on radio station ownership, buyers have built large companies able to offer advertisers the sort of broad coverage, within a market or across the nation, that newspapers and television have boasted.
Analysts said that CBS was the most serious rival Jacor bidder, with Chancellor, controlled by the Hicks, Muse leveraged buyout firm, also having shown an interest.
Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, has 625 radio stations, 19 television stations and about 220,000 billboards in 25 countries. Mr. Mays founded the company with Red McCombs, a flamboyant San Antonio car dealer who now owns the Minnesota Vikings, 26 years ago when they bought a local FM station for $130,000.
Mr. Mays is about as modest in discussing his company's performance since then as Mr. Limbaugh is in discussing the virtues of his political doctrines. "A stellar growth performance history," Mr. Mays said.
Based in Covington, Ky., Jacor, including pending acquisitions, has 230 radio stations and one television station, as well as Premiere Radio Networks, which syndicates radio shows. Mr. Zell, said to be out of the country, could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Republicans List Terms for I.M.F. Payout

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Republican Congressional leaders presented the Clinton Administration today with a list of lending conditions that they want imposed on the International Monetary Fund in order for Congress to approve $18 billion in new money for the I.M.F.
Administration and Congressional officials said that they were hopeful that they could soon agree on compromise legislation to provide the money to the I.M.F. to refill reserve accounts depleted by the fund's attempts to bail out the economies of Russia and three Asian nations. 
 But they said they were still without a timetable for an agreement. Citing the turmoil in international financial markets, the White House has insisted that the legislation be approved and sent to the President before Congress adjourns for the year, which could happen this weekend.
While the list of conditions being sought by the Republicans was not made public, Congressional officials said that it included a demand that the I.M.F. open its books for public scrutiny, that it end the practice of lending to foreign governments at below-market interest rates, and that it shorten the lending period on most loans.
The list was presented to Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin during a meeting today on Capitol Hill with the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, and the House Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia.
After the meeting, Mr. Rubin told reporters that it had gone well. "It was a good meeting," he said. "It was very constructive and we're just going to keep working forward."
Administration officials say the White House is reluctant to accept any legislation that imposes onerous lending conditions on the I.M.F., especially at a time when the fund needs flexibility to avert a global financial meltdown.
The Senate has already approved the full $18 billion in new fund financing requested by the Clinton Administration. But the House has balked at the request and has so far approved only $3.4 billion.
The talks this week are aimed at satisfying House Republican leaders, who are being pressed by conservatives within their party who have questioned whether the economic crisis that has swept the third world is evidence that the monetary fund has outlived its usefulness.
"I have been as critical about the I.M.F. as many, but given the crisis we have around the world, the U.S. needs to provide leadership," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, a key Republican in the talks.
He said that given the chaos in international financial markets, the United States was left with no option but to provide the money to the fund. "The only real avenue is the I.M.F.," he said.
Congressional officials say the House leadership has shown a new willingness to resolve the monetary fund issue -- and to end a variety of other financing disputes with the White House -- in hopes of preventing a Government shutdown that might distract public attention away from the impeachment investigation of President Clinton.
Moreover, if the United States fails to provide the money other nations might reduce their contributions, leaving the fund short of the $90 billion its says is needed to deal with the current financial world crisis.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Yield for 30-Year Rises to 4.99% In a Mixed Session for Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities ended sharply mixed yesterday, with selling by hedge funds battering the long end of the market even as shorter maturities were bolstered by weakness in equities.
Several analysts said shorter maturities were up on expectations of slower growth and further rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Some others said a widely publicized decision by Greg Smith, a Prudential Securities strategist, to raise cash allocations in investment portfolios might have helped the shorter-bill sector. 
 The 30-year bond fell 2 3/32 , more than two points for a second consecutive day, to a price of 107 23/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 4.99 percent, from 4.86 percent on Wednesday. Bills and shorter-term notes also gained, with the bond-equivalent yield on a one-year bill down to 3.92 percent. Among other long-term issues, the yield on the 10-year note rose to 4.57 percent, from 4.39 percent the previous day.
Dennis C. Hynes, chief market strategist at R. W. Pressprich & Company, said that yesterday's trade in bonds was certainly tied to hedge funds liquidating speculative investments in Japanese yen, as the yen gained on the dollar.
"The unwinding by hedge funds has now overtaken the flight-to-quality bid in Treasuries," Mr. Hynes said. "The need to unwind yen trades is the most dominant thing in the market right now."
He said that because the yen had rallied, it put severe pressure on those investors who had bet on a weaker yen, a higher dollar and a stronger Treasury market. "When the yen rallied, the short yen positions became unprofitable and that forced the unwinding of the trade, which now goes in reverse, starting with the sale of Treasuries," he said.

HEADLINE: G.E. Profit Rise Meets Estimates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 8

 BODY:
The General Electric Company said today that its third-quarter profit rose 13 percent, matching expectations, even as delayed shipments of power-generating equipment were partly responsible for disappointing sales growth.
Net income at G.E., owner of the world's largest nonbank finance company and the top-rated NBC television network, rose to $2.28 billion, or 69 cents a diluted share, from $2.01 billion, or 60 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 9.8 percent, to $24.14 billion from $21.99 billion, less than the 15 to 20 percent increase that G.E. predicted in early September. 
 Shipments of some turbines to Indonesia were pushed into the fourth quarter, raising concern that G.E. is not immune to global economic turmoil, analysts said. While several multinational companies like Coca-Cola and Gillette have warned that profits will slump because of the Asian economic crisis, G.E. gets only a small part of its revenue and profit from that region.
G.E., the most valuable United States company, fell $3.4375 a share, to $71.5625, as 15.6 million of its shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Sales Gains At Retailers In September

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The nation's discount retailers today reported strong September sales gains at stores open at least a year, while department stores and others, hit by unseasonably warm weather early in the month and Hurricane Georges, had only slim gains.
"Discounters performed exceedingly well and department stores exceedingly weak," said Michael Niemira, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. in New York. 
 Sales in stores open at least a year, known as same-store sales, rose 4.5 percent in September compared with the month a year earlier, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, tipped off the month's trend by reporting a 9.5 percent gain. Sales at the discount store Dollar General rose 8 percent. Family Dollar Stores reported a 12.3 percent increase and Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, posted a 6.1 percent gain.
The Kmart Corporation, the largest discounter after Wal-Mart, said same-store sales rose 5.6 percent.
Among department stores Sears, Roebuck & Company, the No. 2 United States retailer, said domestic same-store sales fell 1.7 percent in September and J. C. Penney Company, the No. 4 retailer, said sales fell 6.6 percent. Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's and Macy's, said sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Luxury retailers also posted sales declines. Neiman Marcus Group, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., for example, said sales fell 7.1 percent.
"There's a clear shift in consumer spending from the upper scale to the discounters," said Kurt Barnard, retail consultant and president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, in Upper Montclair, N.J.
The bright spot among department stores was the May Department Stores Company, which operates Lord & Taylor, Filene's and Hecht's. Its sales rose 4.3 percent.
Clothing sales met or surpassed expectations at several specialty apparel retailers. Sales at Ann Taylor Stores, which revamped its women's career clothing line after it lost customers to unpopular fashions last year, rose 8.5 percent, which was better than expected. Sales at Gap Inc., which has heavily advertised its jeans and slacks, rose 14 percent. The retailer also benefited from strong sales at its Old Navy casual-clothing chain, analysts said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Dollar Hits111.73 Yen Before Staging Comeback

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Foreign-exchange traders battered the dollar into what looked like a second consecutive free fall yesterday before the currency abruptly reversed course, ending only slightly lower against the Japanese yen in extraordinarily volatile dealings.
On Wednesday, the dollar registered its biggest one-day drop against the yen in a quarter century, losing more than 8 percent of its value. 
 There was little movement between the currencies during overnight trading in Tokyo, but when European markets opened the dollar again came under attack, plunging as much as 7 percent, to a low of 111.73 yen, a level last seen in early June 1997.
Selling slowed and then turned during the afternoon in New York, and by late in the day the dollar was quoted at 119.05 yen, down from 120.25 yen late Wednesday.
"This has been about the craziest day my colleagues and I have ever seen," said Jeremy Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston. "But in spite of this we are optimistic, because we seem to have gotten rid of the speculative excess that was in the system."
As on Wednesday, traders said much of the selling was done by large speculative hedge funds unwinding positions they had taken based on a bet that the yen would remain weak. And the impact of those sales was magnified because trading volume was quite light yesterday, Mr. Fand and others said.
"The market has been very quiet," said Michael Rosenberg, manager of currency and international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch & Company. "There is no liquidity in this market, and no appetite for risk in this sort of a chaotic situation."
Traders said the dollar's slide slowed and then reversed after the trading desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York began calling currency dealers to ask about conditions in the market.
The New York Fed, which has operational control of the Government's day-to-day dealings in the foreign exchange market, makes such calls when conditions appear unsettled. But some traders interpreted the inquiries as a possible sign that the Fed might be preparing to buy dollars to send a message that the United States wants the dollar to stabilize.
In addition, Mr. Fand said traders were encouraged by news bulletins suggesting that a rescue package for Brazil was in the process of being assembled, and that Congress, after much delay, may be close to approving an $18 billion increase in funds for the International Monetary Fund.
Perhaps most important, there was a recognition that the dollar had fallen much too steeply and much too fast against the yen, especially considering recent predictions that the dollar could reach 160 yen by the end of the year.
"Enough is enough," Mr. Fand said. "What had happened was an obscene level of a correction for a two-day period. There are clearly buyers of dollars with the dollar between 110 yen and 115 yen."
Mr. Rosenberg seemed to share the view that the dollar's wild gyrations against the yen were effectively over. Over the coming weeks and months, he said he expected the dollar to move higher against the yen.
"We need to build a base where the dollar trades between 115 yen and 125 yen," he said. "I think that will be the range for the next few weeks. After that, we think the dollar will gradually appreciate against the yen," perhaps to as high as 170.
News that a financial rescue package for Brazil was being assembled also helped push the dollar up against the German mark and other major currencies.
Late yesterday, the dollar was trading at 1.6375 German marks, up from 1.6138 marks on Wednesday.
"Without any doubt, this last week was a turning point for financial markets," Mr. Fand said.
"The message has been conveyed that a line has been drawn in the sand, and that emerging markets will not be allowed to bleed any more. If Brazil is going to be saved and the I.M.F. is going to get its funding, the world has to have some renewed confidence that this is the end of the financial crisis."

HEADLINE: Proposed Cigarette Deal Doesn't Force Rise in Price

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Under a national settlement being negotiated by the tobacco industry, cigarette makers would not be required to pass along to consumers the cost of the deal, a price increase that many anti-smoking advocates have said is critical to reducing under-age tobacco use.
As part of Federal legislation that failed earlier this year, cigarette producers would have been required to pass along the cost -- about $1.10 a package -- to consumers. Though there is disagreement over the precise impact of price increases on teen-age cigarette use, many public health experts have held that such increases are a major weapon in reducing smoking by young people. 
 But the $198 billion national settlement being negotiated by lawyers for the industry and eight states would allow cigarette makers to absorb part or all of its costs, several lawyers briefed on the proposal said.
That means that producers may choose for competitive reasons to hold down cigarette prices or decide the pace of how they will pass along the settlement's cost. The plan would cost producers 35 to 40 cents a pack over the next five years, industry officials and an analyst estimated.
"I think they will increase cigarette prices slowly to get consumers used to the higher price increases," said Bonnie Zoller, a tobacco industry analyst with the Credit Suisse First Boston Corporation. "A sharp increase in prices could cause a drop in consumption."
Opponents of smoking and some economists have argued that a sharp, significant increase in cigarette prices could provide the most effective way to reduce teen-age smoking.
In May, for example, Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, testified before Congress that the Clinton Administration believed that the "best way to combat youth smoking is to raise the price."
Mr. Summers testified that studies showed that every 10 percent increase in cigarette prices could produce up to a 7 percent decrease in the number of children who smoked. But other economists have called those projections overly optimistic.
The structure of the settlement proposal, which has not been completed, is fundamentally different than the failed Federal tobacco legislation because it leaves the timing of any cigarette price increases up to the producers.
Regulators briefed on the current talks said they did not have the legal authority to require cigarette makers to pass along a settlement's cost because the negotiators are resolving lawsuits, not passing legislation.
Since last year, tobacco companies have reached settlements with four states -- Florida, Minnesota, Mississippi and Texas -- that have brought lawsuits against the industry to recover smoking-related health costs, agreeing to pay those states some $40 billion over the next 25 years.
To reflect the cost of those settlements, producers have announced increases in the wholesale price of cigarettes amounting to 25 cents a pack. But the national average retail price of a pack has remained at about $2.
Ms. Zoller, the analyst, said that the prices being paid by smokers had not increased because cigarette makers were deeply discounting prices on the wholesale level and absorbing settlement costs as they battled for market share.
She said that she expected the pattern of discounting to continue for a time if a new national settlement is reached. She said she believed that the Philip Morris Companies, the nation's largest cigarette maker, could absorb settlement costs longer than other producers because it was financially the strongest.
Ms. Zoller said she believed that if the settlement's cost were passed along to consumers, cigarette use among smokers of all ages would fall 15 percent.
Scott Williams, a spokesman for the tobacco industry, declined to comment on the settlement talks.
Lawyers involved in the talks said that a final plan is not likely to emerge for at least 10 days and may be delayed further. The new proposal is intended to cover the 46 states that either had lawsuits pending against the industry or had not sued it.
Along with Philip Morris, the tobacco companies involved are the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, a unit of the R.J.R. Nabisco Holdings Corporation; Brown & Williamson Tobacco, a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries; Lorillard Tobacco, a subsidiary of the Loews Corporation, and the smokeless tobacco producer U.S. Tobacco, a subsidiary of UST Inc.
