HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Politicians Seek Wider Role In European Central Bank

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 8

 BODY:
As financial gloom grew across Europe today, political leaders were running into deepening conflicts with European central banks over the best way to respond.
With less than three months before 11 countries adopt the euro as a new European currency, the bankers who govern the new European Central Bank are holding to a conservative policy designed to establish the euro's credibility. But political leaders, particularly in Germany and France, have begun bluntly attacking those policies and are pushing for easier money as a way to spur economic growth and jobs. 
 The dispute has intensified in the last few days after the Social Democratic Party's victory in German elections on Sept. 27. While the United States Federal Reserve has begun to cut rates, many of Europe's politically independent bankers have been reluctant to follow suit, and politicians are beginning to complain.
"I find it wrong that the Bundesbank conducts its monetary policy as if these problematic developments in global finance weren't there," said Oskar Lafontaine, the chairman of the Social Democratic Party who is expected to be named Finance Minister in the new German Government. "It's not a holy institution with a doctrine of papal infallibility."
Most central bankers are refusing to bend. European currencies have surged against the dollar in recent days after Hans Tietmeyer, the president of Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, made it clear on Wednesday that he would not cut rates in the near future.
But the pressure is increasing. European stock markets plunged today, largely on expectations that stronger European currencies hurt exports and slow growth. In Germany, Europe's biggest economy and heaviest exporter, the benchmark DAX index plunged 4.98 percent.
In another sign of pressure, the Bank of England announced today that it would cut a key short-term interest rate by a quarter-point, to 7.25 percent. For Britain, which has decided not to join the European currency union and follows a separate monetary policy, it was the first rate cut since June 1996.
In continental Europe, leaders are battling over fundamental economic policy. With the Social Democrats' victory, Europe's biggest countries are or will soon be controlled by center-left governments. A growing number of those governments now favor an easier monetary policy and would like to exert more political control over the European Central Bank. Mr. Lafontaine has been an adamant critic of hawkish monetary policies. Representing the Social Democrats' orthodox left wing, he has argued for years that such policies are the biggest culprits behind the nation's high unemployment.
French political leaders share those views. the Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, has long advocated lower interest rates to spur job creation. He has also bristled at the political independence given to the Bank of France and the new European Central Bank, calling for stronger political controls.
All of that runs counter to core principles of the European Central Bank and of individual national banks. Because the euro will have its debut in January, the central banks of each member country have already locked their policies together into what amounts to a single framework.
By law, the new European Central Bank is allowed only to focus on the question of price stability and inflation. Government leaders are not allowed to interfere or to influence any of its decisions.
"What we are seeing is indeed very significant," said Thomas Mayer, an economist at Goldman, Sachs in Frankfurt. "We aren't used to having a government trying to influence monetary policy. In the strategy of the new German Government, the role of monetary policy is obviously to spur economic growth and the creation of jobs. That is obviously an approach that the central bankers of the European Central Bank do not share."
Many economists argue that Europe is already following an expansionary monetary policy and does not need to change course.
Germany's basic short-term rate is 3.3 percent, and the average rate across the 11 countries in the "euro zone" is 3.7 percent -- significantly lower than in the United States, where rates are more than 5 percent.
Indeed, Mr. Tietmeyer and many private sector economists argue that Europe is already loosening monetary policy as it prepares for the euro. That is because countries with traditionally high interest rates, like Spain and Italy, have to align their rates with those of Germany and France before the debut of the euro.
Until recently, most economists assumed that Germany would help close the gap by nudging its rates upward. Instead, the central bankers appear determined to keep their rates low and let the other countries drop down to their level.
Despite the global financial turbulence, Dresdner Bank and many other institutions still predict that European economic growth will remain well above 2 percent next year and will exceed that of the United States. That is because the United States is likely to be more affected by a slowdown in Latin America.
"The central bankers are confident that monetary policy in euroland is expansionary at the moment and will remain expansionary," said Stefan Bergheim, an economist at Merrill Lynch in Frankfurt. "We don't need to be lectured by central bankers who are running interest rates that are 20 percent higher than ours."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Fears of a Spreading Recession Send Markets Tumbling

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Sparing only a couple of major markets, stock prices tumbled around the world yesterday in emotional and often panicky trading, reflecting investor fear that recession might be spreading from the Far East to Europe and might eventually grip the United States. But then Wall Street suddenly reversed course and produced a late-session comeback in the third-heaviest trading session on record.
Soon after the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slumped 20 percent from its mid-July peak -- the amount that has come to define a bear market -- it bounced back to halve its loss, which amounted to a moderate 1.16 percent. The rally also lifted the index back above the low it set in the Aug. 31 market wipeout. 
The recovery of the blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average was also strong, ending with a decline of just 9.78 points after having fallen 274.20 at midday. Nasdaq stocks, battered for much of the year, also improved during the afternoon, but the chief index still lost another 2.97 percent for the day to make a 16-month low. The Nasdaq has fallen 12 percent in the last four trading days.
Stocks had dropped sharply in Japan and Europe, with Tokyo's Nikkei down 5.8 percent, erasing Wednesday's advance. Major indexes fell 4.98 percent in Germany, 4.45 percent in France and 2.69 percent in Britain. Brazil's exchange, which finished marginally higher, and Hong Kong's, which rose 2.5 percent, were the only markets that escaped damage. "Today you can cut the fear with a knife," said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist for A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. Some of the selling, he added, was with little consideration of price.
Some of the depressed mood this morning was attributed to Abby Joseph Cohen, the widely followed Goldman, Sachs strategist, who trimmed her profit estimates for S.& P. companies by $1.50, to $49, for this year and by $2.50, to $52.50, for 1999.
Nonetheless, she said her lowered expectations would have "little direct impact" on stock returns because of the lowered profits would be offset by lower interest rates and lower inflation.
At Prudential Securities, Greg Smith, its chief investment strategist, recommended that investors quadruple cash allotments to 20 percent of their portfolios, while Ralph Acampora, the firm's technical analyst, sharply reduced his target ranges for the S.& P. and the Dow.
About 2 P.M., however, investors seemed to decide that emotional selling had made many stocks seem like bargains.
"We could be at a pretty important turning point," suggested Richard T. McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. He said it was typical of the final stages of a downturn for dispirited investors to try to wring some profit from shrinking portfolios by selling stocks that had resisted the decline, such as drug companies.
After what Mr. McCabe called this final "capitulation," the market tends to come back, as seemed to happen during the afternoon. Merck traded as low as 121 5/8 before rallying to close at 127, up 1 3/16 .
Financial companies had remarkably sharp reversals, with J. P. Morgan up 5 3/8, to 79 7/8, after trading as low as 72 1/8; Merrill Lynch up 4 3/4 at 42 1/2, after being as low as 35 3/4, and Bankers Trust recovering from 45 to finish at 54 1/2, up 5 5/16 .
Citigroup, the newly minted product of the Citibank-Travelers merger, finished at 32 1/2, up 3/4, after trading at 28 1/2. "We need a big, hard down day to sort of clear the selling pressure," Richard Cripps, chief strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore, said during the morning shortly after canceling a business trip in light of further declines overseas.
In the end, 13 of the 30 Dow industrials managed gains yesterday, with Kodak up 2 7/16 , to 80 1/16 , right behind J. P. Morgan. The biggest Dow loser -- without which the index would have risen -- was General Electric, down 3 7/16 , to 71 9/16 , as third-quarter sales were lower than expected.
Among Nasdaq stocks, Dell Computer swung wildly before losing 2 1/8, to 48 7/16 ; Microsoft shed 2 15/16 , to 91 3/16 , and Yahoo dropped 9 9/16 , to 104 13/16 .
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 1.11 billion shares, with 2,651 stocks closing lower and 615 higher. A total of 933 issues made new lows for the year compared with only 45 new highs.
The S.& P. index drop was 11.24, to 959.44, barely above the 957.28 Aug. 31 low. At its worst yesterday, however, the index stood at 923.32, 22.2 percent below its high on July 17.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PARTIES;
In Area Around New York, Only 2 Break Party Ranks

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
After much wringing of hands, reading of the Constitution and consulting of priests and pollsters, almost every member of the House of Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut did what party leaders asked today on the vote to begin an impeachment inquiry.
Only 2 of the 50 members from the three states broke party ranks in voting on the Republican-sponsored measure, which passed by a vote of 258 to 176. Both were Democrats: Carolyn McCarthy of Long Island and Jim Maloney of Connecticut. 
 Ms. McCarthy, a former Republican who joined the Democratic Party just months before winning her seat in 1996, called her vote the hardest she had taken in Congress. She said she agreed with Democratic leaders in wanting some limits set on the inquiry, but felt that an open-ended investigation was better than none.
"The only way we are going to bring this whole investigation to a close and to get the truth is to move the process forward," she said in a statement.
Mr. Maloney is facing one of the toughest re-election fights of any House member, against a Republican who had vowed to attack him if he opposed the inquiry.
In explaining his vote, Mr. Maloney, a first-term Congressman, said, "This is a very serious matter that has to be dealt with, and this is a way to move the process along so we can get back to the issues that affect the people."
Several Democratic fence straddlers, including Representatives Louise M. Slaughter of New York and Bill Pascrell Jr. and Robert E. Andrews, both of New Jersey, made up their minds late Wednesday after what they said was much anguish and more than a little pressure from the House Democratic leadership.
"Hamilton's words struck me," said Mr. Pascrell, before loosely paraphrasing Alexander Hamilton, a founder of the City of Paterson, which he represents. "If we have an inquiry and it's all over the place, the country will suffer and we will only divide the nation more and more."
Most Democrats echoed the position of President Clinton and other House Democratic leaders in saying that the nation wanted Congress to focus less on investigating the President and more on important issues like crowded schools and the global economic crisis.
"We need to get back to work on the issues affecting the people," Mr. Andrews said.
Several Democrats from the region had already made their opposition to the inquiry known before today's vote, including Representatives Charles E. Schumer, Nita M. Lowey and Charles B. Rangel, all of New York. But that did not stop them from delivering fiery floor speeches attacking the Republican measure.
"We have become a modern-day kangaroo court," said Representative Gregory W. Meeks of Queens.
Among the only Republicans from the region to speak in support of the measure was Representative Vito J. Fossella Jr. of Staten Island. Mr. Fossella, a first-term Congressman, said he hoped future generations would view today's vote as "our finest hour, upholding what our founding fathers and every generation since has looked for and yearned for: the notion of freedom, the notion of liberty, the notion of the rule of law."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Global Turmoil May Slow Nation's Buoyant Economy
The financial markets were jittery as more investors began to fear the country cannot avoid the economic slowdown that has gripped much of the world. The value of the dollar dropped further, interest rates rose and the prices of many stocks fell. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,731.91, lower by just 9.78 points after being down as much as 274 points during the day. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 11.24 points, or 1.16 percent, to 959.44, while the Nasdaq index dropped 43.49 points, or 2.97 percent, to 1,419.12, its lowest close in 16 months. Page A1.
 
Treasury securities ended mixed, with selling by hedge funds battering the long end of the market even as shorter maturities were bolstered by weakness in equities. The 30-year bond fell 23/32 , more than two points for a second consecutive day, while the yield rose to 4.99 percent. C6.
 
The Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, reflecting concern about global financial turmoil and fears of recession among British exporters and manufacturers. C2.
 
No Taxes for Cyberspace Purchases
The Senate voted overwhelmingly to make cyberspace a tax-free zone for most transactions for the next three years. C3.
 
Judge Deals Microsoft a Setback
A Federal judge dealt Microsoft a setback in its antitrust trial preparations by denying the company access to the interview tapes and transcripts for a new book written by two business school professors. C4.
 
Retail Sales Rose 4.5% Last Month
Retail sales at stores open at least a year rose 4.5 percent in September with discounters reporting strong gains, while department stores had only slim gains. C4.
 
CBS News Cutting 120 Employees
Andrew Heyward, the president of CBS News, has laid off about 7 percent of the network's staff, or 120 workers, in an effort to save $40 million, or about 10 percent of the CBS News budget. Competitors ABC News and NBC News have also reduced their staff, but have not announced by how many. C4.
 
U.S. to Bear Most of I.M.F. Burden
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank wound up their annual meetings saying that the United States will bear most of the burden of helping Asia and the rest of the developing world get out of a recession. A8.
 
Republican Congressional leaders presented the Clinton Administration with a list of lending conditions that they want imposed on the I.M.F. in order for Congress to approve $18 billion in new money for the fund. A8.
 
General Electric Profit Rises 13%
Third-quarter profit rose 13 percent at General Electric, matching expectations. Sales rose 9.8 percent, less than the 15 percent to 20 percent increase predicted. C3.
 
Oil Companies Form Joint Venture
Phillips Petroleum and Ultramar Diamond Shamrock are forming a joint venture called Diamond 66 that will run 10 refineries and more than 12,000 gas stations in 36 states and six Canadian provinces. C4.
 
Mexican Court Approves Interest
The Mexican Supreme Court decided that it was legal for that country's banks to charge interest on interest, a practice that is bread-and-butter basic to banking worldwide. C2.
 
$2.8 Billion Stock Takeover of Jacor
Clear Channel Communications is buying Jacor Communications, the broadcaster for Rush Limbaugh, Dr. Laura Schlessinger and other radio personalities, for $2.8 billion in stock. The combined company would rank third in radio revenues, behind CBS and Chancellor Broadcasting, and second in number of stations. C5.
 
Eight States in Tobacco Talks
The $198 billion national settlement being negotiated by lawyers for the tobacco industry and eight states would allow cigarette makers to absorb part or all of its costs. A14.

HEADLINE: $23 Million Expansion Planned for Staten Island Freight Center

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki announced a $23 million expansion project yesterday for the Howland Hook Marine Terminal, a 187-acre Staten Island freight-handling complex that was reopened two years ago by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The expansion comes amid intense competition between New York and other East Coast ports for commercial shipping. It will create the first rail link to the terminal, which lies along the Arthur Kill on the northwest part of Staten Island across from Elizabeth, N.J. 
 Officials said the rail link, budgeted at $15 million, would sharply increase access to the Howland Hook complex, connecting it to freight trains running through the heavily industrialized chemical manufacturing area of northern New Jersey and beyond.
The rail link, stretching from the complex across Union County, N.J., to a Conrail freight line, would provide the first freight train access to New York City from New Jersey. It appeared to be jeopardized in recent months when the Manager of Union County, Michael J. Lapolla, recommended that his Board of Freeholders withdraw its support of the project, saying its economic benefits would flow almost entirely to New York.
That provoked angry protests from officials in New York City, which has already rebuilt track and refurbished a bridge for the link.
And yesterday, Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said that any objections in Union County had been overridden by the board of the Port Authority. The rights of way for the new track are owned by the State of New Jersey and the Port Authority is granted jurisdiction over New York harbor and its waterfront areas by the Governors of New York and New Jersey.
In addition to the rail link, the terminal will get more than 15,000 new freight-handling containers and a refurbished crane. Officials said the project would be completed by late 2000.
"A little more than two years ago, Howland Hook Marine Terminal was literally dead in the water," said Governor Pataki at a news conference at the terminal, which had been abandoned in 1986 when its only shipping tenant, U.S. Lines, went out of business. The terminal's closing contributed to a steady erosion of shipping business in the New York harbor for the next decade.
Since 1996, when Howland Hook was reopened and began taking on a growing share of port business, the tonnage of goods shipped through the harbor has gradually increased. Port Authority records show that it is now holding steady or gaining ground against other major East Coast ports in Baltimore; Halifax, Nova Scotia; Norfolk, Va., and elsewhere.
"Now we are seeing the fruits of our work," Mr. Pataki said. The expansion project announced yesterday comes in the aftermath of $50 million in investments by the Port Authority to modernize and reopen the Howland Hook terminal.
Robert E. Boyle, executive director of the Port Authority, said the amount of cargo handled in New York harbor would continue to grow rapidly. He estimated that cargo volumes handled at Howland Hook and the two other major container terminals operated by the Port Authority -- the huge Port Newark-Elizabeth complex in New Jersey and the Red Hook Terminal in Brooklyn -- would double in the next 15 years.
But while officials said yesterday that Howland Hook's expansion would contribute considerably to the growth of the Port of New York and New Jersey, other major projects remain.
The largest involve extensive dredging of both the Arthur Kill and the Kill Van Kull, a larger channel that ships must navigate to get to the port's container terminals in Staten Island and New Jersey. Both channels are now 40 feet deep, and must be dredged to at least 45 feet to accommodate a new generation of cargo ships that are expected to dominate the shipping business.
A $670 million project to dredge the Kill Van Kull, with $231 million of the costs paid by the Port Authority, is to begin this fall. Federal financing for the project, which is to cover all costs not paid by the Port Authority, was authorized by Congress this year but must be reauthorized each year if the work is to be completed by its projected deadline in 2003.
Dredging of the Arthur Kill has been delayed, if not prevented, because Congress this year voted down $165 million in Federal financing for that project even though the Port Authority has authorized its contribution of an additional $88.7 million. Port Authority officials said yesterday that they expected a new request for the Federal funds to be made in Congress next year.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Growling, butfor How Long?;
Assessing the Fallout From a Season of Lower Earnings

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Is it time for investors to sober up?
As the reporting season for corporate earnings begins, Wall Street analysts seem to agree that profits will decline a few percentage points in the third quarter, ending an almost seven-year run of intoxicating profit gains. 
 The bigger question is what happens next. Will this be just a brief headache or are earnings going to turn into a real hangover? "It is the great issue for the market now," Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, said.
What's worse, even if earnings growth resumes next year, will that be enough to put the stock market back on track? The fall in semiconductor stocks the last two days, despite indications that the industry is turning around, may mean that even moderate gains in profits won't be enough to satisfy the crowd.
And while the Dow Jones industrial average recovered most of its losses by the end of trading yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index, the market yardstick that measures the performance of many of the fastest-growing and most popular technology stocks, absorbed another sharp blow.
Until recently, investors could almost count on pleasant surprises from companies reporting earnings that consistently exceeded expectations. That hope now seems to be vanishing and many investors are tuning out those strategists who continue to sing even a mildly positive tune.
"We're still looking for up earnings," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "And in almost every conversation I have with clients, they challenge me. 'There is no way earnings will go up,' they say."
The reaction yesterday to a new report from Abby Joseph Cohen, the closely followed market strategist for Goldman, Sachs & Company who has been a longtime bull, showed just how touchy investors are.
In a note to Goldman clients before the stock market opened, Ms. Cohen said that she was lowering her forecast for operating earnings -- which are adjusted to remove the impact of one-time write-offs and other charges -- for the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. That announcement helped send Wall Street sharply lower when the market opened.
Still, her outlook remains quite positive in a climate where pessimism seems to be growing. She predicted that earnings for this year would end up about 5 percent above 1997 results and she forecast another 7 percent gain in 1999. That's down, but only a bit, from her earlier forecast of 8 percent growth for 1998 and 8.9 percent for 1999.
Indeed, as Mr. Wien's and Ms. Cohen's forecasts show, a lot of big names on Wall Street continue to bet that any profit dip in the third quarter will be little more than a hiccup.
While they are not expecting the percentile growth in earnings to roar back to the bullish double-digit pace of the mid-1990's, they are still counting on profits to keep improving. Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, is forecasting 2 percent earnings growth in 1999 even though his firm's economists predict a mild recession next year.
Two forces drove the stock market forward during the incredible bull run that began in 1991. One was rapid earnings growth. The other was the flow of billions of dollars from ordinary investors out of other assets into stocks, powering Wall Street to record highs this summer even as earnings growth was really slowing down.
With the bull market in retreat, strategists are looking for something to spur the market to climb again, to encourage investors to gaze over the valley. A return to steady earnings growth could fit the bill.
But the performance this week of Advanced Micro Devices and other semiconductor stocks shows that even good earnings news may be easily overwhelmed by uncertainty about the current economic outlook.
On Tuesday, Advanced Micro reported that strong sales of its K6-2 computer microprocessor had returned the company, unexpectedly, to profitability in the third quarter. Following better-than-expected earnings from Motorola the day before, it was a signal that the industry, which includes the chip giant Intel, might be turning around.
But Advanced Micro's stock plunged, falling 20.8 percent Wednesday and 11.1 percent yesterday. The Philadelphia semiconductor index, which tracks 16 companies in the industry, dropped 3.4 percent Wednesday and another nine-tenths of 1 percent yesterday.
According to several analysts, the chance for an overall earnings rebound requires several diverse elements to fall into place. The economy must avoid a recession, chip makers must make a comeback next year, energy prices need to stabilize near their current levels and the dollar has to come down to levels that help American exporters sell more abroad.
All that is possible. But the price of oil, which had jumped 27 percent, to $16.14 a barrel from Aug. 12 to the end of September, has dropped back this month to $14.42 a barrel. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, says the prospects for economic growth are worsening. And while the dollar is down sharply against the German mark and the Japanese yen from its highs this summer, it remains relatively strong against the currencies of America's other major trading partners.
Ms. Cohen, Mr. Doerflinger and Mr. Wein are all expecting the economy to stay out of a recession. Mr. Doerfliner is forecasting earnings growth of almost 7 percent next year and Mr. Wien is predicting 2 percent earnings growth.
Ms. Cohen does acknowledge that Asia has still not bottomed out and that Latin America is showing "unexpected weakness."
Mr. Wien said that "the momentum of the economy is still good, consumer confidence is still good and the Fed is easing."
Apart from the overall economy, these strategists argue that the hardest-hit industries, like semiconductors and energy, do not need to return to robust earnings growth but merely stop this year's slide to push 1999 earnings higher.
According to Mr. Doerflinger, earnings from the energy industry plunged 29 percent in the first nine months of this year compared with the period in 1997. "If energy earnings are just flat, that would be an improvement," he said.
The recent dollar decline will also add to the bottom line of a lot of American companies next year if its exchange rates just stay where they are. A lower dollar means that earnings from abroad will increase when they are translated back into cheaper dollars.
But not all strategists share this measured optimism about earnings. Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, and Mitchell J. Held, the firm's chief economist, are predicting a 1.1 percent decline in earnings next year. Mr. Held's forecast is based on a weaker economy, a rally in the dollar, continued poor performance from financial companies and downward pressure on profit margins -- because prices cannot rise much and may even fall.
For investors, this range of forecasts by market strategists may not be all that comforting. But it is clearly more in line with the current outlook and, thus, less likely to lead to the kind of profit disappointments that have sent stocks lower.
The same cannot be said for the earnings forecasts assembled by the hordes of analysts who predict earnings for individual companies in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks. These forecasters, according to First Call, are expecting an 18.1 percent surge in earnings next year.
"I would be happier if they were much lower," Mr. Acuff said. "Then I could say that stock market prices reflect the worst."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Out of Hibernation"
While all major stock market indexes have fallen in recent months, the traditional focus on the most well-known measure --the Dow industrial average -- has obscured the true ferocity of the bear market in the much larger number of stocks included in the Nasdaq composite index, which tracks mostly technology stocks, and the Russell 2000 index of small stocks. HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT;
Excerpts From President's Remarks at Meeting on Budget Matters

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks today before a meeting with his economic team, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Mr. Clinton was asked a question by reporters.
PRESIDENT CLINTON. We are about to start a meeting with the economic and budget team about the unfinished work in the budget that has to be done in the next few days. But before we start, I'd like to make just a very brief comment on today's vote. 
 First of all, I hope that we can now move forward with this process in a way that is fair, that is constitutional and that is timely. The American people have been through a lot on this, and I think that everyone deserves that.
Beyond that, I have nothing to say. It is not in my hands, it is in the hands of Congress and the people of this country. -- ultimately, in the hands of God. There is nothing I can do.
But there are things I can do something about, and the most important thing I can do now is to work in the next few days to reach across party lines to do the work that we have to do here. We have got to pass a budget that protects the surplus until we save Social Security, that keeps the American economy going amid all this economic turmoil in the world, that protects instead of damages the environment and that gives the kind of priority to our elementary and secondary education that it so clearly needs. Those are my priorities. I think those are the priorities of the American people. It will require us to put progress ahead of partisanship, but it clearly will strengthen our country. And that's what we're going to work on, and I hope we can do it.
Q. Sir, you could speed the pace of this up if you were to volunteer to testify and decide whether or not now you would challenge Monica Lewinsky's account of your relationship. Have you made any decisions on that front?
A. Let me say again. On that, I will do what I can to help to insure this is constitutional, fair and timely. Ultimately, it is in the hands of Congress. I don't think it's appropriate to comment further today.
Q. Mr. President, have you talked to other world leaders today? And how are you feeling personally about the vote?
A. I have ----. Well, today I spoke with President Chirac of France. And I am meeting tomorrow with the man who will be the next German Chancellor, Mr. Schroder. We talked about Kosovo. And I have been working, as you know, all week long with people from all over the world on the international financial crisis. Personally, I am, I am fine. I have, I have surrendered this. This is beyond my control. I have to work on what I can do.
What I can do is to do my job for the American people. I trust the American people; they almost always get it right, and have for 220 years. And I'm working in a way that I hope will restore their trust in me by working for the things that our country needs. These -- these things we're going to discuss at this budget meeting, that's what I can have some impact on, and that's what I intend to do.

HEADLINE: Study Says Emissions Cut Will Raise Fuel Costs

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Energy Department's official forecasting arm has produced an extraordinarily pessimistic forecast of steeply rising energy prices if the United States fights global warming by clamping down on emissions of heat-trapping gases that come from burning fossil fuels.
Under various outcomes, the forecasting arm, the Energy Information Administration, projected gasoline prices would rise to $1.39 to $1.91 a gallon, and electricity prices would rise 20 percent to 86 percent by 2010. Natural gas prices would rise significantly, and coal prices would soar, the forecast said. 
 Under an international agreement negotiated last year in Kyoto, Japan, the United States would have to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases significantly in 10 to 15 years. But the treaty is in trouble in Congress, where opponents often say it would wreck the economy.
The Energy Department's forecast is sharply at odds with the Clinton Administration's previous assertions that the United States can meet the targets set by the treaty without significant economic disruption. The forecast is to be presented on Friday at a Congressional hearing.
The new study plays directly into the hands of treaty opponents, but those who favor the treaty said it is deeply flawed.
Energy conservation advocates said the forecast, produced using the Energy Information Administration's standard economic models, had relied on absurd assumptions and improper analysis to reach ridiculous conclusions.
"This is one of the most flawed, biased, intellectually dishonest analyses ever produced by an supposedly unbiased analytical organization," said Joseph J. Romm, a former Assistant Energy Secretary. Mr. Romm is an expert on energy technologies like solar power and conservation that would help control greenhouse gas emissions.
He and other critics said the study discounted many of the policies, like tax incentives and research subsidies, that the Administration had proposed for enforcing the treaty if the Senate approved it. They said it used computer models that were unreliable for long-term forecasting.
They said it did not account for the lower costs that would result from a key feature of the Administration's climate change policy: international emissions trading, which would allow the United States to meet the treaty's targets largely by paying other countries to reduce their output of greenhouse gases.
Critics also said the forecast assumed that businesses would be slow to adopt new energy technologies although, under the forecast's own projections, the costs of not acting would be high.
Many such computer models have been used for projecting the costs of the Kyoto agreement protocol on climate change. Because so much depends on the assumptions of the models, their predictions may not be reliable. And critics noted that the Energy Department had a long track record of making bad predictions about long-range trends in energy prices and pollution control costs.
Even so, the new study is certain to fuel criticism of the treaty. The study is scheduled to be presented on Friday at a hearing of the House Science Committee, whose chairman, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican, is a leading critic of the treaty.
The study's projections of the costs of controlling the emissions of greenhouse gases are significantly greater than the predictions of several similar studies, even the gloomy forecasts paid for by industry opponents of the treaty that predicted extraordinary costs.
And it predicts that the costs would be much higher than predicted by Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in a study released in July.
Eileen Claussen, a former senior State Department official who helped negotiate the Kyoto agreement, said that just as Dr. Yellen's analysis was wildly optimistic, this one was wildly pessimistic.
"Both of these forecasts are totally unrealistic," Ms. Claussen said. "It is the most bizarre thing. They haven't put out a single bit of analytical work on the costs that has any credibility at all."
Ms. Claussen now directs the Pew Center on Climate Change, which has drawn together major corporations pledging early actions to cut their emissions of greenhouse gases.
Mr. Romm, who now consults with businesses on how to cut greenhouse gas emissions, criticized the report's assertions that emerging technologies like solar power and fuel cells would gain little over 20 years although costs of traditional fuels were likely to rise.
He ridiculed the study's finding that even with coal prices soaring, power plants would not install any measurable cogeneration equipment, which uses waste heat to generate extra electricity from coal.
Although the new study predicts slowing economic growth as a result of higher energy costs, over the long run this amounts to just tens of billions of dollars in an economy that grows to more than $10 trillion.

HEADLINE: THE TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT;
Routine Business, but No Routine Day

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton maintained an ordinary schedule and an air of absorption today in routine public business as the House approved an impeachment investigation that may shorten his term in office and will certainly affect his place in history.
Mr. Clinton announced measures to protect Medicare recipients dropped from their health plans, warned of a looming refugee catastrophe in Kosovo, lunched with Vice President Gore, signed a bill to publish records of Nazi war criminals and met with his economic advisers on the 1999 budget. 
 In his only remarks on the impeachment vote, Mr. Clinton told reporters in a brief picture-taking session late this afternoon that his future "is not in my hands."
"Ultimately it is in the hands of the Congress," Mr. Clinton said. "I don't think it's appropriate to comment further today."
This morning, as the House was engaged in its wrenching debate over the impeachment inquiry, Mr. Clinton was before a friendly audience in the Roosevelt Room of the White House discussing Medicare and health maintenance organizations.
As he completed his remarks, reporters tried to shout questions about the impeachment debate and the hearings that are likely to begin shortly after the Nov. 3 election.
Their entreaties were drowned out by applause from a carefully selected audience of Democratic lawmakers, Administration officials and senior citizens.
The end of the official transcript of the event reads:
"Mr. President, will you voluntarily testify?"
(No response as the President leaves the Roosevelt Room.)
The President's spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said Mr. Clinton had not watched any of the House debate on the impeachment inquiry, unless he caught glimpses of it on one of the dozens of television sets in the West Wing tuned to the proceedings.
"I don't believe he's watched any of it, unless he's watched it in passing, walking through a hallway," Mr. Lockhart said. "He is surely interested in the outcome; but he's got a job to do here and that's what he's focused on."
Mr. Lockhart added: "We don't have the luxury of being distracted or being anyplace else. We have the people's business to do here, and in fact, that's what's happening over the next few days."
A senior White House official said the only suspense about today's impeachment vote was the number of Democrats who would vote for the Republican impeachment resolution, and even that number was pretty well known on Wednesday night.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, told the White House on the eve of the vote that he expected about 30 Democrats, some in tight re-election races, to defect and join the Republicans. Thirty-one Democrats voted for the Republican resolution.
The President's apparent nonchalance today was the result of this early intelligence, the White House official said. He was not terribly concerned about the vote because he knew how it would turn out.
"This thing got built up bigger than it needed or should have been," the official said. "We're talking about a process that we kind of knew the outcome of for a long time."
Mr. Lockhart said throughout his regular briefing this afternoon that the President remained focused on important matters of state -- the Federal budget, the crisis in Kosovo, the future of Social Security -- a refrain that has left White House spokesmen hoarse.
Mr. Lockhart was asked whether there would ever come a time when the President would shift his focus from these matters to his personal survival. "I don't know how to answer that," he replied.

HEADLINE: CBS News Division Cuts About 7% of WorkForce

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
As part of a broader corporate cost-cutting effort at CBS Inc., the network's news division yesterday laid off about 7 percent of its staff, but closed no bureaus and dismissed no correspondents.
The savings to the company will amount to close to $40 million, or about 10 percent of the CBS News budget, according to people familiar with the budget who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
 CBS News issued pink slips to about 120 people, most of them in administrative or support positions, from a staff of about 1,600. Executives took pains to describe the reductions as a reorganization rather than across-the-board cutbacks. Several producers and correspondents said that this appeared to be true.
Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News, had been researching ways to save money since midsummer, under a directive from CBS corporate executives to all division heads to move CBS toward profitability. All the networks except NBC lost money last year, and are expected to do so again this year, largely as a result of higher prices they have had to pay for entertainment shows and for football games.
ABC News and NBC News have laid off some people, too, but have not announced how many.
"We are consolidating management functions in our hubs in New York, Washington, Los Angeles, London and Tokyo," Mr. Heyward wrote in a memorandum to the news division yesterday. "This means fewer people in Dallas, Miami, Tel Aviv and Moscow, but our core news gathering strength in those places remains intact and is expected to increase elsewhere as this system evolves."
The new system, as Mr. Heyward described it in an interview, relies upon advanced satellite, cell phone and computer technology to link correspondents and producers in the field to supervisors in the hub cities mentioned in the memorandum.
Supervisors in the hub cities will coordinate assignments. Most reports will be transmitted to those cities and edited there, as well, rather than by editors sent, with equipment, to locations where a news event is happening.
The smaller CBS News bureaus, in Dallas or Miami, for example, will lose management staff -- such as a bureau chief, deputy bureau chief and clerical staff. Instead, the bureau will have at least one three-member "coverage team," consisting of a correspondent, camera person and producer.
In addition, many producers in the larger bureaus such as Washington (whose staff was virtually untouched) will now be expected to work for any CBS News program, as the news cycle requires, rather than to work for only one program, such as "The CBS Evening News" or "CBS This Morning," as had been done in the past.
Also, separate assignment desks for the Northeast United States, the national desk and the foreign desk will be consolidated into one assignment desk, responsible for dealing with all requests for reports or elements for reports from CBS news programs.
Al Ortiz, the executive producer of "The CBS Evening News," said, "It puts a greater burden on producers of stories to plan a bit more, since you won't be in the edit room to look over every decision."
Similarly, he said, those in the field "have to use their laptops -- send scripts faster and provide more detailed instruction about how to organize or cut a story" to colleagues assembling stories in the hub-city operation.
About six weeks ago CBS Inc. said it would cut between 200 and 300 jobs by the end of 1998, including those in the news division that were cut yesterday. No layoffs in other divisions were made yesterday.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1269 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
A Volatile Day Turns Wall St. To Uneasy St.

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Over the last six weeks, investors have held onto the hope that the United States might be able to avoid the full effect of the economic downturn that has struck so many far-flung parts of the world. And while the financial markets remain in turmoil, many investors thought that the prices of stocks, bonds and other financial assets had largely taken the bad news into account.
Those illusions cracked yesterday as the value of the dollar fell further, the bond market dropped and the prices of hundreds of stocks plunged even as the main stock market gauges showed minimal losses. One after another, the pilings that have lent a measure of stability to the markets over the last several weeks have been swept away. Page C1. 
 On the surface, things might not look so bad: the Dow Jones industrial average, the market bellwether, finished the day a mere 9.78 points lower, at 7,731.91. But beneath that relatively calm result was a day of turmoil during which the Dow fell as much as 274 points before climbing back in the last two hours of trading.
Even greater damage occurred in the Nasdaq composite index, which measures the performance of many of the fastest-growing technology companies. The index dropped 43.49 points, or nearly 3 percent, to 1,419.12 -- its lowest closing price in 16 months. Over the last two weeks alone, the Nasdaq index has fallen nearly 20 percent -- a spectacular implosion in such a short time.
That greater upheaval reflects a significant shift in the mood of many investors on Wall Street and around the globe. Gone are the expectations, analysts said, that the United States can avoid the economic slowdown that has already gripped much of the world. While many economists on Wall Street still call a recession unlikely, the fact that they are including its potential in their forecasts means that most bets of continued unbridled expansion are off.
Also washing away are some of the last remaining expectations of brisk growth in corporate profits, of companies using much of their excess cash to buy back their own shares, and of individual investors riding to the rescue to buy more stocks each time the market dips.
"There's more confusion in the marketplace now than I've ever seen in my career," said Henry Herrmann, president and chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed Financial, a mutual fund company based in Overland Park, Kan.
"The level of confusion has just got the vast majority of portfolio managers cross-eyed," said Mr. Herrmann, who has worked in the investment business since 1963.
Chief among the confusing situations is the "flight to quality" that has taken place among stock and bond investors. The shift has left blue-chip stocks and United States Treasury bonds performing relatively well while every other category of assets has been hammered.
The latest victims have been the highly visible Nasdaq stocks, posting steep drops stemming in large part from heavy selling by foreign investors. Those investors have been some of the biggest buyers of American stocks over the last two years as the value of the dollar appreciated.
Now, however, with the dollar reversing its course and becoming cheaper in relation to the yen, the mark and other foreign currencies, overseas investors are finding that not only are their American stocks worth less, but they also get less of their home currency for each dollar when they convert their investments.
In addition, those Americans who have come to expect a United States recession have begun to measure its possible effect on technology companies. Those manufacturers that sell equipment to businesses in America and around the world are more likely to be hurt by an economic slowdown than are the large consumer product companies that make up much of the Dow industrial index.
"If there is a slowdown in the purchase of capital goods by companies, the technology companies will be affected more dramatically than a lot of the blue chips," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at the John Hancock funds. "At the same time, people will still be eating and drinking and going to the movies."
Several specific events also led traders to take a decidedly dimmer view of things yesterday. First, the Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-point, to 7.25 percent. But much as with the quarter-point cut in rates by the Federal Reserve last week, equity traders and analysts judged the move to be too little to aid slowing economies around the world, particularly in Europe. Financial markets in Europe fell sharply, with the major stock indexes down 2.7 percent in Britain and 5 percent in Germany.
Long-term interest rates generally rose yesterday, with the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond climbing to just below 5 percent, up from 4.72 percent on Monday. In addition, short-term rates have fallen in the days since the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark rate, and the level of short-term rates generally indicates that bond traders expect further cuts by the Federal Reserve.
Two influential American analysts adjusted their outlooks yesterday, further adding to the gloom. Abby Joseph Cohen, the investment analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company who has been the market's most voluble cheerleader over the last three years, made comments about corporate earnings growth that to many listeners had a slightly negative tone.
If Ms. Cohen did not throw in the towel on her relentlessly optimistic forecast, she at least threw in a washcloth, cutting her estimates of 1998 and 1999 earnings for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, implying that the current economic squeeze will extend well into next year.
And Ralph J. Acampora, who tracks statistical market measures at Prudential Securities, lowered his estimate of how low the Dow might fall. It was Mr. Acampora's prediction of a bear market that caused a stampede out of stocks in early August, when the Dow industrials were still above 8,700. Yesterday, he said he thought the Dow would go as low as 6,700, well below his previous floor of 7,400. To reach 6,700, the Dow would have to fall more than 13 percent from yesterday's close.
Also, Greg Smith, Prudential's chief investment strategist, recommended that aggressive investors increase cash holdings to 20 percent of assets from 5 percent. Most of that cash, he said, should be raised by lowering bond investments to 25 percent of a portfolio from 35 percent, with stock investments falling to 55 percent from 60 percent.
Two other stabilizing factors also appear to be gone from beneath the relatively calm surface of the stock market. Mutual fund investors, who have been a source of stability for stocks in the last four years, demonstrated in August -- the last time the market fell sharply -- that they would withdraw money from funds when performance turned down.
Now, with small stocks continuing a sharp fall, analysts say that funds specializing in shares of small companies are experiencing growing levels of investor withdrawals.
Also, traders speak of fears that one more remaining source of liquidity for the stock market is drying up: corporate stock repurchases. With credit becoming harder to come by, corporations that have been buying back shares to finance option packages and for other uses might be less likely to spend any spare cash they have, at least over the short run.
That leaves many traders fearful that the market will get more choppy, with big swings during the day, like yesterday's, becoming even more common. Investors, they say, should be ready for more rough seas.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "AT A GLANCE: Financial Jitters: A Summary"
 
MARKETS GYRATE. Stocks tumbled in nearly every market, reflecting growing investor nervousness about a possible global recession. The selling dragged the Dow Jones industrial average nearly 300 points lower before it recovered and ended little changed in some of the heaviest trading ever. But the Nasdaq market, home to many of America's growth stocks, skidded again and is now at its lowest level in 16 months. Long-term bond yields, which had fallen to 31-year lows last week, shot up. The dollar, which tumbled more than 8 percent on Wednesday, skidded again in Europe before it rebounded to close slightly lower against the yen.
 
HOPE FOR I.M.F. FUNDING. Republican leaders in Congress and the Clinton Administration moved toward an agreement that would provide $18 billion in new United States money for the International Monetary Fund, considered an important step in containing the financial crisis.
 
EUROPE GROWS MORE NERVOUS. Britain's central bank cut interest rates on concern about the turmoil's effect on British businesses, the first such cut in more than two years. But the move did nothing to stop the slide in British stocks. Across the English Channel, European Union politicians openly worried about keeping interest rates relatively high, fearing that would hurt Europe's economy, the one area of the world where growth has been rising.

HEADLINE: Deals Near on Manhattan Sites for 3 Stock Markets

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Working against deadlines imposed by New York's financial markets, city and state officials are scrambling to complete a series of complex deals in the coming weeks that would create new headquarters for the New York, American and Nasdaq Stock Exchanges in Manhattan.
Taken together, the deals could cost the city and state more than $700 million, mainly in cash. 
 The search for new homes for the financial industry has become a high-stakes real estate version of musical chairs, as the exchanges, which are also being wooed by New Jersey, try to extract huge subsidy packages and New York developers maneuver to get a lucrative piece of the business.
To keep the New York Stock Exchange downtown, officials are optimistic that they can cobble together an agreement to buy five parcels, diagonally across Broad Street from the New York Stock Exchange, where a new trading floor and a billion-dollar headquarters would be built. The outline of a deal must be in place in time for the Nov. 4 board meeting of the exchange, which has said it would consider a move to Battery Park City or New Jersey if the city is unable to secure a location in the financial district.
At the same time, city and state officials are trying to forge an agreement this week with the National Association of Securities Dealers, which owns Nasdaq and is acquiring the American Stock Exchange, for a new headquarters for those exchanges on an empty lot in TriBeCa, in Battery Park City or at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. The N.A.S.D., which met yesterday in New York, is also considering two waterfront projects in Jersey City.
"It's been a game of musical chairs," said Mary Ann Tighe, executive managing director of the Insignia/Edward S. Gordon real estate company, "but now it looks like everybody is going to find a place to sit down."
The exchanges are bargaining for a lot more than cuts in sales taxes or property taxes. The markets, particularly the New York Stock Exchange, are also pushing the state and the city to provide cash to offset the cost of constructing a modern trading operation. The money would be diverted from state and city capital budgets.
To clinch the deals, the city and state may have to provide $700 million in cash, tax breaks and low-cost electricity, an immense sum but less than half the estimated cost to taxpayers of the proposed baseball stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets, taken together.
Officials contend that the city cannot afford to lose the New York Stock Exchange, and that a deal with Nasdaq and the American Exchange would involve a coup for New York: moving the N.A.S.D. headquarters and several hundred employees from Washington to Manhattan.
Fearing the flight of the financial industry in New York and with New Jersey trying to lure the exchanges,during the last 15 years city and state officials have granted nearly a billion dollars in tax breaks and other incentives to investment banks and other financial institutions. The financial industry accounts for only 5 percent of the jobs in New York, but tax revenues linked to the industry generated most of the city's $2.1 billion budget surplus last year.
Although Jersey City officials are still talking to the exchanges, New York officials expect to strike a deal with the New York, American and Nasdaq exchanges in the coming weeks, say people involved on all sides of the negotiations, all of whom would speak only on the condition of anonymity. But the situation is fluid, they say, and anything can happen.
"I think it's going to get done," said one person involved in the talks. "But it's going to be big numbers on both of them."
Officials at the New York Stock Exchange believe that there are still obstacles to clinching the deal, says one person working for the exchange who is involved in the negotiations.
Richard Grasso, chairman of the exchange, has said only that he favors building at Battery Park City.
The financial exchanges have been casting about Manhattan, and occasionally threatening to move to New Jersey, for nearly 30 years. The New York Stock Exchange considered moving to a site on the East River from its historic home on Wall Street in the early 1970's, and the American Stock Exchange nearly moved to Battery Park City in the 1980's. In 1991, both the American and New York exchanges worked on a proposal to build a billion-dollar combined exchange in lower Manhattan, but the deal fizzled in the recession.
But the effort to retain the stock exchanges may undermine efforts on another front: finding homes for commodity exchanges. The TriBeCa site being considered for the headquarters of the N.A.S.D. was originally earmarked as a new home for the Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. Not only that, state officials say that a $98.5 million incentive package for those commodity exchanges, collectively known as the Board of Trade, expired last month.
As a result, the Board of Trade is negotiating to extend its current lease at 4 World Trade Center. Real estate experts say the board is also trying to preserve a claim on the old $98.5 million subsidy package.
While the city wants the N.A.S.D. to move its headquarters, along with Nasdaq and the American exchange, to the TriBeCa site, that move may not be a sure bet. Frank Zarb, N.A.S.D. chairman, has also talked to the developer Douglas Durst about building a new headquarters on 42d Street, near Times Square, that would give the exchanges the prominent location Mr. Zarb wants.
Not only that, Mr. Zarb and his real estate advisers, Cushman & Wakefield, have also talked to John Zuccotti, chairman of World Financial Properties, about building on a vacant parcel at the northern end of Battery Park City.
The only problem is that the Battery Park City site is the backup location for the New York Stock Exchange if the city fails to buy the properties on Broad Street. While the Battery Park City Authority maintains that Mr. Zuccotti has no rights to the parcel, Mr. Zuccotti and World Financial Properties say that they have veto rights over any development at the site by virtue of their having built the four office towers known as World Financial Center.
"They don't have any claim of substance" to the site, said James Gill, chairman of the Battery Park City Authority. "He may want to build there himself. But he's not in a position to block us from having the New York Stock Exchange or anyone else from coming."

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Broad Statewide Support for Pataki's Re-election

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA with MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
After four years as Governor, George E. Pataki has forged a strikingly broad appeal, propelling him to a 2-to-1 lead for re-election over his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, who has barely registered in voters' minds, a statewide New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
Mr. Pataki, the poll also shows, has thoroughly overcome the view of him, once widely held, as an uncaring, ideological conservative out of step with the state, and the stigma of his having risen to power as the protege of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, whose integrity many voters still seriously question. The Governor, who won office as the candidate of conservatives upstate and on Long Island, now enjoys robust support across regional and party boundaries. 
 A month before the Nov. 3 election, 50 percent of voters surveyed favored Mr. Pataki, a Republican, against 22 percent for Mr. Vallone and 6 percent each for B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the Liberal Party nominee. Among likely voters, the Governor's lead was 54 percent to 24 percent for Mr. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker.
The race for attorney general is in a dead heat. The Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, has 38 percent to the 37 percent for the Democratic candidate, Eliot G. Spitzer. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, has a wide lead over his Republican challenger, Bruce Blakeman, 41 percent to 19 percent. One-third of voters remain undecided.
The poll, based on interviews conducted Oct. 1 to Oct. 6 with 1,066 registered voters, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
So far, Mr. Vallone has been utterly unable to galvanize support, even among Democrats and New York City residents. Just a month before the election, a large number of voters polled simply did not know enough to express any opinion about him, good or bad, though he has been a leading figure in city politics for more than a decade. And the support Mr. Vallone has is much weaker than Mr. Pataki's.
Even with such gloomy news, Mr. Vallone can take some solace in that 35 percent of voters said they might change their minds, and that even seemingly runaway races tend to tighten by Election Day.
One of the few bright spots for Mr. Vallone was the finding that many voters are not yet paying much attention to this race, suggesting that some bold stroke, however unlikely, might galvanize their interest and tip the balance.
Another was the continuing high popularity of President Clinton in New York: despite his troubles, 73 percent of registered voters approve of his job performance. In recent days, Mr. Vallone has made an avid defense of Mr. Clinton a centerpiece of his campaign, making him one of the few candidates for high office anywhere in the country to try to gain by embracing the President.
But Mr. Vallone has little money left for that or any other message. His campaign treasury reported having less than $250,000 last week, compared with more than $9 million for Mr. Pataki.
The poll suggests the possibility of a landslide for Mr. Pataki, which he and his aides hope might propel him into contention for national office in 2000. They are acutely aware that a lopsided victory in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 3 to 2, or carrying New York City, would raise Mr. Pataki's stature within the national Republican Party. Only 1 in 5 New Yorkers said they would like to see him run for President or Vice President, however.
In the city, usually the safest of havens for Democrats, the Governor is running virtually even with his challenger, at 36 percent to 39 percent for Mr. Vallone. Four years ago, he got just 27 percent of the city vote against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
In the downstate suburbs, which have been the swing vote in recent elections, Mr. Pataki holds a 5-to-2 lead. And upstate, the core of his support, he outpolls the Democrat by 5 to 1. Upstate, Mr. Golisano runs even with Mr. Vallone, at 11 percent apiece, while Ms. McCaughey Ross has 4 percent.
The attorney general's race falls along more traditional regional lines that shape statewide races in New York. Mr. Vacco holds a 2-to-1 lead upstate, he and Mr. Spitzer are roughly even in the suburbs, and Mr. Spitzer has a 3-to-1 lead in New York City.
Mr. McCall, the first black official elected statewide, is comfortably ahead of Mr. Blakeman, the leader of the Nassau County Legislature, over all in the comptroller's race, and has a commanding lead in New York City. But a third of the voters said they had not decided whom they would vote for.
In 1994, Mr. Pataki, a State Senator, ran as the anti-Cuomo, revealing little about himself other than his intention to cut taxes and enact the death penalty, and relying on voters' disaffection with Mr. Cuomo after 12 years.
Even as he was winning the race for govrnor, many people had little impression of the Republican, or a negative one. His image suffered from his close association with Mr. D'Amato, who had plucked him out of obscurity to be the Republican candidate.
In his first year in office -- and, to a lesser degree, his second -- Mr. Pataki pushed through unpopular budget cuts in areas like health care, education and mass transit. Unions and Democrats waged an intense public-relations campaign against him, including broadcast advertisements likening him to Speaker Newt Gingrich.
But since then, Mr. Pataki has done a remarkable job of washing away those impressions. He has replaced them with a warmer image of himself, built on the 1996 environmental bond act, tax cuts, large increases in state spending in the last two years and a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign this year that has portrayed him as likable, nonpartisan and trustworthy.
The poll found that nearly as many New Yorkers now judge Mr. Pataki to be moderate as consider him conservative, and 1 in 8 actually regards him as liberal.
In October 1994, two weeks before he was elected, just 18 percent of registered voters had a favorable impression of Mr. Pataki. In April 1995, three months after he took office, 27 percent did.
But in this most recent poll, 46 percent viewed him favorably and, perhaps more striking, just 18 percent viewed him unfavorably. Sixty-three percent of registered voters said they approved of Mr. Pataki's performance as Governor, well above the 50 percent mark that usually spells job security for incumbents.
He even trumps Mr. Vallone on a polling question on which Democrats nearly always prevail. Sixty-one percent of voters said Mr. Pataki "cares about the needs and problems of people" like them, up from 40 percent in April 1995, compared with 37 percent who said Mr. Vallone cares about them.
Mr. Vallone's troubles are reflected by Mary Hossman, 60, of Woodside, Queens, one of the people surveyed. She has friends in common with Mr. Vallone and praises the work he has done in city government. A Democrat, she plans to vote for her party's nominee for the United States Senate, Representative Charles E. Schumer, in his bid to unseat Mr. D'Amato.
But she also intends to vote for Mr. Pataki. "Originally I was voting for him because of the death penalty," she said in a follow-up interview. "That made me take interest in him in 1994. Then I just think he did a really good job. The economy is better and the general quality of life is better."
The challengers in the gubernatorial race point to evidence that beyond Wall Street, the state's economy lags well behind the national boom, and complain that Mr. Pataki has somehow fooled people into believing that New York is doing better than it is.
The poll suggest that New Yorkers know their state's problems, but do not blame the Governor. While two-thirds of New Yorkers described the state's economy at "fairly good," just 9 percent rated the it as "very good." Twenty-two percent of New Yorkers judged the state's economy as "fairly bad" or "very bad." That compared with a Times/CBS News national poll taken in August that showed 61 percent of Americans rate the national economy as "fairly good," 25 percent said it was "very good" and 12 percent said it was fairly or very bad.
Mr. Pataki's experience mirrors that of Mr. Cuomo, who was first elected Governor in 1982 and won re-election in a landslide in 1986. Each man was first elected in a tight contest that reflected stark regional divisions, took office in the aftermath of a recession, and then benefited from a strong economy and greatly broadened his base of support in his first terms.
Throughout this campaign, Mr. Vallone has been hamstrung by being relatively unknown outside the city, and he has lacked the campaign treasury to spread his message the way the Governor has done. What broadcast advertising he has done has been mostly drowned out by the far larger campaigns of Mr. Pataki and the two contestants for the Senate, Senator D'Amato and Representative Schumer.
After a year of active campaigning, Mr. Vallone is so little known that three-quarters of voters have no overall opinion of him, and nearly half could not say whether he had the honesty to be Governor, or if he cared about people like them.
Only 1 in 4 Vallone supporters said they favored him strongly, while more than half the Pataki supporters were strongly in favor of their candidate. And the poll provides evidence of a widespread Democratic defection; for now, fewer than half of Democratic voters said they intended to vote for Mr. Vallone.
