HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
JAPAN PARLIAMENT PASSES RELIEF BILL FOR AILING BANKS

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Japan's Parliament approved landmark banking legislation today that will allow the Government to nationalize failing banks, and political parties announced that they had reached a new accord to provide several hundred billion dollars in new money to try to revive the banking system and set the country on a path toward economic health.
The accord on providing money, reached between Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party and most of the opposition forces, could lead to the injection of huge amounts of public money -- more than $400 billion, or four times the amount proposed a week ago -- into the nation's banks. The Liberal Democrats hope that the political alliance holds long enough for them to win passage in the Parliament for the new accord by Friday, when the current session ends. 
 The possibility of a way out of the financial crisis sent stocks surging today, with shares of the nation's banks jumping an average of 8 percent. The Nikkei index of 225 shares rose 5.24 percent, to 13,555.01, in a big comeback after last week's plunge. United States markets also rose on optimism about a solution to Japan's financial problems. Page C1.
 At midday on Tuesday, the Nikkei was down 30.44 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 13,524.57.
"They are like the wheels on both sides of a car," the Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, said at a news conference, referring to the two pieces of legislation. "When both of them pass the Parliament, it will mean that we can send out a clear and strong message to the world that a global depression will absolutely not begin in Japan."
The law enacted by Parliament today allows the Government for the first time to deal with large, failing banks by nationalizing them, liquidating them or transforming them into publicly owned "bridge banks," which take over the good loans and good borrowers and try to collect on the bad loans. It would establish a public institution to resell the good assets and deal with the bad ones in a process also used by the American Resolution Trust Corporation, which helped clean up the savings-and-loan crisis in the 1990's.
The accord announced tonight, if enacted and carried out, would amount to a bold attempt to revive lending by cash-strapped banks and thus bolster a recovery.
With Japan's economy in its deepest recession since World War II, the recent wild gyrations in the stock market and the sudden and sharp surge in the yen against the dollar, politicians have become a bit jittery that the financial crisis both here and abroad could worsen and that the economy could sink even further.
In Washington, Clinton Administration officials said they were encouraged by the new legislation, but were still waiting for the Japanese Government to carry out the steps and deal forcefully with its economic problems. The United States has grown increasingly impatient with Japan for failing to clean up its banking system and revive its economy, and while the new legislation and today's accord move toward those goals, it is unclear how successfully Japan can carry out these steps.
Other analysts were also skeptical, partly because Japan has announced agreements in the past, only to have them not live up to promises. One key criticism has been the worry that Japan's major banks will not apply for an injection of taxpayers' money, particularly if it means they will be punished through controls on management or reductions in shareholder capital.
The Democratic Party, the main opposition to the new accord, has demanded that the Government force the banks to take public money. Politicians disclosed few details of the agreement, but after the Democratic Party protested, the Liberal Democrats decided to bolster the amount of the bailout.
For many, though, Japan is at a critical juncture.
"If Japan is able to adjust, it can become a locomotive to pull Asia out of its troubles," said Kenneth Courtis, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group Asia Pacific, at a conference today in Singapore. "Otherwise, it could become a Titanic that pulls the rest of Asia under."
The new accord, a second set of bills to revive the banking system, is intended to provide banks with sorely needed new capital so that they can lend to corporations throughout Japan. Last week, politicians had proposed a bailout of 10 trillion yen, or nearly $90 billion. Though no amounts were specified tonight, politicians said the accord could provide between $435 billion and $585 billion, or about 10 percent of annual economic output. The money, however, is not expected to be spent all in one year. International banks could receive taxpayers' money if they agreed to absorb another failing institution, if there was a severe credit contraction or if more capital was needed in a merger.
Masaru Hayami, the governor of the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, warned officials in Washington recently that all the banks were short of capital and that the resulting credit squeeze had helped stifle economic recovery. With a weak capital base, large international Japanese banks have been trimming their lending to meet capital requirements set by the Bank for International Settlements. Banks with only domestic business must conform to Government rules.
The international banks say they currently meet those standards, but just as troublesome is the level of equity capital -- a narrower measure of capital -- that could absorb real losses arising from writing off unrecoverable loans. The amount of the nation's bad debt could be anywhere from $670 billion to $1 trillion.
In addition, the tumbling stock market, which is flirting with 13-year lows, hurts the level of capital at the banks. Recent banking proposals by politicians highlight just how low the levels of capital could tumble at the banks if their bad loans were dealt with right away.
According to the guidelines in one proposal, the core amount of equity capital at the banks could fall by nearly half if the top 19 banks disposed of problem loans in line with internal findings of the Bank of Japan. The Democratic Party and others have demanded that the banks address these problem loans by setting aside a portion of profits to absorb losses in the expectation that one-fifth of these loans go bad, a proportion based on findings by the Bank of Japan.
The difficulty, however, is that most banks contend that these loans are currently in fine shape, and they have created virtually no cushion of profits for them.
The precarious level of capital is why many analysts are calling on the politicians to put the money in first and then tackle the rebuilding of the sticky principles that govern the system. For years, analysts and economists here and abroad have been demanding greater financial disclosure, tougher accounting standards and more market-oriented rules in the financial system.
"I am for disclosure," said Ryuji Konishi, a former bank executive who now teaches economics at Tokyo University. "But this is not a time of peace."
Chikara Sakaguchi, a member of Parliament and a leader in the New Peace Party, has said that his party supports the Liberal Democrats' bill. Yoshio Suzuki, a senior member in the Liberal Party, which was instrumental in tonight's agreement, said that the Liberal Party would also vote to pass the bill and that the bill was assured passage.
"We have finally succeeded in establishing a scheme which is essential to overcome the present financial crisis," he said.
Not everyone is happy with the bills, though. Some senior bankers say that Japan may be passing up the chance to make the financial system and its institutions much more competitive through the kind of change that can emerge only from a crisis.
In the words of one Japanese banker, Japan needs "the hands of the devil and the heart of a Buddha," so that painful revamping may be done now to bring long-term benefits.
Others say that the Liberal Democrats' version is barely different from the plan that is being replaced because of opposition from the Democratic Party. Under that plan, a bailout of $260 billion, Japan's banks received public money worth about 1.8 trillion yen, or $15.7 billion, in March, but the plan failed to inspire worldwide confidence in the banking system.
"I'm very pessimistic," said Ka tsuya Okada, a Parliamentary member for the Democratic Party, the main opposition whose views are being edged out of the second set of legislation.
"The philosophy and the method are not so clear yet. It seems as though the Government is forcing the vote."

HEADLINE: Russia Sees NATO Raids as Imperiling Cooperation With West

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Russia mounted a last-ditch campaign today to avert NATO air strikes against Yugoslavia, warning that such strikes could bring an end to cooperation with the Western alliance.
The intensity of Russia's diplomacy reflected the ascension of Yevgeny M. Primakov, the Foreign Minister turned Prime Minister, who has often cast Moscow as a wounded great power in an open-ended struggle with the West. 
 As Foreign Minister, Mr. Primakov had no higher goal than to circumscribe NATO's influence and contest American dominance. He repeatedly described the Balkans as historically an area of Russian influence.
Today Russia orchestrated a full-court press. First Mr. Primakov told Italy's Acting Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, that NATO strikes would be a "tragic mistake" that threatened cooperation between Moscow and NATO.
Then Russia underscored its unhappiness by recalling its representatives to NATO headquarters. A Russian general even engaged in a bit of saber-rattling by threatening to ship arms to Serbia.
In reality, Russia's leverage is somewhat limited.
Russian cooperation with NATO had never amounted to very much. Its representatives at NATO headquarters are primarily interested in fighting old wars over NATO expansion, not finding new ways to work together.
The sole exception has been the deployment of Russian peacekeeping troops in Bosnia, an arrangement that is widely regarded as successful but not indispensable.
Russia's Parliament could vote down the second strategic arms reduction treaty, and obtaining Russia's approval of the accord is a high American priority.
But the fate of the treaty is already in doubt in the Communist-dominated Parliament. And Mr. Primakov has publicly said approving it is in Russia's interest, as its missiles are getting old anyway.
NATO has never been popular with the Russian public. But with the economy in a state of near collapse, Western intervention in the Balkans appeared to be primarily an obsession of the political establishment.
Still, Mr. Primakov has proved to be very skillful at playing a weak hand. As Foreign Minister he helped negotiate the Founding Act, which set the terms of NATO's expansion to the East.
Mr. Primakov's strategy today appeared to be to influence some of the waffling members of the alliance by threatening a rupture in NATO-Russia cooperation. The approach also distances Moscow from NATO in the event the strikes go ahead.
Igor S. Ivanov, Mr. Primakov's former deputy and his successor as Foreign Minister, today described NATO military intervention as "a very dangerous decision which brings us to the red line, after which, from our point of view, some very hard consequences may follow."
Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader, said NATO military action would lead to an annulment of agreements between Russia and the alliance.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko faction, was a rare voice of moderation.
From the hospital where he is being treated for a heart attack, he said the Yeltsin Government had not been tough enough with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and urged Russia and NATO to find common ground.
Yugoslavia, for one, seemed to appreciate the Kremlin's help. Today it announced that Borislav Milosevic, the President's brother, would be its next Ambassador to Moscow.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
NATO Order Clears Way For Bombing of the Serbs
The United States and its allies approved an order opening the way for NATO to begin a bombing campaign against Yugoslavia over Kosovo in four days' time, but White House officials said an agreement to end the crisis appeared imminent. Senior American and NATO officials said the envoy Richard C. Holbrooke, above, had made significant progress in talks with the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic. A1 

Russia mounted a campaign to avert air strikes, warning that they might signal an end to cooperation with the Western alliance. Yevgeny M. Primakov, Russia's Prime Minister, recalled his country's representatives to NATO headquarters. A10
 
NATO forces in Bosnia and Croatia are needlessly paying millions of dollars in rent that is winding up in the coffers of the governing political parties, say financial experts who have studied the two governments; diplomats say those parties are often the principal obstacles to peace. A10
 
Economy Hurts Chinese Women
Women over 35 are bearing the brunt of the pain as China struggles to convert to a market economy by closing and shrinking state-owned industries. The women are far more likely to be laid off and far less likely to find a new job than any other group in China. Many of them learned few skills under the old system, and they face outright discrimination. A1
 
Concern Over Yeltsin's Health
President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly cut short a three-day visit to Central Asia after his doctor announced that Mr. Yeltsin was suffering from bronchitis and a slight fever. The announcement compounded the sense that the nation lacked a fully functioning leader during one of its gravest crises. A8
 
U.S. Closer on I.M.F. Funds
The White House and Republican Congressional leaders were said to be close to a deal to provide $18 billion to the International Monetary Fund in exchange for new conditions on loans to foreign governments. A10
 
U.S. Holds 6 in Legal Limbo
Newly declassified Government documents show that the United States has relied on weak and unsubstantiated evidence that has never been fully investigated to detain six Iraqi dissidents who worked with the C.I.A. against President Saddam Hussein. The six have been held for more than a year and a half based on circumstantial allegations of espionage that the Government has never tried to prove, declassified F.B.I. interviews and reports and formerly secret court testimony show. A9
 
New, Conservative Priests
Young American men entering the priesthood are more conservative and tradition-bound than many of their elders and most American Roman Catholics, according to bishops, priests and church surveys. Some older priests, in Rome and elsewhere, worry about a rift developing between clergy and congregation. A3
 
NATIONAL A12-17
 
Gay Man Dies From Attack, Fueling Anger and Debate
Matthew Shepard, the gay college student who was kidnapped, robbed and pistol-whipped in Wyoming, died, five days after he was rescued from a ranch where he had been left tied to a fence for 18 hours in near-freezing temperatures. The announcement fanned the outrage that followed word of the attack, spawning vigils, producing a call from President Clinton for Federal hate-crimes legislation and fueling debate over such laws in Western states, like Wyoming, that have resisted them. A1
 
3 Americans Receive Nobel
Three American pharmacologists -- Dr. Robert Furchgott, 82, of the State University of New York in Brooklyn; Dr. Louis J. Ignarro, 57, of the University of California at Los Angeles, and Dr. Ferid Murad, 62, of the University of Texas Medical School in Houston -- were awarded the Nobel Prize for for physiology or medicine. The award recognized their surprising discoveries of how natural production of a gas, nitric oxide, can mediate a wide variety of bodily actions, such as widening blood vessels, helping to regulate blood pressure, initiating erections, battling infections, preventing formation of blood clots and acting as a signal molecule in the nervous system. A14
 
6 Killed While They Sleep
Six people believed to be illegal immigrants from Mexico were hit and fatally injured by a freight train as they slept on a desolate stretch of tracks in southern Texas. Officials said they believed that the immigrants might have been victims of a belief that the rails would keep them safe from snakes. A12
 
H.M.O. Ruling Is Challenged
The Clinton Administration is asking a full appeals court to overturn an August ruling that gave new rights and consumer protections to six million Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations, saying that the Government should not be held accountable for the actions of H.M.O.'s that sign contracts with Medicare. A17
 
No Accord in Budget Talks
Republican leaders in Congress and White House negotiators ended their talks on the Federal budget without reaching agreement, but pushed back their deadline to midnight tomorrow to work out their differences. Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, both predicted the House and Senate would vote by tomorrow to approve a final accord with the White House on the $1.7 trillion budget, of which about $500 billion has been in dispute. A16
 
Gore Takes the Offensive
Vice President Al Gore, emboldened by recent polls that suggest a backlash against Republicans for initiating impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, made his strongest comments yet on the subject, criticizing a "do-nothing Congress" for not passing significant legislation. A16

The re-election campaign of Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco received a total of $46,000 last year from executives and subsidiaries of a Long Island car-leasing company, Oxford Resources, during and shortly after Mr. Vacco's investigation of complaints against the Oxford. Aides to Mr. Vacco said there was no connection between the donations and the handling of the case. A1
 
Dispute Over Mayor's Pay Plan
Mayor Giuliani plans to offer a 13 percent salary increase to child abuse investigators and their supervisors. But union leaders said they would challenge it. B1
 
Clinton Comes Calling
President Clinton came to New York to promote the Senate campaign of Representative Charles E. Schumer. But Mr. Schumer, who has been criticized by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for missing votes, did not attend -- he had gone back to Washington for votes on the budget. B1

Supporters and opponents of Terrence McNally's play about a gay Christ-like figure, "Corpus Christi," announced plans to demonstrate outside the theater tonight. B4

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Deal Is Reported To Be Near

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The White House and Republican Congressional leaders are close to an agreement to provide $18 billion to the International Monetary Fund in exchange for new conditions on the fund's loans to foreign governments, Clinton Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The officials said the deal, which they expect to be announced this week as part of an overall budget settlement, would require that the I.M.F. raise the interest rates on most loans and shorten the repayment periods. 
 Congressional officials said although some details of the legislation were under negotiation, the package would probably require that loans be repaid in two and a half years.
The lending conditions had been sought by House Republicans, who opposed the full $18 billion in financing that the Administration had requested to help the fund as it tries to avert a global economic crisis.
The money would go to replenish accounts that were depleted by efforts to bail out the economies of Russia and three Asian nations.
Prominent Republican lawmakers have contended that billions of dollars that went to the bailouts were squandered and that liberal lending had encouraged some nations to pursue reckless policies.
The legislation is widely expected to single out South Korea, one of the three Asian nations that received a bailout, and to demand that the monetary fund bar further loans to Seoul if the Government tries to use any of the money to underwrite specific domestic industries that have been especially hard hit.
The Clinton Administration has begun to consult other nations that are large shareholders in the I.M.F. about what lending conditions to impose.
Gene Sperling, who heads the White House's National Economic Council, spoke over the weekend about "a growing sense that there will be both funding for the I.M.F. and significant I.M.F. reforms." But longtime critics of the fund were known to be pressing for even tighter restrictions than those that have been tentatively agreed upon.
Fulfillment of Mr. Sperling's twin predictions would follow many months of debate over the I.M.F. Its critics have complained not only of its loan practices, which they say contribute to economic instability, but also of what they see as excessive secrecy that has made the fund all but unaccountable.
One aspect of the emerging accord would require the fund to issue written summaries of its board meetings and other significant documents, with some exceptions, within three months.
Nations borrowing from the I.M.F. would be compelled to liberalize their trade policies, cease government-directed lending on preferential terms and cut out favoritism in bankruptcy proceedings.
In pressing for full financing, the Clinton Administration has insisted that $18 billion is essential to replenish reserves exhausted by the financial turmoil in Asia and Russia, and to enable the fund to combat continuing crises in other regions.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks in Broad, Sharp Rallies as Bank Bill Passes in Japan

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yesterday after Japan's parliament approved legislation to revive its moribund banking system, setting off rallies in Asian and European markets.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 101.95 points, or 1.29 percent, to 8,001.47. It was the first close above 8,000 for the Dow since Sept. 29. 
 Volume in the United States was light, and the bond market was closed for Columbus Day.
"This is a good rally and a continuation of what went on Friday," said Bill Allyn, head of stock trading at Jefferies & Company. "But because the bond market was closed and volume was down, Tuesday's session might be more telling."
Broader indexes also registered sharp gains. The Nasdaq composite index, which has been pounded recently, completed its biggest two-day advance since October 1987. It climbed 53.59 points yesterday, or 3.59 percent, to 1,546.08, after gaining 73 points on Friday. Still, the two gains have not completely reversed the nearly 200-point decline recorded earlier in the week. And for the year, the index is still down 1.55 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.32 points, or 1.35 percent, to 997.71. The New York Stock Exchange composite index increased 6.25, to 492.95. And the Russell 2,000 index of smaller companies rose 7.22 points, to 325.62.
Volume on the Big Board was 691 million shares.
Optimism about a solution to Japan's financial and economic problems had sent stocks in Tokyo up 5.24 percent. Revitalized banks in Japan could lift the world's second-largest economy out of recession, helping the rest of Asia in the process and easing the world financial crisis. The news spurred Hong Kong's Hang Seng index higher by 5.68 percent. In London, stocks in the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index rose 4.4 percent. German stocks climbed 7.5 percent. And equity prices on major exchanges in Latin America also registered big gains.
Still, some traders said they were not convinced about the Japanese plan, adding that with companies reporting third-quarter earnings, United States stock prices are vulnerable. "I think the Japanese plan is a Band-Aid," said one block trader who asked not to be identified. "What has happened over the last couple of days is nice, but we are not out of the woods. If we get more bad news, we will be back in the doldrums again."
Other analysts said recent developments had raised their hopes about the future.
Peter Canelo, a United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, said a global move toward lower interest rates started by the Federal Reserve Board should help reliquefy the international economy. Nearly as important, he added, has been the recent decline in the value of the dollar, a drop that should help emerging market countries whose currencies are tied to the dollar. The reforms in Japan should also help, he said.
"Our feeling is that the Dow would have a tough time moving above 8,400," he said. "I am feeling a little bit better about things than I was a week or so ago. But third-quarter earnings numbers are going to be very, very important."
The Chrysler Corporation helped to bolster optimism about third-quarter earnings when it surprised industry analysts with a profits report that exceeded expectations. Shares of the company, which is being bought by Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, gained 2 1/2, to 44 1/4, after it said it had earned $1.02 a share in the quarter, up sharply from 65 cents in the period a year earlier. The consensus estimate among analysts polled by the First Call Corporation was 87 cents a share.
Hopes that earnings at technology companies may have bottomed out helped to fuel gains among a number of the industry's leaders.
The Intel Corporation, which is expected to report third-quarter results after the market closes on Tuesday, rose 1 5/8 yesterday, to 85 7/16. Microsoft gained 2 7/8, to 99 3/4. And Dell Computer jumped 3 1/4, to 56 1/16.
Worries about the stability of the financial system persist, however.
Prices of many bank and brokerage stocks rose again yesterday, but there were some notable exceptions.
Merrill Lynch, which is expected to release third-quarter earnings on Tuesday, fell 1 3/4, to 43 7/8. Citigroup lost 1/2, to 34 15/16. And Bankers Trust Company slumped 4 5/8, or nearly 8 percent, to 54 1/4, after Fitch IBCA, the debt rating agency, lowered its rating on the company, citing concerns about its earnings prospects.
The financial sector was also the venue for the session's most spectacular trade, a 2.5-million-share block of Wells Fargo.
The bank, which is completing its $30.7 billion merger with the Norwest Corporation and is expected to report third-quarter earnings next week, saw its stock price plummet 16 3/4 yesterday, to 319 15/16. The 2.5 million shares were sold when the stock was trading at 315 a share.

HEADLINE: Is Loss of Credibility a Crime or Misdemeanor?;
A Remote Prospect

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Thomas L. Friedman's assessment of our need for a President to lead the world in responding to its growing economic crisis ("Oh, by the Way . . .," column, Oct. 10): 
 I question Mr. Friedman's apparent assumption that President Clinton, even if freed from legal responsibility for his behavior in the Lewinsky affair, would retain the authority and credibility sufficient "to galvanize the process, explain it and press it forward."
The prospect of effective leadership's being exercised in any context over the next two years by a disgraced, discredited and disreputable President seems remote, to say the least.
 
THOMAS J. CAROLAN JR.
Silver Spring, Md., Oct. 10, 1998

HEADLINE: Candidates Risk Little With Harsh Ads

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
At a Sunday morning service recently, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake went to the pulpit of his church in Queens and urged the candidates for the United States Senate, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Charles E. Schumer, to cease their "dirty campaign." They were doing themselves a disservice and would ultimately turn voters away from an important political contest, Mr. Flake told the congregation, which included Mr. D'Amato that morning.
Mr. Flake got the answer to his plea two days later. Senator D'Amato released three new advertisements attacking Mr. Schumer ("Chuck Schumer consistently votes against us," the announcer says in one), while Representative Schumer slashed into Mr. D'Amato's environmental record, asserting that "people are wise to his act." 
 Civic leaders like Mr. Flake, and some voters, might frown on such politicking -- thrashing the opponent, rather than advancing one's own accomplishments -- but the candidates and their advisers in this pivotal Senate race have concluded that they have no other choice.
The unrelenting attacks -- on voting records, on ethics, on political ideology, even on the place that Mr. Schumer calls home -- are the inevitable result of a competition that features a relatively unpopular Republican incumbent fighting for re-election in a Democratic state, and a relatively little-known challenger trying to knock out one of the most resourceful figures in politics.
Mr. Flake's concerns notwithstanding, the candidates and their strategists have decided that the risks of "going negative," as it is known, are far outweighed by the effectiveness of such politicking. The finger-pointing between Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato about who started it, and who has been more negative, might present intriguing questions for historians one day, but it is unlikely to influence many voters in November.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll underscores their judgment. By any objective measure, the campaign between Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato is about as negative as they come -- it is, arguably, the most negative Senate race in the nation this fall -- yet 54 percent of voters said it was no more negative than Mr. D'Amato's last contest, in 1992, against Robert Abrams. In fact, 14 percent said it was more positive.
More voters blame Mr. D'Amato for the tone of the race, by 34 percent to 26 percent, and slightly more are inclined to think Mr. D'Amato's attacks are unfair, instead of the ones offered by Mr. Schumer, the Times/ CBS News Poll found. But there is no evidence of voters punishing the candidates for what they see as tactical transgressions. Three weeks of punch-for-punch campaigning have produced a statistical dead heat for the candidates, the Times/CBS News poll found.
The telephone poll of 1,066 registered voters in New York State, taken from Oct. 1 to Oct. 6, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
The fact that the campaign has devolved to this level so fast is certainly not a surprise to anyone familiar with the dynamics of the race or its two tenacious contestants. "Neither of these guys had a choice; it was inscribed the day before the primary," said Norman Adler, a political analyst from New York who is not affiliated with either candidate.
But though both have embraced the same tactic, they have done it for different reasons, and that is revealing of the shortcomings and political positions Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato find themselves in this year.
Mr. D'Amato's motivations can be determined from a cursory reading of any public opinion poll: The Senator invariably scores less than 50 percent against his opponent. In the Times/CBS News Poll, 41 percent of registered voters said they would support him. That is not good for an incumbent who has been in office for 18 years, since by this point, there is little that Mr. D'Amato can tell undecided voters to win them over.
That means that Mr. D'Amato must provide them with reasons not to support Mr. Schumer, which he has been doing since the night Mr. Schumer won the Democratic primary (and as the Senator has done in all of his statewide races in New York). To this end, Mr. D'Amato has combed through 23 years of Mr. Schumer's legislative record, picking out votes -- some on major pieces of legislation, and others on procedural or inconsequential matters -- to portray the Brooklyn Representative as liberal or hostile to upstate New York. Most recently, he has seized on the fact that Mr. Schumer, who has for most of his career had a strong attendance record in Congress, missed more than 100 votes this year as he attended to his campaign needs.
Mr. Schumer's attacks on Mr. D'Amato have been no less brutal. Mr. Schumer's challenge has been built on one overarching theme: that Mr. D'Amato is a chronic liar. ("Too many lies for too long," is the last line of most commercials, a slogan so harsh that it appears to have taken even Mr. D'Amato's breath away).
It is a broad pre-emptive attack intended to inoculate Mr. Schumer against any criticism Mr. D'Amato might come up with between now and Nov. 3, by stirring what polls suggest are strong doubts about Mr. D'Amato's trustworthiness.
As an all-encompassing theme, Mr. Schumer's approach pushes the horizon of negative campaigning, and could, if Mr. Schumer wins, be remembered as a political benchmark one day. Early indications are that it is successful. The Times/CBS News Poll shows that Mr. Schumer continues to have a generally favorable rating among voters, suggesting that Mr. D'Amato's attacks have yet to stick.
Mr. Schumer's confrontational strategy has two other unstated purposes. First, it was designed to catch the attention of Democratic contributors across the country who were deciding where to send their checks in this year's 34 Senate contests, by signaling that Mr. Schumer would run the campaign against Mr. D'Amato that some Democrats believe Mr. Abrams failed to do six years ago. And the unusually sharp cast of the attack -- even some Democrats describe it as a little over the top -- is intended to be splashy enough to win Mr. Schumer a few newspaper articles and some television coverage.
Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato are executing the kinds of campaigns that have been part of American politics for the better part of 200 years, but which really came into focus with the 1988 Presidential contest. That year, Vice President George Bush and the Republican Party devastated Michael S. Dukakis with a searing run of ads that questioned Mr. Dukakis's fortitude, ideology and even his patriotism. It is often cited by analysts as evidence of the potency of such tactics.
There are some notorious examples of negative campaigning this year as well. In the Nebraska Republican primary for governor, Representative Jon Christensen accused Mike Johanns, the Mayor of Lincoln, of condoning child pornography after a cable television channel in his city showed some nudity. Other Republicans assailed Mr. Christensen, and he went on to lose the primary.
But viewed by the three best measures of a campaign's negativity -- the sharpness of the attacks, their sheer volume, and the mix between positive and negative -- the New York race stands out this year. Mr. D'Amato's menu of television is almost entirely negative. Mr. Schumer has leavened his mix with a handful of positive advertisements and is expected to produce more upbeat ads as Election Day approaches.
That has formed the backdrop for a second subject of dispute between Mr. Schumer and Mr. D'Amato: which candidate is responsible for the attacks, and who is the most negative. That may sound like an academic question to viewers bombarded with one attack ad after another, but it is particularly relevant this year because Mr. D'Amato has -- once again -- tried to portray himself as a victim of unfair attacks.
Mr. Schumer notes, correctly, that Mr. D'Amato was the first to run attack ads, starting the day after the primary with one that asserted: "Liberal Chuck Schumer. Wrong on taxes. Wrong on welfare. Wrong on crime. Wrong for us." (Mr. D'Amato actually began attacking Mr. Schumer in a Dec. 30, 1997, letter to supporters, in which he said, "I've listened to this guy for 17 years and I still can't figure out what they taught him at Harvard. It wasn't common sense!") Mr. Schumer knew Mr. D'Amato's history well enough to be ready with his own attack ad the moment the Senator ran his.
Finally, the two are now quarreling about what is fair in political discourse. Mr. D'Amato contends that Mr. Schumer crossed the line. "Campaigns aren't always gentlemanly-like," Mr. D'Amato said yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan in which he assailed Mr. Schumer's attendance record. "However, I do believe it is one thing to point to a person's record and it is another thing to use pejoratives that have been used in this campaign that go beyond." He said he was referring specifically to Mr. Schumer's having described him as a liar and a bully.
Mr. Schumer responded by mocking Mr. D'Amato. "When he finally gets someone to answer him back, he starts whining," he said.
In truth, even the Representative's supporters acknowledge that calling someone a liar is extraordinary by the standards of American politics. Still, the Senator's bid for sympathy based on Mr. Schumer's perceived excesses arguably runs up against his own history.
Mr. D'Amato played a very prominent role in writing the book on attack politics in this country over the past 25 years. He helped produce a seminal snippet of campaign advertising 18 years ago. "And now, at age 76 and in failing health, he wants six more years," the announcer said as the screen showed a crumpled Javits poster fluttering to the ground. The subject of the attack was Senator Jacob J. Javits, a Republican. Mr. D'Amato defeated him in the Republican primary by 70,000 votes, and went on to win the general election.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Mall Builder Says 60% of Space Taken

 BODY:
Glimcher Realty Trust has signed leases or obtained letters of intent to lease 60 percent of a 1.3 million-square-foot mall it is building on a former landfill in Elizabeth, N.J., the developer said yesterday.
Retailers that have signed leases include Annie Sez, Bed Bath and Beyond, Daffy's and Foot Locker, said Marie Izzo Cartwright, a spokeswoman for Glimcher, a real estate investment trust based in Columbus, Ohio. Ms. Cartwright declined to discuss lease terms or say how much space had been leased or was still under negotiation. 
 The Gardens Value Mega Mall is being built at a cost of $363 million just off the New Jersey Turnpike near Newark International Airport. Financing includes $140 million in tax-exempt economic development bonds and government grants, a $163 million loan from Bankers Trust and Huntington National Bank, plus $56 million in equity from Glimcher. Construction began in April, and the mall is scheduled to open in the fall of 1999, Ms. Cartwright said.
Despite recent signs of declining consumer confidence, Ms. Cartwright said the mall would include bargain outlets like Off 5th-Saks Fifth Avenue Outlet, and should be attractive to the cost-conscious.
Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, said the mall's favorable location was more important than the short-term economic outlook. "I think consumer spending is likely to slow down," Mr. Feiner said. But he added, "One could easily argue that from a longer-term standpoint, this could be viewed as an intelligent move."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: Waving Her Cultural Magic Wand

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
In her wheelchair, facing a roomful of work by the likes of Donald Judd and Barnett Newman, her back to the magnificent view of San Francisco Bay afforded by her apartment in the Pacific Heights section, Phyllis C. Wattis seemed braced by what she loves: modern art and this city. At 93, her hearing is poor and a recent leg infection has curtailed her mobility, but she wears her hair jauntily in a silver pageboy and she has an unmistakably mischievous smile. In deference to company, she wasn't listening to Stravinsky, turned up loud. "I play 'The Rite of Spring' all the time," she said.
It was a rare interview for Mrs. Wattis, one of the nation's great cultural philanthropists -- "California's Brooke Astor," in the words of David A. Ross, the new director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art -- whose generosity, mostly to local arts institutions, has amounted to an astounding $100 million. She squeezed the interview in between a board meeting at the modern art museum and a visit to the San Francisco Art Exposition, where she viewed almost all the 100 booths, a sampling of galleries worldwide. 
 The October afternoon was one that her husband, Paul Wattis, a construction and mining magnate whose philanthropic interests were more science-oriented, would have indulged but not understood. He died in 1971; his company, Utah International, which in its early days was the primary contractor on the Hoover Dam, was bought by General Electric five years later, a merger that greatly enhanced Mrs. Wattis's wealth.
"We always gave whatever we could," she said. "You have to give. But my husband thought all artists were robbers if they tried to sell their art. They were decorators to him."
She laughed at the memory, just one of myriad anomalous elements of her long life. Arts donors, after all, are rare enough. But perhaps no one is like the independent-minded Mrs. Wattis, a great-granddaughter of Brigham Young who moved here from Utah in 1936 and has, particularly in the last part of her life, treated her adopted city in the manner of a tough, doting mother determined to rear a cultured child.
"I can imagine Phyllis as a pioneer woman," said Lotfi Mansouri, the general director of the San Francisco Opera since 1988. "My favorite story about her is that when I was appointed, some of the board members had a dinner party to introduce me, and they had me sitting next to Phyllis. At dessert, she turned to me and said, "Damn it, usually these parties are so boring I didn't bring my hearing aid. But I think you might be saying some interesting things."
Admired not just for her generosity, but for her discernment, she is known for her thoughtful gifts, from an English horn for a teen-ager in the San Francisco Youth Orchestra to the more than $20 million that recently helped the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art buy 13 works by Robert Rauschenberg and others by Duchamp, Mondrian, Anselm Kiefer and Wayne Thiebaud when its collection was being criticized as unworthy of its new building.
"She believes a great museum needs to be based on masterpieces," Mr. Ross said. "She unabashedly believes in the power of great works of art, and she gives unqualified support, an increasingly rare thing."
The cultural life of this city owes much of its profile to her. In the early 1980's, after Mrs. Wattis gave $3.25 million to the San Francisco Symphony to help build its new home, she also donated $750,000 more so the hall could have an organ, a particular yearning of its music director at the time, Edo de Waart.
"I don't think she cared about it so much, but she sensed that he cared about it," said Peter Pastreich, the symphony's executive director. "Others were asking, 'How often will you play this thing?' And the truth is, you don't play it every week, but when you do, you want it to be great. That's an argument that Phyllis Wattis understands and others don't."
Without her, the San Francisco Opera would not have been able to commission contemporary works like Sir Michael Tippett's "Midsummer Marriage" and Hans Werner Henze's "The Sailor Who Fell From Grace With the Sea." Nor could it have staged several productions of Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" and "Lulu," or, with anything resembling the lavish care it received, its current production of "A Streetcar Named Desire"; she paid for the entire production and the rehearsal time.
"I've had the same seats at the opera for 30 years," Mrs Wattis said wryly. "I felt it was my duty to get them out of 'La Boheme.' "
It was just a decade ago that she surprised the San Francisco cultural world by suddenly dissolving the foundation she had founded with her husband in 1958 and run since his death, distributing all its $26 million in assets. Since then, she has given away some $70 million of her personal funds. She donated $20 million to the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco for a new building yet to be built and acquisitions. She gave $5 million to the city's Museum of Modern Art for its new building, now four years old, before her gift for acquisitions. The California Academy of Sciences received $10 million, the Exploratorium $5 million, the Berkeley Art Museum $2 million.
"Obviously it can't be a bottomless pit, but I don't think she intends to die with any money," said Nancy Bechtle, the president of the symphony board. "Most philanthropists don't give away their capital, but that's what she does, and she gives graciously and gladly."
What makes Mrs. Wattis that much more unusual is that she grew up with no interest in the arts and no encouragement to pursue them. She was born Phyllis Cannon in 1905 in Salt Lake City. She was the third of six children whose father was a sugar company executive and mother a homemaker.
"I grew up as a tomboy in a big family, and I don't think I ever thought about art," she said. "I don't ever remember going to a museum. My mother thought she could sing. I was sent to take music lessons with my uncle. It didn't take."
Her parents' families, though not her parents, were polygamous. Her paternal grandfather, George Q. Cannon, had five wives and 35 children; a fanatic about education, he sent all of his children east to school. His 22 sons all went to M.I.T. The girls, "whatever number that leaves," Mrs. Wattis said, "went to Fannie Farmer's cooking school." Her own father, she said, enjoyed travel. "He took us to Europe, a family of six," she said. "And I remember he put us on a plane from Paris to London, in 1925, two years before Lindbergh."
Mrs. Wattis attended the University of Utah, then finished her degree, in economics, at the University of California at Berkeley before returning to Utah. She married, and when her husband's company moved its headquarters to San Francisco in 1936 she settled there.
Despite her husband's antipathy toward artists, he was an opera fan, and the couple attended together. Still, though the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art had been founded, by Grace L. McCann Morley, the year before they arrived, Mrs. Wattis said she did not bother with the museum until the early 1950's.
"That was the first time I saw modern art," she said. It wasn't until 1964, however, when a driving tour of Europe brought her and her husband to Kassel, Germany, home of the Documenta art fair, "that I understood what Grace had been talking about all those years."
In three days at Documenta, "it was all in front of me," she said. "I saw everybody for the first time. Calder, Max Ernst, Emil Nolde. That was my real introduction." She added, shyly, "I did some drawing myself." And she began to buy art. Her first acquisition, an abstract marble sculpture by Max Bill, stands today in her foyer.
When Paul Wattis died, he left his assets in the foundation, which had grown from what Mrs. Wattis described as almost an afterthought -- "everyone was starting foundations back then" -- to an organization that was regularly solicited by scientific and artistic causes. She ran it nearly single-handedly; her son and daughter and two nephews, who were nominally on the board, showed little interest. Finally, in 1988, fearful of its management in the future, she decided to liquidate.
"I thought, 'What's going to happen to it?' So I just decided to distribute it all."
The latest flurry of gifts, those who know Mrs. Wattis say, has been motivated by her failing health. "She has finally focused on her mortality," said Gary Garrels, chief curator at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. "She's saying, 'I want to do things while I'm here.' I mean, how much fun is a bequest?"
And she does, evidently, have fun. At the Art Exposition, accompanied by Mr. Garrels and Ella King Torrey, president of the San Francisco Art Institute, she greeted dealers from all over the country; remembered one, Linda Durham, a woman from New Mexico she had met 20 years earlier who called Mrs. Wattis "the first person to ever be kind to me when I started out in business," and impressed another, Perry Rubenstein, from New York, with her questions about an abstract painting by Gerhard Richter.
"Most people are buying trophies," Mr. Rubenstein said when she was gone. "She's not. She has real intellectual curiosity, which is what distinguishes the lookers from the great collectors."
Afterward, as she sipped champagne and discussed with Mr. Garrels the work of the painter Sigmar Polke, Ms. Torrey recalled last year's Christmas party at the Art Institute, where the tree was topped with a puppet made by two students; it was Mrs. Wattis's likeness, in a long gown, holding a wand. Mrs. Wattis had given the school $5 million for the faculty retirement fund, physical resources and equipment.
"She gave generously, but not lightly," Ms. Torrey said. "She was very tough on me about it, wanting to know exactly how the money would be used. But it was everything we needed. And the students knew it."
Hence the puppet, which they presented to her. "Fairy-God Phyllis," they called it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The philanthropist Phyllis C. Wattis in San Francisco. (Jenny Thomas for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Line Between Loving and Cursing

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

LIKE NEVER BEFORE
By Ehud Havazelet
268 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.
 There is a moment in Ehud Havazelet's new book, "Like Never Before," that incarnates the distilled bitterness, the melancholy sting, of this quietly powerful collection of stories. Max Birnbaum, the distracted and ineffectual son of a famous rabbi from Cracow and the father of two disappointing children, is in his living room in Queens speaking to his wife, Esther, who is dying of cancer. 
"I love them," he says abruptly, speaking of his children, David and Rachel, whose estrangement from their parents exemplifies Mr. Havazelet's view of human relations as battles nearly to the death.
"Tell them that," Esther replies. And then:
"Tell them," he sneers. "That I never will understand them, how they live?" Max thinks about his long-dead brother, killed by the Nazis, and he has Job-like thoughts of God: "That every morning I curse him for a traitor and I curse them for the unhappiness they bring." His hands make a gesture of futility. "You too," he says, "for tricking me like this, for leaving. Every morning I curse you all, and then I curse myself. I should tell them that?"
Mr. Havazelet, who got respectful attention for "What Is It Then Between Us?," his first collection of stories, proves himself again an impressively talented writer in "Like Never Before," a book that lives on the precarious edge between loving and cursing. A series of independent but related stories, the new book consists of intense, often searing scenes from three generations of a spiritually wounded Polish Jewish family living in Queens.
Mr. Havazelet writes with a kind of anatomical precision, his scalpel slicing at his characters to expose the dark reality beneath. He has a sharp, almost grotesque wit, a fine ear for the eccentric cadences of lower-middle-class New York Jews and an unsentimental compassion for the scars they bear.
The first story, "Six Days," sets the scene, etching in the relationship between Birnbaum and his son that will emerge as the central conflict of Mr. Havazelet's collection of vignettes. Birnbaum teaches in a Hebrew day school, living in the shadow of his father, the rabbi of an Orthodox Brooklyn congregation. One Yom Kippur, in his father's synagogue, prayers are interrupted when David and a friend, playing ball outside (already a sacrilege), break a synagogue window with a ball.
"The boy saw his father's eyes, the look in them. He's going to kill me, he thought. Birnbaum leaned over, grunting words he didn't recognize. He tried to reach with his fists, but he couldn't, so he began using his feet on the red-faced creature scuttling away from him on its back near the wall."
In "Light of This World," which describes a day in the life of three truants from the Hebrew Day School, it becomes clear that there is a cruelty in David that goes beyond the normal cruelty of children. Mr. Havazelet provides a flashback in the next story, "Lyon," where Birnbaum, then 16 and known as Maxim Birnboym, and his older brother, Rachmil, both refugees from Cracow, collect money to pay for Jews to be smuggled across the border into Switzerland. This brief excursion into Birnbaum's past is all the more powerful because it is so brief, and only once more referred to -- in Birnbaum's acrid comment to his dying wife.
The brief incident, written with a kind of verbal suddenness reminiscent of Isaac Babel, tells almost all one needs to know about the troubled fate of the Birnbaum family. It is not only the sins of the fathers that are visited upon the sons, Mr. Havazelet seems to be saying. It is more importantly the wounds that have been inflicted upon them and that they struggle without success to keep to themselves.
The most brilliantly executed piece in the collection may be "Leah," which is the story of Rachel, David's sister, told through her relationship with a female cousin exactly her age, a kind of inverse doppelganger. While Rachel shares David's rebelliousness, she is more lost than vengeful. David, whose look is one of "quiet outrage, detachment, the aloof expectation of pain," is a disturbed and disturbing figure, shown by Mr. Havazelet in an almost luridly bright and unforgiving light.
In "Leah" we see him as a 17-year-old full of mockery, contempt and self-punishment, a boy who spreads a dark shadow around him. We later glimpse his marriage to a non-Jewish woman named Maura, who fails to evoke a sympathetic response in her husband when a neighbor is murdered. David by now has become an architect, intelligent and ambitious, but he is so damaged and self-punishing as to be unwitting in his cruelty. He falls in love with a young woman at work, comes home late one night and wakes Maura to tell her the news. "What was happening to him was unusual," he thinks in his solipsistic way; "if it happened to you once in your life you were lucky. Could she try and see that?"
Mr. Havazelet tells these stories with a remarkable economy and stylistic precision, the characters emerging in just a few quick strokes. "His mouth, through his thick ungainly beard, was a wet red hole glistening with teeth," he writes of an early suitor of Rachel's cousin Leah. When Birnbaum is introduced to David's second non-Jewish wife, he takes it as "one more signal that his life, so meagerly lit, was about to get darker still."
There is very little in the way of redemption in Mr. Havazelet's vision of subtly but irrevocably afflicted lives, only a small flicker of possible understanding between David and Rachel near the end. When Birnbaum, his wife dead, goes to Seattle to try to settle his accounts with David, living there with his wife and two young children, even the effort of the two men to embrace is a failure. The experience of reading Mr. Havazelet's stories is one well on the dark side of poignancy, but it is also one of pleasure at the realization of a striking talent.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ehud Havazelet (Tim Wydronek/Farrar, Straus & Giroux)

HEADLINE: Ford to Produce Gearless Car Transmission

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced plans today for mass production of a new, gearless car transmission to be produced in a joint venture that could also become a new model for labor relations in the auto industry.
The new transmission, which uses a system of pulleys instead of gears, allowing many subtle gradations of power to speed, improves fuel economy by 10 percent to 15 percent, Ford said. Large-scale installation of the new transmission would help Ford meet Federal fuel-economy regulations in the United States and compete in foreign markets where gas prices are high and fuel economy is important to car buyers. 
 Ford said that it would form the joint venture with ZF Friedrichshafen A.G. of Germany, which had patented a design for a so-called continuously variable automatic transmission. Ford will own 49 percent of the venture and ZF will own 51 percent. The two companies said they would begin installing the transmissions in 2001 model-year cars and would install a million of the new transmissions annually by 2005 at a Ford transmission factory in Ohio.
The transmissions would be installed mainly in small Ford cars in the United States and abroad. But Ford also planned to sell some to other auto makers overseas, said Jacques Nasser, the president of Ford's worldwide automotive operations, who will become Ford's chief executive at the end of the year.
Ford's choice of a joint venture to build the new transmissions also opened the door for it to make the first use of an unusual provision in all of the Big Three's labor contracts since 1996. The provision allowed the auto makers to pay lower wages in any new auto parts businesses that they enter through joint ventures.
Mr. Nasser said that all current employees at the company's transmission factory in Batavia, Ohio, would remain Ford employees. But any future hires would be employees of the new joint venture, and Ford would eventually like to have a separate labor agreement at the factory, he told reporters today.

HEADLINE: Prototype of Peace via Trade in Gaza

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: GAZA, Oct. 9

 BODY:
The grandly named Gaza Industrial Estate, an unprepossessing 120-acre collection of vacant factory sheds and water towers rising from the ragged flatlands east of Gaza City, is an unlikely focus for the highly charged, high-stakes Middle East peace negotiations.
Fenced off from potential markets by the barbed wire of the Israeli border, the park has been ready for business for nearly a year. But security-conscious Israeli officials had been unwilling to guarantee the unimpeded flow of goods that an industrial park needs to attract and sustain investment. 
 Now, hailed by all sides as the first tangible achievement of the current phase of the tortuous Israeli-Palestinian negotiating process, the Gaza Industrial Estate is expected to be operating before the end of the year. It will employ up to a thousand Palestinians, and eventually more, in several small-scale manufacturing ventures.
What was hailed here as a diplomatic and economic breakthrough would almost anywhere else in the world be an unexceptional, small step in industrial development.
Still, it is a measure of the Gaza Strip's isolation and economic desperation that this tentative, modest project looms so large for Palestinian planners.
"This is very, very important," said Abdel Rahman Naim, head of the Gaza office of the Palestinian Directorate for Free Zones and Industrial Parks, part of the Palestinian Authority. "This will be the first concrete outcome of these negotiations, the first project with real benefits for people here."
At the same time, the Gaza project has been embraced by Israeli officials eager to demonstrate some visible progress and flexibility in the talks. "Karni seems like a little item on the agenda, but it can have great ramifications," said Natan Sharansky, Israel's Trade and Industry Minister, using the Israeli name for the border crossing known to Palestinians as Montar.
Opening the park for business has also been a key short-term goal of American mediators, who are acutely aware of the steady economic deterioration here since the signing of the Oslo accords between Israel and the Palestinians five years ago.
The United States has pledged some $6 million for items like a water treatment plant on the Palestinian side and the improvement of Israeli border inspection sites.
Gaza now has little to offer a labor force that expands by an extraordinary 5 percent yearly, propelled by what for 15 years has been the highest recorded birth rate in the world. Emigration from Gaza to Israel or to Palestinian areas in the West Bank is forbidden by the Israeli authorities.
Depression-scale unemployment -- averaging 37 percent last year, the United Nations has reported -- is worsened by Israeli denials of daily work visas for the 25,000 Gaza laborers who are authorized to cross the border for jobs in construction and agriculture. Israel cites security as the reason for the visa denials.
As they concluded talks in Jerusalem and Gaza in recent days in preparation for the coming round of peace negotiations in Maryland, American officials said optimistically that they anticipated 17 initial private investors and an eventual 40,000 workers at the park, a figure equivalent to a fifth of the current Gaza labor force.
The Palestinians managing the project are more cautious, reporting that they have received a dozen serious proposals -- one from an Israeli company, the rest from Palestinians -- for projects ranging from garment making to the manufacture of steel security doors.
If all of the projects go forward, they say, the park will employ about 3,000 people within 18 months and as many as 20,000 within five years.
"As an industrial zone, this is very small," acknowledged Awni Abdul-Rahim, the general manager of the Palestinian Industrial Estates Development Company, or Piedco, the local company running the park.
And its economic viability, he added, is contingent on the cooperation of Israeli customs and security officials, who will ultimately control access. "Everything depends on Israel," Mr. Abdul-Rahim said.
Gaza's exports are routinely obstructed by border closings and security checks, further skewing a chronic trade imbalance. For every five trucks that arrive here from Israel, only one goes out, and it typically goes out very slowly.
On a recent afternoon at the border checkpoint next to the industrial park, six Israeli customs inspectors examined a truckload of Gaza potatoes for hours, pallet by pallet, bag by bag, with hand-held metal detectors.
American advisers hope to smooth these bottlenecks with computerized scanners, bonded inspections and other high-tech customs systems developed for the border between the United States and Mexico.
"If they want it to be a successful business it cannot be interrupted," Mr. Sharansky said. "Yet one of the biggest explosions of the last year in Tel Aviv started with a truck from Gaza, so we can't take the security issue lightly."
While the agreement to open the industrial zone is being trumpeted by American diplomats as a done deal, Palestinians and Israelis are still haggling over legal and technical details and, perhaps more important from the Palestinian viewpoint, how it is portrayed in an eventual peace accord.
The Palestinian Industrial Estates Development Company, which says it is investing $10 million in the industrial park, is controlled by the powerful Masri clan from Nablus in the West Bank. The Palestinian Authority, which has leased the land for 49 years, will receive 10 percent of Piedco's profits, Mr. Abdul-Rahim said.
The Palestinians acknowledge that their ultimate goal is to attract Israeli joint ventures, both for immediate business reasons -- Palestinian industry "is weak on marketing," Mr. Naim said -- and as a long-term survival strategy.
A precondition for any Palestinian export venture is secure access through Israel to other foreign markets, and the Palestinians hope to build an allied constituency of Israeli industrialists equally dependent on open borders.
Palestinian officials, some of whom once preached socialist self-sufficiency, promise a laissez-faire paradise for prospective export manufacturers. They say there will be no corporate taxes, minimal regulatory oversight and workers who will earn $300 to $400 a month, the prevailing unskilled pay rate within Gaza but about half of what Palestinians earn in Israel.
"There will be no interference from government or from unions," Mr. Naim said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Israeli soldiers at a Gaza checkpoint examined a shipment of Palestinian-grown potatoes headed for Israel. American advisers hope to modernize such customs bottlenecks to simplify the flow of commercial traffic. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)
 
Map of the Gaza Strip showing location of the Gaza Industrial Estate: The Gaza Industrial Estate is an unlikely focus for peace talks.

HEADLINE: Bill to Increase Work Visas for Foreigners Gets New Lease on Life

BYLINE: By JERI CLAUSING 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Congressional leaders revived legislation today that would nearly double the number of employment visas available for skilled foreign workers.
The measure, which is sought by high-technology industries, appeared dead on Friday night, but budget negotiators agreed today to include it in the omnibus spending bill that Congress is trying to finish this week so it can adjourn. 
 "This is a big victory for the economy, which is being fueled in large part by our high-tech industries," said the author of the legislation, Senator Spencer Abraham, a Michigan Republican. "The legislation strikes the right balance in safeguarding America's competitive edge and protecting U.S. jobs."
The final proposal represents a hard-fought compromise with the White House, which had opposed Senator Abraham's original measure because of concerns that it lacked proper protections for American workers.
Silicon Valley companies have pushed hard for the visa legislation, contending that they cannot find enough skilled Americans to fill crucial jobs.
The industry won another victory today with the passage of the Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act, which is intended to protect technology and other start-up companies from lawsuits in state courts over stock price fluctuations. The compromise measure, now endorsed by both houses of Congress, imposes a single national standard for such suits.
The legislation to increase the number of so-called H1-B work visas, a result of months of wrangling with the White House, appeared to have been killed on Friday night after Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, questioned the validity of the high-technology industries' claims of worker shortages and blocked a final vote.
The final version increases from 65,000 to 115,000 the number of H1-B visas available in each of the next two years and sets the number at 107,500 in the third year.
It requires that if 15 percent or more of a company's work force consists of employees on H1-B visas, it must attest that they have not replaced American workers.
Companies hiring H1-B workers with master's degrees or higher or at salaries of $60,000 or more would be exempt from that requirement. There are also special exemptions for small businesses and start-up companies.
The legislation also authorizes the Labor Department to investigate suspected abuses of the program and imposes a $500 filing fee on visa applications and renewals. The more than $75 million raised by these fees would be used for training and scholarship programs for United States citizens.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
No Need for World Rate Cut, European Bank Chief Says

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Despite growing anxiety that global financial problems might soon affect Europe, the president of the new European Central Bank rejected demands today to relax monetary policy in an effort to spur economic growth.
In a toughly worded message aimed in part at European political leaders, the central bank said there was no need for worldwide reductions in interest rates or other forms of "policy activism" to jump-start economic growth. 
 "There is certainly some kind of slowdown, but not a crisis," said Wim Duisenberg, who as president of the European Central Bank now oversees monetary policy across the 11 countries that will adopt the euro as a single currency on Jan. 1.
"Proposals for a reassessment of capital controls as an acceptable policy option, or recent calls for worldwide, uniform interest rate reductions, are inappropriate as they do not address the very nature of the problems," he said.
Mr. Duisenberg's remarks, which came after a meeting of the bank's governing council, underline a growing divergence between monetary policy in Europe and the United States. While the Federal Reserve has begun lowering American interest rates amid fear of a significant slowdown in the economy, the European bankers are barely flinching from their original course and remain preoccupied with establishing the new currency's credibility.
A surprising effect of that policy has been the strength of existing European currencies, like the German mark and the French franc, which essentially mirror expectations for the euro.
Traders, far from being skittish about an untested currency in the offing, have begun buying the current national currencies as a haven from global shocks in Asia, Latin America and Russia. The mark and the franc are nearly 10 percent stronger against the dollar than they were in August.
In recent days, the European Central Bank has come under increasing pressure from national leaders to either reduce interest rates or support other measures to keep European growth from slipping.
In Germany, Chancellor-elect Gerhard Schroder has called for lower rates, and his designated finance minister has repeatedly assailed the German central bank's, and by extension the European bank's, tight-money policies as misguided. The French Cabinet continues its complaints against those policies.
Most economists predict that growth in the so-called euro zone will remain above 2.5 percent through the end of 1998 but will substantially slow next year. The continuing problems in Asia and Latin America are expected to curtail demand for European exports, and the recent shift in exchange rates will dig more deeply by making European exports more expensive in dollar terms.
Signs of slowing growth are already becoming apparent in Germany, where industrial exports have been the economic engine in the last 18 months. Machine-tool and engineering companies have lowered their forecasts for exports next year. Hoechst, the chemical and pharmaceutical giant, warned on Monday that its profits in the second half of this year would fall below those in the period a year earlier.
European banks are also reporting big setbacks and are eliminating thousands of jobs because of losses in securities trading, soured foreign loans and heightened competitive pressure. In the last 10 days, the chairmen of two leading financial institutions -- UBS of Switzerland and ING Barings in the Netherlands -- have resigned in the wake of big losses. Some analysts expect more bad news in the months ahead, predicting that banks will be forced to write off more foreign loans than they already have.
Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged that financial crises elsewhere would affect Europe. "The number of signs suggesting that the world economy will slow down in 1999 is increasing," he said at a news conference here today. He also noted that uncertainty had been heightened by the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the American hedge fund, and by the losses at individual banks.
But he insisted that "proposals inspired by policy activism" must be avoided. He said he was not concerned about the recent plunge in the exchange value of the dollar, which could hurt European exports. And he said European interest rates were about where they should be. "There are no signs of a credit crunch in Europe," he maintained.
The European Central Bank is still struggling with the tools it will use to set monetary policy, torn between basing it simply on the growth of the money supply or on inflation targets. In principle, many central bankers would prefer to follow the example of the Bundesbank, which bases lending rates almost entirely on the growth of the German money supply. In practice, money statistics vary considerably between countries in the new currency union, and new forms of financial transactions have further complicated the definitions of money.
After months of debate behind closed doors, Mr. Duisenberg announced that the bank would use both money supply and inflation targets. The overall goal will be to keep inflation under 2 percent.
Mr. Duisenberg acknowledged the bank was under pressure. "The political pressure could increase -- I would not deny that," he said. "But it is pressure against a strong institution. We will make our own judgments, use our own analysis and reach our own decisions."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
General Motors Posts Loss of $809 Million

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation lost $809 million in the third quarter, mainly because of a nearly eight-week-long strike that ended on July 29 and crippled G.M.'s production in North America, the auto maker announced today.
G.M.'s loss of $1.28 a diluted share was slightly better than analysts' expectations. The company's North American operations continued to cut costs aggressively, paying less for auto parts and making factories more efficient. But today's report also showed that the company had been discounting its vehicles heavily in North America while its foreign operations were beginning to suffer from economic troubles overseas. 
 Auto analysts said that the strike at two G.M. auto parts factories in Flint, Mich., had caused so much disruption that it was hard to draw firm conclusions from the quarter's results. "The best thing about the third quarter is it's over," said Michael Ward, an analyst at Paine Webber. "Going forward, the news should get more positive."
G.M. said the strike cost it $1.2 billion in the third quarter, the same amount it lost to the strike during the second quarter. Michael Losh, G.M.'s chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview that the $2.4 billion in after-tax losses from the strike should be pared to roughly $2 billion by the end of the year as factories continue to work overtime to make up lost production.
G.M. earned $1.04 billion during the third quarter of 1997, or $1.34 a share, but those figures included aerospace operations that G.M. has since sold. Excluding the aerospace operations, the strike and a $271 million after-tax charge for the disposal of some auto parts factories, G.M.'s profits fell 28.4 percent during the third quarter, to $697 million, compared with $973 million in the quarter a year earlier.
G.M.'s sales in the third quarter plunged to $34.42 billion, from $41.89 billion in the quarter a year earlier, partly because some operations were sold but mainly because of the strike.
Mr. Losh said that with the third quarter behind it, G.M. was well positioned for the fourth quarter. The introductions of new pickup trucks in North America and the new Opel Astra sedan in Europe were expensive during the third quarter but should start helping the auto maker's results, he said.
While G.M. spent an unusually high average of $1,732 a vehicle in discounts in the North American market during the third quarter, that figure fell to $1,400 for sales at the end of September, Mr. Losh said. Full-sized pickup trucks require virtually no discounts to sell, and G.M. had very few of them until the end of the quarter because it was changing the design.
The weakening of the dollar this month may also make it harder for foreign auto makers to offer discounts, easing the pressure on G.M. to provide large discounts. "One of the things that ought to help us is the yen is not 135 or 145" to the dollar, Mr. Losh said. The dollar was trading at 119.15 yen late today in New York.
Financial analysts generally accepted G.M.'s predictions that with the strike more than two months in the past, discounts might dwindle. "Once you get your '98 models cleared out and your floor traffic back, then you can cut the incentives," said Greg L. Salchow, an auto analyst at Roney & Company, a brokerage house here.
Investors had little reaction today to G.M.'s results. Shares of G.M. fell 87.5 cents, to $51.0625, in a falling market.
G.M. announced plans in August to sell or spin off a 20 percent stake in Delphi Automotive Systems, its huge auto parts subsidiary, early next year, and Mr. Losh reaffirmed those plans today. G.M.'s longstanding intention to wait until next year may allow enough time for financial markets to settle down, he said.
The strike pushed G.M.'s cash reserves down to $11.5 billion on Sept. 30 from $14.6 billion a year earlier and $12.1 billion on June 30. Mr. Losh said that G.M. expected the reserves to rebound soon to the company's target of $13 billion. When that happens, G.M. will resume the $4 billion share buyback program that it announced in March and suspended last summer in response to the strike, he added.
One of the sharpest tumbles in G.M.'s earnings occurred in the unit handling automotive operations in Latin America, Africa and the Middle East. Mainly because of the high interest rates and weak economy in Brazil, previously one of G.M.'s most profitable markets, the division reported a loss in the third quarter of $64 million after a $165 million after-tax profit a year earlier.
G.M. automotive operations in Europe earned $50 million in the third quarter after losing $21 million in the quarter a year earlier. G.M.'s tiny Asian automotive division made $2 million in profits in the last three months after losing $7 million in the third quarter of last year. The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, which makes car loans and leases, earned $313 million in the third quarter, virtually unchanged from a $312 million gain in the quarter a year earlier.
